Name: Empowering Young Women to Lead Transformative Change YWCA (CIF)
External_Title__c: Empowering Young Women in Haiti to Lead Transformative Change
Summary__c: "Empowering Young Women to Lead Transformative Change" aims to address social taboos, educate, and strengthen the capacities of vulnerable young women 18 to 25 years old. The beneficiaries will stem from poor economic backgrounds, with limited social and political power, low self-esteem, and little career opportunities. During its 12 month duration, the project will take place at the YWCA Haiti Center, located at #52 Rue Goulard, Petion-Ville, Haiti. A total of 240 young women will benefit directly from weekly Leadership Academy trainings and an additional 15 will receive training from the Institut de Développement Personnel et Organisationnel S.A.(IDEO), an implementing partner. IDEO is contracted to instruct mentor trainers using the material that has recently been developed by YWCA Haiti, HAGN and other partners; and to help monitor, along with a contracted M&E specialist, trained young women’s performance. By the end of the program, these young women will have the capacity to continue training the current mentors of the 16 organizations belonging to the Haiti Adolescent Girls Network delivering the Espas Pa Mwen program in the West and Southeast Department. This will enable the YWCA Haiti to continue it’s Leadership Academy program as well as strengthen the capacities and sustainable aspect of the HAGN mentors. The current staff of the YWCA Haiti and the Haiti Adolescent Girls Network will be in charge of implementing the project.

Name: RFL-Phone Project-Texas Gulf Coast
Summary__c:
**Pilot project began in FY14 and continues in FY15*
The pilot project seeks to partner with the organization, Ozanam, for the purpose of providing international calls to migrants traveling through Texas.  Service provision will be implemented through the partnership.  This effectively means that the organization will provide a space and a phone, while the American Red Cross will provide material resources in the form of international calling cards, two volunteers, informational materials and material resources.  To implement the program, the ARC volunteer will use the attached American Red Cross call guidelines (see attached).  In addition to implementing this initiative using American Red Cross guidelines, the volunteer will also provide a monthly log of the calls.  Each call is a reconnection to a family member and can potentially provide important contact and knowledge of the migrant’s well-being.  It is estimated that the need for calls home will reach 340 minutes a month, with an initial ask for 1,000 minutes worth of international calls for a three month period. 
 
In addition to providing international calling cards for this organization, the American Red Cross Texas Gulf Coast Region seeks to supplement this partnership with additional material resources, which are needed by the beneficiaries.  Specifically, the partner has asked the American Red Cross to contribute 400 units of comfort kits, which would be used by migrants coming to the shelter.  These comfort kits provide basic hygiene needs which are desperately needed by migrants who have had limited access to water, and have traveled the rough terrain with limited access to water and basic hygiene.

Name: RFL-Phone Projects- El Paso
Summary__c:
*project that began in FY14 and carrying-over to FY15*
Thet project seeks to partner with the Opportunity Center for the Homeless, for the purpose of providing international calls to migrants traveling through Ciudad Juarez/EI Paso border. Service provision will be implemented through the partnership.  This effectively means that due to locations of the Living Centers and the transient nature of the migrants coming to the shelters, it is seen as best practice to entrust the partner organization with the material support; mobile phones with international calling capabilities since they have full- time staff on site to implement the program. In addition to implementing this initiative using American Red Cross guidelines, the partners have agreed to provide a monthly log of the calls. Each call is a reconnection to a family member and can potentially provide important contact and knowledge
of the migrant's well-being .

Name: RFL-Phone Projects-San Diego
Summary__c:
*this is a carry-over project that began in FY14*
Partner with organizations that serve migrants, farmers, and workers and provide their clients with a way to reestablish contact with family members and tell them they are safe and well. We also aim to assist them with basic medical aid.  This grant will provide the funds needed to purchase the necessary equipment and plans to fulfill our proposal. The first aid kits supplemented with additional antibacterial ointment and bandages will help with our client's medical needs. The international calling plan, Skype monthly subscription, and signal boosters will be necessary to give our clients a way to call their family members internationally

Name: Canaan Social Engagement Program
Summary__c:
Canaan is a rapidly emerging city north of Port-au-Prince in the West Department, now estimated to be between 100,000 and 150,000 residents. Canaan developed after the 2010 earthquake in response to the establishment and operation of a relocation settlement as well as a Haitian government declaration of eminent domain of the surrounding area. The city has received little external assistance from Haitian authorities or the international community. However, Canaan continues to grow with grassroots investments by local households; these investments were estimated at US$100 million as of July 2013.

The lack of government oversight has caused Canaan to grow similarly to informal settlements of Port-au- Prince, with poor access to basic services, construction and urbanization in areas at high exposure to natural hazard, and inadequate waste management systems. Furthermore, social cohesion in Canaan is only in nascent stages, given that most of the residents have been there for approximately two years or less.

This program represents the first significant investment in the zone in social engagement, coming at a critical time before United States Agency for International Development (USAID) in partnership with American Red Cross (ARC) and Unité de Construction de Logements et de Bâtiments Publics (UCLBP) begins implementation of the $12 million, livelihoods and infrastructure work in early 2015 as part of the Canaan Urban Development Program. This program proposes to build community cohesion by establishing fair community representation structures and engaging the community in common concerns surrounding Disaster Risk Reduction (DRR) and the environment. This work will provide a foundation for future implementing actors in the city to begin work. The program therefore proposes to start in December 2014 and continue for 18 months until May 2016. As this program is one of the first interventions in Canaan, it aims to target the entire population, an estimated 100,000 to 150,000 people. In particular, marginalized groups (including women and youth) will receive greater emphasis to ensure they are fairly represented in community structures.

The overall program goal is to mobilize and organize the communities within Canaan to improve their resilience. This will be accomplished through three programmatic axes: (1) social engagement; (2) disaster risk reduction; (3) environmental engagement. 

These three axes correspond to three program objectives: 
  1. Increase community cohesion, representation and capacity to engage national and local government, as well as international organizations; 
  2. Communities are better prepared against natural disasters with increased understanding of natural hazards and risks;
  3. Increase community understanding of local environmental concerns and engagement for improving the environmental status.
These objectives will be accomplished by coordinating with the Haitian government and other implementing actors to define a common social engagement approach and to establish community platforms that are representative of the communities. These platforms will engage Haitian authorities and support community assessments in DRR and environmental concerns, as well as the establishment of long-term entities responsible for follow up activities (e.g. establishing Community Intervention Teams with Department of Civil Protection).

The program will be directly implemented by ARC in close coordination with the Haitian Red Cross (HRC). Consultants will be engaged on a punctual basis for surge capacity or technical expertise. The HRC will play a vital role in mobilizing their volunteer network in Canaan to build community cohesion and buy in as well as conduct household level messaging on key messages related to DRR and the environment.

Name: Israel, Occupied Palestinian Territories Complex Emergency-2014
Summary__c: Hostilities between Israel and Hamas and other armed groups in the Gaza Strip escalated on July 7; fighting further intensified when Israel began a ground operation in Gaza on July 17th. The hostilities further exacerbated the serious humanitarian situation of the civilian population in Gaza, which is already dealing with chronic difficulties largely brought about by restrictions on the movement of people and goods and the fragility of infrastructure and basic services. On August 26, a ceasefire was agreed between Hamas and the Israeli government.

Name: Support for Hopital de 'lUniversite d'Etat d'Haiti (HUEH) through PiH
External_Title__c: Support for University Hospital through Partners in Health
Summary__c: This project provides 100% support for an exclusive contribution towards payroll for the local employees that have or will perform active services at the l'Hôpital de l'Université d'Etat d'Haïti (HUEH) from January 12, 2010 through September 30, 2010. This emergency funding will allow for continued operations of HUEH and thus continued care for victims of the January 12th earthquake. It will also allow for the continued delivery of medical care to the general public through the Hospital’s walk-in Triage Department that is currently open 24 hours, seven days per week. HUEH is the largest medical center in Haiti and the sole public national referral hospital for specialty care. The national public health system in Haiti relies on HUEH for care that is otherwise unavailable anywhere else within the country. The PIH/ZL program to provide staff salary for Haitian HUEH staff for nine months will provide the immediate support required for the hospital to adequately and sustainably care for the patients in its wards and at its doors.

Name: Cholera Prevention and Treatment Efforts through FRC
External_Title__c: Cholera Prevention and Treatment Efforts through French Red Cross
Summary__c: The Red Cross has coordinated an aggressive response to the cholera outbreak that has spread throughout Haiti and into areas of the Dominican Republic.  As part of this response, the American Red Cross partnered with the French Red Cross to support hygiene promotion programs, an ambulance service, the creation of camp hygiene and sanitation committees, disinfection of latrines and public places, cleaning drainage systems, installing and managing Oral Rehydration Posts, chlorinating local water supplies, and distributing soap, chlorine, waste bins and water drums. The French Red Cross also set up a number of Cholera Treatment Units in Port au Prince and is rehabilitating three primary healthcare centers in Petit Goave. This project reached 403,661 people.

Name: Directly Implemented Cholera Prevention in Camps and Communities
Summary__c: The Red Cross has coordinated an aggressive response to the cholera outbreak that has spread throughout Haiti and into areas of the Dominican Republic.  The American Red Cross is working to stem the spread of the disease as well as provide care for those infected by it. As part of this effort, the American Red Cross trained staff and volunteers to go out into camps and communities across the country to provide cholera and hygiene education. The teams also distribute soap, oral rehydration solution and water purification tablets.  This project has also set up Oral Rehydration Points and Posts, where trained volunteers can refer cholera patients that they encounter to proper treatment facilities. This program built upon similar work that the American Red Cross has been doing in Port-au-Prince since the start of the outbreak in October 2010, while expanding its reach to parts of Haiti’s North.

Name: Guatemala Drought-2016
Summary__c: The ongoing El Niño phenomenon has worsened existing drought conditions, affecting 110,000 families in Guatemala’s dry corridor. Most of those affected work in agriculture, reporting crop loss of 50 percent or more. Families estimate that food reserves will be depleted by April 2016.

Name: Cholera Response and Treatment Efforts through CARE
Summary__c: The Red Cross has coordinated an aggressive response to the cholera outbreak that has spread throughout Haiti and into areas of the Dominican Republic.  As part of this response, the American Red Cross partnered with CARE to establish Oral Rehydration Points, support schools with cholera prevention activities, facilitate cholera case management training, ensure water and sanitation support to eight health facilities and prevent the spread of cholera through education and the distribution of critical relief supplies. The project reached over 500,000 people.

Name: Responding to Cholera through IHRC
External_Title__c: Responding to Cholera through the Interim Haiti Recovery Commission
Summary__c: The Red Cross is coordinating an aggressive response to the cholera outbreak that has spread throughout Haiti and into areas of the Dominican Republic. As part of this response, the American Red Cross partnered with the Interim Haiti Recovery Commission (IHRC), providing 5,000 cots from its domestic warehouses for distribution to medical facilities treating cholera patients.

Name: Operational Support for Bernard Mevs Hospital through Project Medishare
Summary__c: The American Red Cross has supported the payment of operating expenses, payroll and administrative fees for the Bernard Mevs Hospital Project Medishare Critical Care Trauma and Rehabilitation Program in Port au Prince. The hospital operates 24/7 for the general public, providing the only critical care and trauma services for all of Haiti. The Hospital Bernard Mevs Project Medishare employs 190 staff members.

Name: Post-Earthquake Health and Hygiene Promotion in Camps
Summary__c: The American Red Cross Post-Earthquake Health Promotion Program followed a community-based approach to providing first aid and promoting hygiene, health and safety in the camps. Program activities included hygiene promotion, condom distribution, and education on preventing cholera, malaria, HIV, and sexual and gender-based violence.  The program also conducted disease mitigation activities in the camps.  In most cases, this program worked in the same locations as the Emergency Disaster Risk Reduction program, complementing disaster risk reduction work with health and hygiene promotion services to camp communities.

Name: Cholera Prevention and Treatment Efforts through PAHO
External_Title__c: Cholera Prevention & Treatment Efforts through Pan American Health Organization
Summary__c: The Red Cross has coordinated an aggressive response to the cholera outbreak that has spread throughout Haiti and into areas of the Dominican Republic.  As part of this response, the American Red Cross partnered with the Pan American Health Organization (PAHO) to purchase, ship and store some 1.4 million solutions of Oral Rehydration Salts, 480,000 bags of Ringer Lactate and a variety of other life-saving medicines and medical supplies during the critical early stages of the response.  This partnership also enabled PAHO to purchase logistical equipment for their warehouse, implement an online information management system to track stock and medicines available in their warehouse, produce cholera beds and train Ministry of Health personnel for the transition of the cholera Alert and Response System to the Haitian government.

Name: Mobile Medical Services through Belizean Grove Health Foundation
Summary__c: This project aimed to improve the health of women and children in the rural commune of Borgne, Haiti, by providing 12 mobile health clinics as part of the comprehensive cholera prevention and response initiative of a Haitian organization, Haiti Outreach Pwoje Espwa (H.O.P.E), which is supported by the American Red Cross.

Name: Coordinated Vaccination Campaign Round 2 through UN Foundation
Summary__c: This is a resumption of the multi-agency “Coordinated Vaccination Campaign,” described in the record titled "Coordinated Vaccination Campaign Round 1 through UN Foundation," to maintain the elimination status of measles, rubella and polio in Haiti.

Name: Cholera Programming in Port-au-Prince through Save the Children
Summary__c: The Red Cross has coordinated an aggressive response to the cholera outbreak that has spread throughout Haiti and into areas of the Dominican Republic. As part of this response, the American Red Cross partnered with Save the Children to manage Cholera Treatment Units (CTUs), transition the CTUs to Oral Rehydration Points (ORPs) with a referral system to CTUs, and conduct cholera prevention-focused hygiene promotion activities in Port au Prince.  The American Red Cross worked together with the US Agency for International Development’s Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance (USAID/OFDA) to fund this program.

Name: World Disaster Report 2016
Summary__c: This is a cash pledge of $10,000 USD to help support publication of the IFRC's 2016 World Disasters Report.

Name: Transitional Homes through Haven
Summary__c: The global Red Cross network is helping families transition to safer, more secure homes.  To support these efforts, the American Red Cross partnered with a number of international non-governmental organizations to construct transitional homes, which include access to water and sanitation facilities.  As part of this initiative, Haven constructed 499 homes.  The project also included hygiene promotion.

Name: FY15 OD in Guatemala
Summary__c:
This project was submitted by the Guatemalan RC as part of the RFA process that the LAC region organized for OD related proposals. It was chosen as one of 5 proposals to receive up to $10,000.

The project focuses on increasing the capacity of delegations (GRC branches) in the area of financial resource mobilization and financial management. This will be achieved by training the branches on fundraising cycle and resouse management and then working with the branches to establish a strategy for resource mobilization/fundraising, identifying revenue sources and executing plans for diversification of income as well as trainign. Out of the 10 branhes participating, 5 branches with the best fundraising proposals will receive seed money ($500) to kick off their plan and activities/

Name: FY15 OD in Ecuador
Summary__c:
The Ecuadorian Red Cross (ERC) Strategy 2011-2015 has as its fourth strategic objective: “Strengthen the Management and Positioning of the National Society”; and based on this objective it has undertaken a series of efforts to achieve these established goals.
 
To achieve this objective, among other activities, the ERC proposes the project: “STANDARDIZATION OF PROCESSES TO CONSOLIDATE ERC PROVINCIAL BRANCHES FINANCIAL INFORMATION” that aims to improve the accountability and transparency of financial operations, specifically the administration of fixed assets in 18 provincial branches and 1 cantonal branch in the territorial network, which are implementing the VISUAL FAC financial system.
 
These branches need to be strengthened since their current accounting system does not have the module for the administration of fixed assets set up, which makes the creation of timely information for decision making and accountability difficult. The ERC has been working with its branches in the innovation and implementation of technologies that allow them to substitute the manual and off-the-books registers for a tool that allows them to optimize time and resources, as well as the automatic generation of reports for decision making.

SCOPE:  

Goal: Standardization of processes to consolidate ERC provincial branches financial information

The project aims to implement the module for the administration and control of fixed assets in the Fac Visual System (version 9.0) in 18 provincial branches and 1 cantonal branch, as well as provide technical support and accompaniment from the ERC to standardize the implementation of current policies and regulations. This proposal will start with the training of the project members and will define a timetable for the gathering of information on fixed assets
Objective
Strengthen the administrative management through the improvement of the accountability and transparency of financial operations in 18 provincial branches and 1 cantonal branch in the territorial network, which have started the process of standardization, through the following activities:
 
Objective 1: Provincial and cantonal branches, with the module for the administration of fixed assets implemented, used and creating reports.
Objective 2: Accounting- financial personnel from the branches trained in the implementation of institutional standards that strengthen the control and administration of assets.
 
The expected products are:
  1. Provincial and canton branches with a module for the administration of fixed assets implemented, used and creating reports.
  2. Accounting- financial personnel from the branches trained in the implementation of institutional standards that strengthen the control and administration of assets.
 
Activities to be implemented include: training to update knowledge of the administration of fixed assets and the acquisition of modules for fixed assets, and support and monitoring for 19 branches.
 
BUDGET:  

Total Budget: The total budgeted for this project is $12,114.00 USD.
  • ARC will provide $10,000.00 USD to support the project, while the remaining $2,114.00 USD will come from ERC’s cost-share.  
TIME:  

Time: The project will be completed in 6 months, commencing January 1st 2015 and ending on June 30th 2015

Name: Liberia Social Mobilization 2015
External_Title__c: Strengthening the Nationwide Measles Follow-Up Supplemental Immunization Activit
Summary__c:
The Liberian Red Cross Society requests support in the amount of $208,378.00 for the implementation of a social mobilization campaign to coincide with the upcoming Liberia national vaccination campaign.  The Liberian Red Cross Society will train and mobilize volunteers to conduct house to house cavassing in six out of the fifteen administrative counties targetted during the campaign.  The planned activities and  outcomes of the project are as follows.

Activities:
  • To train at least  2,850 Red Cross volunteers in Measles Supplemental Immunization activities (SIAs) strategy for delivering a second opportunity of measles vaccine to all children 9-59 months of age, before 30th November, 2015 
  • To conduct pre-campaign house to house canvassing/dialogue visits and social mobilization on the importance of measles vaccination to 433,511 households of the 6 project Counties by 14th of May, 2015 
  • To support 100% of vaccination sites in the 6 targeted project counties to reach 95% SIAs coverage of the 368,484 targeted infants aged 9-59 months 
  • To conduct a post campaign search for adverse events following immunization and document that at least 95% children 9-59 months were reached in the 2015 Measles SIAs in Liberia
  • To procure 3,000 T-shirts to promote visibility of measles SIAs and Liberia Red Cross  
Outcomes
  • 2,850 Red Cross volunteers trained in social mobilization for Measles SIAs
  • 433,511 households reached and parents/caretakers receive the correct information regarding the measles SIAs before the vaccination dates.
  • 368,484 eligible children receive the supplemental measles vaccination dose.
  • 3000 T-shirts/Aprons procured to promote LNRCS visibility and capacity  in health interventions

Name: FY15 OD in Costa Rica
Summary__c:
Due the need identified the need to strengthen certain areas of the NS, in particular as in the areas of organizational capacity and planning processes to increase project management capacity and promote the empowerment and leadership of the auxiliary Red Cross branches, and given the interest of the American Red Cross delegation in strengthening the sustainability of efforts previously implemented in 2013 and 2014 in Central America, a survey to identify the main institutional strengthening needs of the National Societies was conducted. The results of the survey demonstrate that there are several key areas that need to be strengthened. 

In Costa Rica, the Costa Rican Red Cross identified the need to work on an effective strategy to strengthen its branches, on project management, planning and organizing of activities; as well as the need to develop annual operational plans which are a condition to receiving the state subsidy.

As such OD activites in Costa Rica will focus on streghtening project organization and planning capacity, strengthening the capacity of the technical and administrative staff of the National Society to formulate, manage and implement integrated projects aligned with the National Society  Strategic Plans, and salary support to a a regional board administrator who will be responsible for developing an annual work plan that includes community development activities as these activities are a determinant in the distribution of the state grant that the National Society gives to each of the branches. .

Name: FY15 OD in Belize for Strategic Planning
Summary__c:
The Belize Red Cross has embarked on a restructuring of its Headquarters with priority placed on the productive functions of the National Society and strategic direction that will take the National Society to self- sustainability and development of its greatest assets, Volunteers and Members. A restructuring plan and a log frame for the years 2014 and 2015 have been developed and are aligned to the National Society’s last 5-year Strategic Plan (2011-2015), the Inter American Framework for Action as well as IFRC’s Strategy 2020.  However, the National Society’s Strategic Plan for 2010-2015 expires in December, 2015.
 
The process for development of a new 5-year Strategic Plan (2016-2020) requires the support of a National (countrywide) consultation for a National Society Development Plan which will inform the strategic direction for the next 5 years, aligning the Belize Red Cross to the demands and needs of the most vulnerable communities as well as to address some of the country's humanitarian priorities in a self-sustainable manner, while maintaining relevance within the region. The project will provide financial and technical support to the Belize Red Cross for the development of a new 5-year Strategic Plan 2016-2020 through a National (countrywide) consultation and a National Society Development Plan.  These two plans will guide the National Society’s work for the next 5 years.
 
Specific intended outcomes of the project are:
  1. The Belize Red Cross has a National Society Development Plan that informs the National Strategic Plan 2016 – 2020.
  2. The Belize Red Cross has a National Strategic Plan (2016-2020) that provides direction for the National Society’s role and functions within Belize
  3. The Belize Red Cross has increased capacity for sustainability and improved their service delivery.

Name: Ethiopia Population Movement-2015
Summary__c: Violence in South Sudan since December 2013  is creating a complex humanitarian crisis, with a large flux of refugees into Ethiopia. Ethiopia now has the largest number of refugees in Africa, with approximately 644,000 refugees. 196,500 of thse are from Sound Sudan. A majority of the refugee camps in Ethiopia have reached, or are reaching full capacity. Main concerns include building a new refugee camp, malnutrition among refugees, as well as critical shortfalls in humanitarian aid.

Name: RFL-Training-Nebraska
Summary__c: The Kansas Nebraska SW Iowa Region is applying for a grant to train volunteers and staff in Restoring Family Links casework. This will greatly increase the region's ability to serve local communities with reconnecting families needs. The grant will also support outreach efforts later in the fiscal year once the capacity of the region to do outreach has grown.

Name: FY15 OD in Nicaragua
Summary__c:
Due the need identified the need to strengthen certain areas of the NS, in particular as in the areas of organizational capacity and planning processes to increase project management capacity and promote the empowerment and leadership of the auxiliary Red Cross branches, and given the interest of the American Red Cross delegation in strengthening the sustainability of efforts previously implemented in 2013 and 2014 in Central America, a survey to identify the main institutional strengthening needs of the National Societies was conducted. The results of the survey demonstrate that there are several key areas that need to be strengthened. 

In Nicaragua, the The Nicaraguan Red Cross has identified the need to strengthen the capacity of branch staff in project management, resource mobilization, organization and planning.

As such OD activites in Nicaragua will focus on resource mobilization and project managment at the branch level, streghtening project organization and planning capacity and  strengthening the capacity of the technical and administrative staff of the National Society to formulate, manage and implement integrated projects aligned with the National Society Strategic Plans.

Name: Emergency Shelter through Habitat for Humanity
Summary__c: Following the January 2010 earthquake, over a million Haitians were left in need of emergency shelter.  In addition to distributing supplies directly through relief teams on the ground, the American Red Cross partnered with Habitat for Humanity to provide approximately 70,000 people with emergency shelter kits. The kits enabled beneficiaries to either construct a new shelter or make repairs to an existing shelter.  Additional kits have been pre-positioned for use in future disaster responses. Each kit contained the following components: two 5-gallon buckets, two tarpaulins, rope, wire, nails, duct tape, a hammer, a pry bar, two chisels, pliers, 10 dust masks, leather work gloves, safety glasses, a hacksaw with two replacement blades, and a folding knife.

Name: Prosthetics Clinic Support through ICRC
External_Title__c: Prosthetics Clinic Support through International Committee of Red Cross
Summary__c: Injuries from the earthquake resulted in the loss of limbs for more than 5,000 survivors.  With support from the American Red Cross, the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) helped rebuild a prosthetic and physical rehabilitation center, Klinik Kay Kapab, run by the Haitian NGO Healing Hands for Haiti.  The ICRC also provided technical assistance for the center to be able to create prosthetic devices for 1,000 people and provide rehabilitation services for 3,000 people.

Name: Shelter Paint Kits through FRC
External_Title__c: Shelter Paint Kits through French Red Cross
Summary__c: The global Red Cross network is helping families transition to safer, more secure homes. To support these efforts, the American Red Cross partnered with the French Red Cross to improve the sustainability of transitional homes built by the French Red Cross. Through this partnership, 1,250 vulnerable displaced families received a paper voucher with a maximum value of 6,000 GDES (US$120) to be used to purchase a paint kit. Painting the homes helps them better withstand inclement weather, thus making them more durable.

Name: RFL-World Refugee Day-Phoenix
Summary__c: The grant will fund the organization of the World Refugee Day 2015 in Phoenix.

Name: Field Hospital Support through GRC
External_Title__c: Field Hospital Support through German Red Cross
Summary__c: The American Red Cross provided support to the German Red Cross Society for the operation of a field hospital located in Carrefour, just outside of Port au Prince.  The field hospital opened immediately after the earthquake and continued to provide free medical services through the end of December 2010, treating over 70,000 patients.  The hospital provided both fixed and mobile health services, as well as training for volunteers to provide psychosocial support and community health and hygiene promotion.  In addition to supporting the operation of the hospital and the salaries of the staff, the American Red Cross is now providing support to rehabilitate the soccer field that housed the hospital after the hospital shut down.

Name: Transitional Shelter through UNOPS
External_Title__c: Transitional Shelter through  United Nations Office for Project Services
Summary__c: The global Red Cross network is helping families transition to safer, more secure homes.  To support these efforts, the American Red Cross partnered with a number of international non-governmental organizations to construct transitional homes, which include access to water and sanitation facilities.  As part of this initiative, the United Nations Office for Project Services (UNOPS) constructed 1,500 transitional homes and supported rubble removal as a part of this process.

Name: Livelihoods and Host Family Support through Fonkoze
Summary__c: Destruction from the January 12 earthquake deprived many Haitians of the livelihoods they depended on to support their families and left them either displaced or hosting displaced relatives or friends, putting enormous stress on already scarce resources. To address this problem, the American Red Cross partnered with Fonkoze, Haiti’s largest microfinance institute, to provide microfinance grants and loans to reach 220,810 people, including female heads-of-households, business owners and families hosting displaced Haitians.

Name: Transitional Homes through ACTED
External_Title__c: Transitional Homes through Agency for Technical Cooperation and Development
Summary__c: The global Red Cross network is helping families transition to safer, more secure homes. To support these efforts, the American Red Cross is partnering with a number of international non-governmental organizations to construct transitional homes, which include access to clean water and the installation of family latrines. As part of this initiative, the Agency for Technical Cooperation and Development (ACTED) has constructed 1,706 transitional homes, 1500 latrines and 1700 rainwater harvesting systems. They will also conduct hygiene promotion and disaster risk reduction activities.

Name: FY15 OD in Myanmar for Technical Support for CAS Facilitator
Summary__c:
This project is a contribution to the Danish RC, who are hiring a Cooperation Assistance Strategy (CAS) facilitator on behalf of Myanmar Red Cross.  This contribution will be expended by the end of American RC’s FY 2015, in line with ARCT donor requirements. 
 
At the Partnership Meeting in October 2013, Myanmar Red Cross Society (MRCS) and its Red Cross Red Crescent partners agreed that the development of Cooperation Agreement Strategy (CAS) was necessary in the light of the MRCS working in a rapidly evolving and complex environment with an increasing number of partners and opportunities for a better coordinated approach in its effort to improve service delivery and organizational capacities, and better financial sustainability or recognition.
 
The purpose of CAS Facilitator is to facilitate a process of participatory development of the MRCS Cooperation Agreement Strategy that guides the collective objectives and actions of the National Society and its partners and supports the capacity building of MRCS on CAS process.
 
Specific responsibilities of the CAS facilitator can be found in the TOR, which is attached to the grant letter.

Name: RFL-Outreach-South Carolina
Summary__c: South Carolina is applying for an outreach grant in order to participate in a local event with the refugee community and organization serving refugees. This event will help the local chapter build relationships with both the organizations that serve populations that have potential reconnecting families needs as well as the communities themselves. The grant will also fund an RFL banner which is a great promotional tool for chapter's to use at events.

Name: RFL-Training-Instructors
Summary__c: The purpose of this project is to train RFL Instructors in the top 20 regions in the United States.

Name: FY15 OD in Panama
Summary__c:
Due the need identified the need to strengthen certain areas of the NS, in particular as in the areas of organizational capacity and planning processes to increase project management capacity and promote the empowerment and leadership of the auxiliary Red Cross branches, and given the interest of the American Red Cross delegation in strengthening the sustainability of efforts previously implemented in 2013 and 2014 in Central America, a survey to identify the main institutional strengthening needs of the National Societies was conducted. The results of the survey demonstrate that there are several key areas that need to be strengthened. 

In Panama, the Panamanian Red Cross identified the need to create a project liaison office which would develop tools, improve institutional project management and align the Annual Operational Plan as well as the need to strengthen the capacity of branches in project management, planning, and organizing of activities.

As such OD activites in Panama will focus on creating and strenghtening a Liason office, streghtening project organization and planning capacity and  strengthening the capacity of the technical and administrative staff of the National Society to formulate, manage and implement integrated projects aligned with the National Society  Strategic Plans.

Name: FY15 OD in El Salvador
Summary__c:
Due the need identified the need to strengthen certain areas of the NS, in particular as in the areas of organizational capacity and planning processes to increase project management capacity and promote the empowerment and leadership of the auxiliary Red Cross branches, and given the interest of the American Red Cross delegation in strengthening the sustainability of efforts previously implemented in 2013 and 2014 in Central America, a survey to identify the main institutional strengthening needs of the National Societies was conducted. The results of the survey demonstrate that there are several key areas that need to be strengthened. 

In El Salvador, the Salvadoran Red Cross identified the need to have an efficient resource management strategy, strengthen its branches, project management, and support in planning and organizational processes to improve structure and decision making processes

As such OD activites in El Salvador will focus on strengthening the organizational development of the branches of the Red Cross, to develop, manage and implement projects and self-management processes that enable them to have the necessary resources to develop sustainable actions in benefit of community work. This will also include salary support to the Sensuntepeque branch Administrator in order to help these processes and have this person design and active a management plan for the branch.

Name: RFL-Volunteer Outreach-Arizona New Mexico El Paso Region
Summary__c: The aim of this project is to continue community involvement in and build community support for the work of the Red Cross with migrant communities in southern Arizona. The project will involve an exhibition and a senior paper and will focus on the child immigration crisis, community volunteer invovlvement and preparedness. The Red Cross will be the prominent sponsor for the exhibition and the Santa Cruz Office of Emergency Management as well as Zonta International will be hosting tables.

Name: FY15 OD in Peru
Summary__c:
One of the points of the newly approved Peruvian Red Cross statutes is the creation of the category of “associate sponsors". These are the individuals that make periodic financial contributions to the National Society, in order to generate funding sources and resources to develop institutional and sustainable community development programs.
 
Since it is a new initiative, the purpose of this project is to design a plan to attract subscribers partners, to guide the implementation of a pilot project to capture associate sponsors in the city of Lima

SCOPE:  

Goal: Develop a plan to attract associate sponsors, who can be part of the implementation of a pilot project in the city of Lima, which can then be replicated nationally through PRC’s provincial branches.


Objective
Attract Sponsors
 
The expected products are:
  • R1.- To have an appropriate Action Plan elaborated for Capturing of associate partners .
  • R2.- Enhanced Public Image and External Communications of the Peruvian Red Cross.
  • R3 Registration of associate sponsors incorporated into the Peruvian Red Cross.
 
Activities to be implemented include:
  • Designing a Plan of Action to attract sponsors
  • Design traveling stand/module
  • Design and development of outreach information
  • Recruitment Campaigns
 
BUDGET:  

Total Budget: The total budgeted for this project is $15,875.00 USD.
  • ARC will provide $10,000.00 USD to support the project, while the remaining $5,875.00 USD will come from PRC’s cost-share.  
TIME:  

Time: The project will be completed in 6 months, commencing January 1st 2015 and ending on June 30th 2015

Name: Improving First Aid and Emergency Health Services in Canaan through HRC
External_Title__c: Improving First Aid and Emergency Health Services in Canaan
Summary__c:
Canaan, a suburb of Croix-des-Bouquets, located North of the Greater Port-au-Prince Metropolitan area, has been settled by surviviors of the 2010 earthquake in a rapidly growing urbanization process.  As of 2013, the growing population was estimated between 100,000 and 150,000 inhabitants. The agglomaration lacks the basic social services, including functional public medical or health services. The state health referral center located nearby is not functional due to the unavailability of medical staff and other critical resources.

The GoH, the International Olympic Committee (IOC) and their partners have made a considerable investment of roughly $18M through the construction of a the Sport for Hope Center, the largest sports facility of its kind in Haiti.  The sports complex aims at supporting social development through sports funded by the IOC and the United Nations.  It offers, among other services, a First Aid and Emergency Health Point (FAEHP) operated by the Haitian Red Cross.

The FAEHP provides key services to the sports complex in the area of injury management as it represents the only functional medical facility in the area. As such, it provides services not only to the sports center but also to the surrounding communities of Canaan.

The goal of this project is to increase resilience of the Sport for Hope Center's users and Canaan community members through improved access to first aid and emergency health services.

Name: InterAmerica Framework for Action (IAFA) 2016-2020
External_Title__c: InterAmerica Framework for Action

Name: Pakistan Monsoon Floods-2014
Summary__c:
• Heavy monsoon rains produced flash floods along four  rivers in eastern Pakistan during the first week of September.  The flooding caused homes to collapse in the Punjab, Gilgit Baltistan and Azad Jammu & Kashmir  regions and  triggered landslides, resulting in loss of life, damage to property and infrastructure, and  agricultural and livestock losses.
  • However, according to the latest flood alert from the Pakistan Meteorological Department, all the major rivers are back to flowing at their normal state of flow and flood levels are decreasing.
  • The flooding in Pakistan has affected 2.3 million people and caused more than 350 deaths and 620 injuries in affected regions of the country. More than 47,000 houses have been destroyed or damaged and millions of crops have been wiped out, which will have large implications for food security and livelihoods.
  • The greatest needs in the flood affected areas of the country include food, emergency shelter, health, and water and sanitation.

Name: FY15 OD Support for Caribbean Delegation Office
Summary__c:
The American Red Cross’ (ARC) Caribbean Delegation (Car Del) requests nearly $40,000 of new
Ann Ray Charitable Trust Capable Partners funding for a seven-month project (December 1st, 2014 to June 30th, 2015) to support the CRRO’s efforts to address critical organizational development priorities in the Caribbean.[1]  The proposed project will target The Bahamas, Grenada, Guyana, and St. Kitts and Nevis Red Cross Societies.  Based on the technical capacity of the CRRO and the priorities identified with each target Red Cross Society, the proposed project will look to contribute to the organizational development of the target national societies by addressing the following:
  • Leadership and youth development & engagement (Bahamas Red Cross, Grenada Red Cross, Guyana Red Cross, St. Kitts and Nevis Red Cross);
  • Volunteer management (St. Kitts and Nevis, Grenada Red Cross); and
  • Branch development (Bahamas Red Cross).
Leveraging the CRRO’s mandate to support Organizational Development priorities of the National Societies in the Caribbean along with strength of the CRRO technical and relationship focal persons, the proposed project will develop work plans with NS to address key OD priorities, provide routine mentorship to NS to implement work plans, and conduct periodic visits to monitor the implementation of the work plan and provide technical support.  Through these activities, the proposed project will aim to support the objectives to strengthen youth engagement, leadership, and volunteer-focused organizational development capacity of target NS in the Caribbean, key priorities identified in the CRRO’s Organizational Development Plan.  Although this proposal does not intend to fully address each objective immediately, it does seek to catalyze and reinforce CRRO’s capacity to provide routine consultation and technical support to ultimately help NS address their long-term priorities.  This effort will also look to support the Car Del’s Resilience in the Americas FY15[2] strategy and draft LAC Strategy Objective IV[3] to promote resilience by contributing to regional cooperation and collaboration with Movement actor (Annex 1, RITA FY15 Proposal).
 
[1] Regional priorities were identified through CRRO’s conversation with NS leadership, which lead to the development of Country Support Plans. These plans reiterate the priorities from the more in depth research from a 2007 Study of the Americas report (annexed).   ARC’s Caribbean Delegation’s experience in the region and long-standing relationships with target NS further validates this regional prioritization.
[2] The RITA program is a multi-year resilience initiative aimed at reducing communities’ vulnerabilities and increasing their ability to remain healthy, connected and organized.  The Car Del’s FY15 RITA program will be implemented across 38 communities in Belize, Bahamas, Guyana, and Jamaica.  A key component of FY15 RITA is enhancing the organizational development of target NS (Objective 1: Strengthen OD and capacity of NS through direct technical, financial, and coordination support).  This project proposal aims to directly contribute to that effort for The Bahamas and Guyana Red Cross Societies.
[3] The draft LAC Strategic Objective 3 is to enhance delivery of our humanitarian mandate by responsibly engaging in movement coordination.

Name: Micronesia Community Resilience and Capacity Development (CRCD)
External_Title__c: Micronesia Community Resilience and Capacity Development (CRCD)
Sub_Sector__c: Community-Based Disaster Preparedness;National Society Response Readiness;Project Management;Volunteer Management;Early Warning Early Action;Community Mobilization;Education and Awareness;Advocacy;Partnership;Resource Mobilization
Summary__c:
The American Red Cross (ARC) proposes to work with the Micronesia Red Cross (MRCS) and climate-affected small island communities in the Federated States of Micronesia's Chuuk State to carry out coastal community resilience and disaster risk reduction activities which will prepare for and respond to climate risk and climate change. The project goal will be to reduce the number of deaths and injuries and lessen the negative socio-economic impact caused by climate related disasters (e.g. typhoons) and environmental degradation in vulnerable Micronesian Islands. The project will assist the MRCS to improve their overall disaster risk reduction (DRR), communications and resource mobilization capacities in order to sustain a longer term DRR approach throughout the Micronesia archipelago and more effectively support the government of Micronesia, in its official auxiliary role to better prepare for and respond to disasters.  The project intends to achieve this goal through focusing on two objectives: 1) To strengthen exposed disaster prone small island communities of Chuuk State to be better prepared for or mitigate the negative impact caused from reoccurring disasters (i.e. especially typhoons) and adapt to climate change by improving their capacity and enhancing their resilience; and 2) To contribute to improved national Red Cross institutional capacity to confront DRR and climate change adaptation issues.
 
Over a 30-month period, ARC, in collaboration with MRCS, will assist up to nine communities comprised of 22,170 direct beneficiaries and an overall 48,654 persons will indirectly benefit, all of whom are affected by a variety of recurring climate risks and disasters, most especially typhoons, to strengthen the resiliency of their communities in the State of Chuuk.
 
The program goal and related objectives have been organized under two Program Sectors, and relevant sub-sectoral areas, in the Micronesia Community Resilience and Capacity Development Project.

Name: FY15 OD North Pacific Governance and Legal Base Workshop
Summary__c:
The American Red Cross, in coordination with the IFRC Representative to the North Pacific, will support the Executive Director from the Micronesia Red Cross Society (MRCS) to participate in an event to be held in Majuro Atoll, Marshall Islands: a Governance and Legal Base Master Class.  Through this event, the national societies represented will finalize their Constitutions and Rules of Procedure in preparation for their next Annual General Meetings and build some further expertise within the region on these issues.  Senior personnel from IFRC-Geneva will be involved as facilitators. 
 
While participants will come from multiple NS, the American Red Cross support will cover only the costs of MRCS participation.  This is paid for out of the FY 2015 ARCT Capable Partners grant, specifically the pot of funds set aside at the global level for technical assistance.

Name: Philippines Typhoon Hagupit-2014
Summary__c: Typhoon Hagupit (locally known as “Ruby”) has gained strength in the western Pacific and is projected to intensify further as it heads towards the Philippines. The typhoon has maximum sustained winds of 190 kilometers per hour and wind gusts of up to 235 kilometers per hour. It is expected to make landfall on December 6th.

Name: FY15 OD in Tanzania for Governance Induction
Summary__c:
The Tanzania Red Cross Society (TRCS) is requesting $ 20,072 USD from the American Red Cross for the Governance Induction Program to increase our national society’s sustainability, service delivery effectiveness and ultimately greater success in fulfilling our mandate.
 
The Tanzania Red Cross National Society has three important governance levels: the national level, regional level and sub-regional levels (districts and village branches). The governance at regional and sub-regional levels is of paramount importance in providing appropriate guidance and direction. The main problem at these levels arises when the governance is not active or provides ineffective leadership. Key reasons which account for this situation include limited understanding of the Red Cross structure and fundamental principles, as well as the systems and roles of the governance in supporting the national society to achieve its mission. The 2012 elections brought in a number of new faces to the governance leadership. Over 80% of those who were elected at regional level are their first term in governance leadership. This means that the majority of the newly elected governance members have limited understanding of the Red Cross movement, its fundamental principles and statutes; a situation which contributes to their inefficiency in providing guidance and decision making in the day to day Red Cross endeavors. The national society has inducted RMC members from only ten out of twenty regions with regional governance structure; it has failed to induct governance members from the remaining regions due to financial limitations.
 
The proposed project will therefore enable the national society to organize for induction seminars in early January 2015 for RMCs from the remaining ten regions of Dar es Salaam, Dodoma, Morogoro, Mtwara, Pwani, Kaskazini Pemba, Kusini Pemba, Kusini Unguja, Kaskazini Unguja and Mjini Magharibi. Through this project, the governance members will be imparted with relevant knowledge, empowering them to effectively play their roles as envisaged. The implementation of this project will also complete the induction process of governance members from all TRCS regions currently within the regional governance structure.

Name: From Camp Transformation to Urban Revitalization (CATUR) though UN Habitat
External_Title__c: Camp Formalization Through UN Habitat
Summary__c:
More than 3 years after the earthquake, camps remain a major issue for Port-au-Prince Metropolitan Area. According to the CCCM cluster, 55,371households are still living in 312 camps. Without alternatives to relocate or rehouse the poorest households, many residents are strengthening their shelters with concrete blocks and basic structures for water storage . Camp committees and private initiatives are investing in provision of basic services such as community schools, free clinics and shops as most of the camps are socially organized as communities. The process of camp transformation into neighborhood is ongoing without proper planning guidelines and provision of adequate infrastructure. The main risk is the expansion of existing informal and underserviced areas with poor quality and unsafe constructions, in the absence of development controls. 

Rental subsidies for camp closure are currently the main governmental intervention addressing camp issues while the Housing Policy, developed by the Unité de Construction de Logements et de Bâtiments Publics (UCLBP) with support of UN-Habitat, identifies other options like camp formalization, retrofitting rental units, sites and services. Even though a high proportion of the rental subsidy funds are used by landlords to upgrade their buildings, external evaluation on rental allocations show that after one year 75% of the returning families do not remain in the rental accommodation identified and approved under the subsidy scheme. The Camp Coordination and Camp Management cluster (CCCM) is doing an evaluation of rental subsidies impacts, and exploring other options and alternatives such as camp formalization. 

The project aims to assist the government bodies (UCLBP, relevant ministries) and municipal authorities in the building of consensus regarding all camp exit strategies including the less developed alternative of in situ camps upgrading and urban integration. The objective is to strengthen analysis and decision making with a view to ending displacement based on case-by-case survey of specific camps in consultation with the CCCM Cluster.

The project proposes to formalize 2 or 3 selected camps through urban integration with the surrounding neighborhood and through provision of support which could include housing support, rental subsidies, access to basic services such as road, water and sanitation networks, or a combination of these options. The project evaluation, which will be based on lessons learned from the implementation and processes applied, will contribute to systematize the full approach in order to replicate the process. In this vein, the project will provide a platform of methodological support and improved tools to “end displacement”, focusing on “camp formalization”.

Given the Nations’ commitment to use the recovery phase to bridge and support the development of Haiti, this opportunity of guiding the process for camp formalization could pave the way for urban revitalization by looking at a multitude of cross-sectoral issues related to urban development such as local governance, community empowerment, training and capacity building, land issues, housing, in addition to access to basic services, water and sanitation.

Name: FY17 Prepare Central Asia (PCA) in Kyrgyzstan

Name: FY13-15 Resilience in the Americas (IPA/RITA) in Guyana
Summary__c: Currently, there is a tendency to design community based disaster preparedness (CBDP) programs using a prescriptive, standard package of activities. While the activities have proven effective in some contexts, programming in this way neglects to consider articulated community desires and indigenous coping strategies as the basis for program design. It also limits the scope of disaster risk reduction interventions to a core set of CBDP interventions that may not be the most relevant or effective in all environments or that could be strengthened by integrating additional sectors. The proposed integrated, participatory assessment initiative will result in better understanding of the key needs, vulnerabilities, and hazards of diverse, disaster prone communities as well as existing resources that may be mobilized to make them safer and more able to cope with hazards.

Name: Fire Sensors for Safer Urban Communities in East Africa
Sub_Sector__c: (GIS & INFORMATION MANAGEMENT);(KNOWLEDGE MANAGEMENT);(PARTNERSHIPS, NETWORK AND DIALOGUE);(TECHNOLOGY)
Summary__c: Through the Fire Sensors for Safer Urban Communities project the American Red Cross, in collaboration with the Kenya Red Cross, South African Red Cross and other partners, aims to work with 2,000 vulnerable households – a minimum of 1,000 each in Mukuru (Nairobi), Kenya and Khayelitsha (Cape Town), South Africa – to pilot the use of emerging technology to reduce fire risks. The main objectives of the proposed innovation project are to prototype, install and test several models of fire sensors in two locations and to develop a business plan that will drive expansion to other vulnerable urban communities.

Name: FY16 OD in Myanmar with ARCT
External_Title__c: Myanmar Red Cross Society Organizational Development Project 2015-2016
Summary__c:
Problem Statement:
MRCS considers the role of township branches and its capacity building pivotal to service delivery through community based programs. However, the capacity of township branches needs to be enhanced to ensure effective service delivery. The importance of branch capacity development has been highlighted in the MRCS strategic plan 2016-2020. The importance of the branch development was also highlighted in the mid-term review of its strategic plan as well as during Organizational Capacity Assessment and Certification (OCAC) process. MRCS has recently updated its branch development model into a Branch Organizational Capacity Assessment and Certification (BOCA) tool and guidelines.

Project Goal: Targeted MRCS branches have strong capacity to undertake humanitarian assistance in time of disaster and emergency and receive enhanced support for resource mobilization.

Project Objectives and Outputs: 
Objective 1: Targeted MRCS branches have improved capacity to undertake community-based activities to support vulnerable people
Output 1.1: Township branches are aware of their capacities and areas of improvement
Output 1.2: Township branch volunteers are motivated and have skills to function as effective Red Cross leaders and transfer their skills and experiences to counterpart branches
Output 1.3: Township branches have support of the local authorities for its development and carry out its activities in the communities (for two additional branches selected
 
Objective 2: Targeted MRCS branches are better organized and resourced to address community-based services in the long term.
Outputs 2.1: Targeted MRCS branches have cohesive teams including new volunteers with increased capacity to implement the Red Cross services
Output 2.2: Targeted MRCS region branch has successfully transferred its skill to a potential new targeted branch
Output 2.3: Targeted MRCS region branch has implemented fund-raising activities with support from the headquarters
Output 2.4: MRCS national headquarters has structured interaction with corporate and other Red Cross Red Crescent partners through events such as partnership meeting. 
​
Project Locations: 
Long lone, Tanintharyi, Bokepyin townships, Tanintharyi Region, Myanmar
Kayah State, Myanmar

Estimated Beneficiaries:
220 branch volunteers and community members in five townships

Name: FY13-15 Resilience in the Americas (IPA/RITA) in Jamaica
Epidemiological Study of the Causes of Deaths and Injuries in the 2015 Nepal EQ
Summary__c:
The purpose of this project is to identify the causes of injuries and deaths in the April 25 earthquake, which will then provide a basis for education and training of the Nepali public in basic disaster preparedness. Through this study, the implementing agency will seek to answer research questions related to: risk factors associated with injuries; environmental hazards; risk mitigation efforts; disaster response behavior of the public; importance of rapid search and rescue and medical treatment to specific injury outcomes; public perception of effective and feasible ways of disaster preparedness.

1. Design and finalize interviewer-friendly and coding-ready survey form in both English and Nepali
2. Develop scientific random sampling methodology
3. Conduct field data collection of 500 households residing in regular households and IDP camps using mobile survey application on mobile devices
4. Manage survey data uploaded in central server under supervision of dedicated IT and data management personnel
5. Conduct data analysis of the data collected from epidemiological survey; health facility records; perception of health workers and service seekers
6. Prepare a research report up to 5000 words with a focus on instructive summary statistics and implications for disaster preparedness
7. Translate the research report into Nepali
8. Develop a 4-page public education summary of findings in English and Nepali

The contract for the full research assignment will be held between Save the Children and HERD. The contract will be shared with the American Red Cross. Save the Children and the American Red Cross commit to working together to use the findings of the research throughout 2016. This includes: updating the key messages for DRR working with the Nepal Risk Reduction Consortium (NRRC) and organising a joint launch of the findings in Nepal as well as internationally.

External_Title__c: Results Framework

Name: St Louis de Gonzague Track through Global Communities
External_Title__c: St Louis de Gonzague Running Track
Summary__c: On January 12, 2010, Haiti was hit by a devastating earthquake. The Saint-Louis de Gonzague school, one of the most respected academic-based schools in Haiti, suffered severe damage, particularly the school premises in the city center of Port-au-Prince, which were completely destroyed. Historically the school grounds served the community; as a space for youth to exercise and for community groups to host activities aimed at children. To restore this valuable community space, Global Communities will restore and constuct a six-lane certified running track that will serve 1,400 students from the St Louis de Gonzague school and approximately 12,000 students from eight schools in the neighboring Delmas area, as well as athelets that train or compete for the Haiti Field and Track Association. The budget for the track is $150,000. Global Communities will use eight weeks of build time, late April to late June, to complete the project.

Name: Global Resilience Partnership - Stage 3
External_Title__c: Crowdsourcing community resilience in urban slums
Summary__c:
This is the Solution Statement (proposal) for Stage 3 of the Global Resilience Partnership (GRP) design challenge. The American Red Cross (in collaboration with a multi-disciplinary team of partners) had already received a Stage 2 award to develop the solution currently being proposed.

For the solution, ARC-led team is proposing a set of activities around the theme of crowdsourcing resilience data and solutions in urban slum communities. The team will do research and development and preliminary application of the solution in 2 slum communities in Dhaka, Bangladesh. The proposal is for approximately $1 million and would last 2 years.

Name: Nepal Early Recovery WASH Program (TT&WF Chao Foundation)
External_Title__c: Nepal Early Recovery Water, Sanitation and Hygiene Program
Summary__c:
Request for Proposal to the Red Cross: 
Supporting Long-­term Earthquake Recovery in Nepal 

This is a Request for Proposal from the T.T. and W.F. Chao Foundation, a private U.S. foundation 
that is exploring options for supporting long-­‐term  recovery efforts in the wake of the Nepal 
earthquakes. The foundation is considering an initial donation of $250,000 to the  Red  Cross,  
with  the  possibility  of  subsequent  funding  of  $100,000.  Please  send  the Proposal to 
Jennifer Jenkins at Jenkins@law.duke.edu.  Proposals should contain the information requested 
below. We appreciate your work, and look forward to receiving your response. 
 
Project Description 

Please provide a narrative describing the project (or projects) to which this funding would  be  
dedicated.  All  funds  must  be  used  for  the  purpose  of  long-­‐term  recovery  and 
rebuilding efforts in Nepal. The narrative should include the following information: 
•   A detailed  description  of the project(s),  including  goals and precise  activities.  We 
would  be  particularly   interested  in  projects  dedicated  to  building  earthquake-­‐ 
resistant  structures,  possibly  under  the aegis  of the Nepal  Red Cross  Society  and Shelter 
Cluster 
•    A brief summary of your relief efforts in Nepal to date 
•    What  you  have  learned  from  previous  long-­‐term  recovery  efforts  and  how  this  will guide efforts in Nepal  
•    Key project staff and their relevant backgrounds 
•    A project timeline  
•    Outcomes and metrics, including how project success will be demonstrated 
•    Anticipated  challenges  (government  bureaucracy  or  corruption,  disruption  due  to 
weather or aftershocks, etc) and corrective actions 
Project Budget 
Please  provide  an  estimated  budget  that  includes  specifics  about  how  the  $250,000 
would be allocated by relevant categories (wages and labor, supplies, transportation, etc).  
 
Financial and Narrative Reports  

The foundation  will request  semi-­‐annual  narrative  and financial  reports  detailing how the 
donated funds were used, and, when the initial grant has been fully utilized, a final report 
detailing the expenditures and outcomes. Please confirm that you would be able to provide these. 
 
Additional Funding  

After the initial grant has been fully utilized, if the Red Cross needs additional funds 
to  complete  your  recovery  work  in  Nepal,  please  submit  a  follow-­‐up  proposal  for  up  
to $100,000. 

Privacy 

The foundation wishes to maintain its privacy with respect to this inquiry—please 
do  not  publish  or  share  my  name  or  the  name  of  the  foundation  beyond  your  internal 
communications. Thank you. 
 
Contact information 

To  ensure  that  we  have  the  correct  information,  please  include  the  name  and 
contact  information  of  the  primary  person  responsible  for  this  proposal,  and  the  Tax  
ID Number of your organization.

Name: FY17 Nyaruguru Resilience Project in Rwanda -Duhuzeimbaraga, twiyubaka (Africa)
External_Title__c: Nyaruguru Resilience Project in Rwanda -Duhuzeimbaraga, twiyubaka
Sub_Sector__c: Health Promotion;(DISASTER RISK REDUCTION);Community-Based Disaster Preparedness;Contingency Planning;Micro-mitigation Projects;Savings and Loans;Community Mobilization;Microfinance
Summary__c:
The goal of this project is: to reduce the number of deaths, injuries and socioeconomic impacts caused by disasters through strengthening Rwandan Red Cross Society and building safer and more resilient communities, focusing on 12 villages in Rwanda’s Nyaruguru district by mid-2017.

Objective 1: Strengthening RRCS organizational and institutional capacity to design and deliver integrated programming, and in disaster management
  • Outcome 1.1: Enhanced knowledge and skills in integrated program design, implementation and management among RRCS headquarters and Nyaruguru project field staff.
  • Outcome 1.2: RRCS’ Nyaruguru local branches improved planning, mobilization, technical and program management capacity.
 
Objective 2: Supporting targeted Nyaruguru communities to better organize and collectively have the capacity to assess and manage their natural resources, reduce hazards and address vulnerabilities
  • Outcome 2.1: Targeted Nyaruguru communities are organized and mobilize for action to reduce disaster risks and address vulnerabilities.
  • Outcome 2.2: Nyaruguru communities increase knowledge and skills to assess, plan and take action to address risks and vulnerabilities.
 
Objective 3: Increasing Nyaruguru communities’ knowledge, skills and ability to respond to and reduce the spread of preventable diseases within their communities
  • Outcome 3.1: Nyaruguru communities increased knowledge in health and sanitation practices in addressing preventable diseases.
  • Outcome 3.2: Increased RRCS and community capacity to improve water and sanitation services in Nyaruguru communities to reduce incidences of water borne diseases.

Name: FY17 Regional Health Initiative (RHI) in Belarus
Summary__c:
The goal of the project is to strengthen capacities of the BRC Gomel Regional branch to enhance services for PLHIV in the field of healthcare and HIV prevention among youth in Zhlobin.  The project pursues this goal through the following objectives:
By strengthening the resources of the Belarus Red Cross Gomel regional branch
By enhancing access to services related to prevention, care and support by specialists for PLHIV living in Gomel region and the immediate area
By contributing to a reduction in new HIV cases among youth under 31 living in Zhlobin district
and by ensuring the project's sustainability while phasing out of external funding.

Name: Missing Maps Through JP Morgan Chase
Summary__c:
Program Outcomes
JPMC grant support for the Missing Maps Project will:
  • Enhance the ability of the Red Cross to plan, prepare for and respond to disasters in highly disaster-prone areas
  • Identify disaster risks and develop preparedness and response programs in disaster-prone urban areas to support vulnerable households and at-risk communities and families
  • Grow a collaborative, digital network of contributing mappers, which can provide a unique, high-impact opportunity for employee engagement through virtual volunteerism
Employee Engagement
A Red Cross representative will facilitate all 16 marathons, offering insight into conditions on the ground in the cities being mapped, as well as an explanation of the disaster preparedness activities that JPMC funds are supporting. 
 
Project Activities
JPMC funding will support the Red Cross to train staff, volunteers, community leaders, and school teachers to conduct detailed risk mapping in priority cities. GIS technology will be incorporated into assessments to identify the cities’ most vulnerable areas, critical infrastructure, and existing capacities/resources.

Name: West Africa Mapping Hub (Page)
Summary__c:
While parts of Africa are well mapped the majority of the continent simply is blank. Millions of vulnerable people simple do not exist to decision makers because no map exists that shows their village. During the ebola crisis over 3,700 people helped create the best map of West Africa that has ever existed through remote mapping of satellite imagery through the Humanitarian OpenStreetMap Team. This map however is out of date and lacks significant detail to be truly helpful for the next crisis.

This project would take advantage of the Red Cross’s ability to work across borders to create and expand mapping tools and infrastructure to extensively map all of the areas within 15 kilometeres of the Liberia, Sierra Leone, and Guinea borders. The project would create a series of mapping hubs that would be a free and open space for anyone to come and learn about mapping. Community members would be incentivized to map through a tiered approach to be developed.

Tech Tools to be developed:
Improved Field Papers
See Concept Note
100% offline OpenDataKit/OpenMapKit server
Hard Ware
Intel Edison/Ushahidi BRCK – RaspberryPi
Powered by Ona Lite
Improved OpenMapKit
See Concept Note

Program:
Creation of Missing Maps Hubs
Groundtruthing of village/town locations
Using a similar methodology as the MSF Sierra Leone village mapping
http://americanredcross.github.io/evd_village-survey/
Village Name, Alternate Name, Village Chief, Population, water resources, school/community center
Road network
Road quality
Road type (paved/dirt/gravel)
Hospitals and School
All will be mapped after the initial village assessment is complete
Rapid Assessment/Capacity study
Potential intervention for some villages and towns for health/resilience interventions

Name: FY17 Organizational Development (OD) in Africa Program
Summary__c: The American Red Cross respects each national society’s institutional priorities and aims to assist them as they work to strengthen their organizations, whether through programmatic capacity building or through larger-scope OD initiatives. While flexibility is imperative in order to meet the needs of the ever-changing humanitarian environment, the American Red Cross continues to apply learnings from previous and ongoing OD efforts. In FY17, OD support will focus on continuing to leverage impact and sustainability by building on some of the existing OD partnerships that may include national societies in Kenya, Tanzania, Rwanda, South Africa, Zambia and Zimbabwe. Such strategic initiatives, including strengthening youth and volunteer engagement, branch capacity, leadership, and governance, will remain a priority. Pacific Tropical Cyclone Pam-2015
Summary__c:
• Category five Tropical Cyclone Pam is moving through the South Pacific Ocean and has caused significant damage in the Solomon Islands and Vanuatu over the past two days.
  • In the Solomon Islands assessments of damage are on-going while heavy rain is causing flooding and landslides. Communications continue to be a challenge in all provinces.
  • In Vanuatu there are reports of damage to permanent structures and many informal shelters are completely destroyed. There are also reports of damage to health facilities, loss of running water and power outages. Many islands are still cut off from communications so the full scale of the impact is not yet known
