Name: Nepal Social Mobilization for Measles and Rubella Campaign August 15,2015
External_Title__c: Measles Social Mobilization Campaign in Nepal
Summary__c:
Background
Measles is a highly infectious disease which can cause serious illness, lifelong complications and even death. But it can be easily prevented through vaccination. Clinically, almost similar to measles, rubella infection causes milder disease than measles. In pregnant women, the virus infects the placenta and developing fetus, rubella causes variety if physical defects, collectively known as Congenital Rubella Syndrome (CRS).
Coordinated efforts under National Health Policy contribute towards improving health status and achieving the MDGs. Increase in availability of health facilities and mobilization of health volunteers at grass root levels and promotion of public, private partnerships often contribute to addressing health issues at community level. Alongside this, humanitarian and development partners are also often pivotal in playing a key role in augmenting the Government of Nepal capacity to reduce the burden of measles and rubella.
On April 25th, a 7.8 magnitude earthquake struck 48 miles northwest of Kathmandu, Nepal, affecting an estimated 8 million people across 41 districts in Nepal’s West and Central Regions. Of these 41 districts, 14 have been identified as highly affected. Apart from attending to the immediate needs for the medical care, food, shelter, access of water and sanitation for these districts, preventive public health interventions are also equally critical for considerations as humanitarian emergency.
One of the measures currently being organized by Ministry of Health and their partners, including Nepal Red Cross in response to the earthquake is will be to carry out a mass immunization campaign. As a key partner to the MOPH, the Nepal Red Cross will support the MOHP in carrying out the mass vaccination campaign through the implementation of social mobilization activities.
 
Such efforts will be invaluable in contributing towards preventable diseases but also in working towards achievements of the millennium development goals (MDGs) through improvements in maternal and child health.
 
Proposed activities for NRCS Campaign Coverage
NRCS has been involved in previous immunization campaigns in three key areas, which have included: firstly, NRCS local chapters mobilizing its volunteers at vaccination booths, secondly NRCS have carried out social mobilization activities in focused in geographical areas and thirdly NRCS have integrated immunization dissemination and motivation messages for routine vaccination in relevant health projects. Therefore, similar activities will be carried out in the upcoming mass vaccination campaign.
 
Overall Campaign Goal: To immunize children between 6 months to 5 years to reduce morbidity and mortality associated with measles and rubella.
 
Overall Campaign Objective:
  • To immunize all children between 6 months to 5 years of the 14 most earthquake affected districts of Nepal
  • Increase awareness among people about the immunization campaign to ensure their participation
 
Nepal Red Cross Society Goal: To contribute to the Ministry of Health and Population Measles and Rubella campaign in the 14 most earthquake affected districts (Kathmandu, Lalitpur, Bhaktapur, Kavre, Sindhupalchok, Dolakha, Ramechhap, Okhaldhunga, Sindhuli, Nuwakot, Rasuwa, Dhading, Gorkha, Makwanpur) through key social mobilization activities.
 
 
Outcome
  1. Reach target population with messages through mobilization of volunteers and school students
  2. Increased coordination among stakeholders at central and district level

Name: Disaster Risk Reduction (DRR) in Myanmar - Phase II - OFDA
External_Title__c: Enhancing Disaster Safety in Vulnerable Communities and Schools in Myanmar - Pha
Summary__c:
This 18-month project represents a continuation and geographic expansion of the preceeding “Enhancing Disaster Safety in Vulnerable Communities and Schools in Myanmar project, which ended on February 29, 2016. This OFDA-funded Enhancing Disaster Safety in Vulnerable Communities and Schools in Myanmar – Phase II project will continue work in existing program areas while also expanding into additional townships. 

Goal: To reduce the number of deaths, injuries and impact from disasters by increasing safety and resilience in public schools and communities.

Objective: To build the internal capacity of the MRCS (at national and branch levels) to ensure the efficient delivery of disaster response,
preparedness programs and to design and conduct disaster risk reduction education.
 
The overall aim of Phase 2 is to not redesign the original project but rather to strengthen Phase 1 activities and expand the project’s benefits to a wider scope of beneficiaries in an additional disaster prone regions in Myanmar. This will also allow us to incorporate lessons learned from implementation in Phase 1. There will be three substantial changes from the original project in Phase 2:
  1. Expansion of geographic project areas
  2. Incorporation of lessons learned from Phase 1
  3. Incorporation of lessons learned from the Myanmar Red Cross Society’s 2015 flood response operation
 During Phase 2, the project will continue to strengthen the activities in the initial 5 communities in Dedaye Township and 10 public schools in Dedaye and Yangon areas. Additionally, it aims to extend its coverage to:
  • 5 communities and 5 public schools in one township of Bago region (Bago township)
  • 2 public schools in Bago town (Bago township)
  • 6 public schools in two townships of Yangon region
Thus, the total geographic areas of the project proposed to be covered by Phase 1 and Phase 2 will be 10 communities in Ayeyarwady and Bago region and 23 public schools in Ayeyarwady, Yangon and Bago region.

For Reference:
Phase 1 of this project (July 1, 2013 to February 29, 2016) covered:
  • 5 communities in Dedaye Township of Pyapon District in Ayeyarwady Region;
  • 5 public schools in Dedaye Township of Pyapon District in Ayeyarwady Region and 5 public schools in Yangon Downtown areas.

Name: Zimbabwe Food Insecurity-2015
Summary__c: A slow onset of the rainy season was followed by severe flooding that destroyed crops. This situation was followed, and exacerbated, by a long dry spell, resulting in a crop yield below the 5 year average. Zimbabwe Vulnerability Assessment Committee report estimated 16% of Zimbabwe's rural population are food insecure and 1,500,000 people wil lbe in need of food assistance at the peak of the hunger period. Coping mechanisms are severely strained, and social safety-net interventions by the Government and partners are limited.

Youth will receive training in entrepreneurship, mentoring and coaching in accessing business development services. Approximately 900 youth will benefit from the project.  The Entrepreneurial Institute of the Foundation Etre Ayisyen (FEA) will provide management oversight and administration, along with the overall portfolio of program activities including recruiting participants and administering local training. The program model has been proven successful in identifying young people with appropriate drive and interest, offering them comprehensive technical and life skills training as well as practical experience and support in starting their own small businesses.  FEA has received support from many organizations, including UNDP, Oxfam, CECI, Kellogg’s foundation, Intel, and the Ministry of Commerce of Haiti.

Name: Youth Education and Leadership through HELP (CIF)
External_Title__c: Youth Education and Leadership through HELP
Summary__c:
Haiti’s staggering rates of “brain drain” (84%: the highest in the world) and university enrollment (1% among the lowest in the world) are among the primary obstacles to meaningful socioeconomic development across the country. The lack of local skilled labor, effective management, educated leadership, and institutional capacity are recognized as significant impediments to progress at all levels.  By supporting professional training and internships, as well as leadership development and community service experience to students in HELP’s comprehensive univeristy scholarship program, this project contributes to increasing economic opportunities for young Haitians while also building technical capacity in country. The goal of this project is for HELP’s student body of 150 academically talented, socioeconomically disadvantaged young men and women to make progress towards gaining leadership and employment skills that will enable them to access economic opportunities and to contribute to positive change in Haiti. 

The project has two interconnected objectives:

  1. Internships & Career Services: To plan and implement an internship program enabling HELP students to contribute to capacity building for, and access potential employment opportunities at, local development organizations, including ARC and its international affiliates and partners; 
  2. Leadership Program: To build the capacity of HELP’s four-year leadership curriculum providing access to training in leadership, civics, citizenship, and community service to a student body of 150, including the expansion of HELP’s nationwide outreach activities that provide secondary school students across the country with knowledge of educational opportunities available at HELP, with a particular focus on connecting HELP students with ARC-affiliated youth group members in the Carrefour Feuilles neighborhood through community engagement activities.

Name: Pillowcase Project in Hong Kong with Disney
Summary__c:
The Pillowcase Project has been successfully introduced in schools in several cities in the United States to effectively teach preparedness concepts to elementary school students.  As part of the program’s curriculum, Red Cross staff and volunteers teach a 60 minute disaster preparedness lesson in a classroom setting using a pillowcase that can be filled with items to help prepare youth for a disaster.  Items can include extra clothing and shoes, flashlight, water, comfort items, toothbrush, and other items a child may need if they have to leave their home following a disaster.  Some of the hallmarks of success, including the short time period and the fun aspect and the practical application, indicate a natural opportunity for translation to other languages and contexts. The American Red Cross and the Global Disaster Preparedness Center have received a grant from the Disney to support the expansion of the program in six countries as a pilot and proof of concept starting in August 2013 and completed by December 31, 2015.
With its school based disaster risk reduction programming, the Red Cross network is able to provide school-age children with critical disaster management skills that enable them to be more resilient to absorbing the shocks and stresses of disasters. Students will also be better prepared to manage and cope with the harmful negative effects of disasters, thus, ensuring the safety of their student populations.
The intended outcome of the pilot is to determine the method of implementation of the Pillowcase Program in countries outside of the United States. There are three key outputs:
1.Create a framework for national societies to participate in Pillow Case Project
  • Collaborate with Disney and International Services Response and Programs unit to identify three pilot national societies
  • Procure pillow cases
  • Create a ordering system for pillow cases that is easy for the national society to use (and efficient)
2.Design a scalable version of the Pillowcase Project that is easy to adapt and localize for different countries.
  • Build on the work done domestically by the American Red Cross to create a model lesson plan and other tools for adaptation by the national society
3.Conduct learning, evaluations and address lessons learned
  • Conduct classroom learning in 10-15 schools in each of the pilot countries
  • Conduct evaluation on the efficacy of the classroom learning

Name: Social Media and Analysis Tools for Humanitarian Work in the Asia-Pacific Region
Summary__c:
Given the increasing adaptation of communication and information technologies worldwide it is essential for the Red Cross and the humanitarian sector to learn how to best integrate these technologies into their work. The IFRC World Disaster Report 2013 “Focus on technology and the future of humanitarian intervention” gives many examples on how technology, including social media and other information/communication technologies, are used in the humanitarian sector. As with any type of technology, it is also essential to understand the limitations and potential for failure for the application and use of these communication and information technologies.
 
In collaboration with other partners, the GDPC seeks to build out the current knowledge and awareness within the global Red Cross network on how communities are using social media to gather information and communicate with their networks. Beyond the use of such technologies in response to a disaster, it is of interest to better understand how social media could be used to inform vulnerable populations before a disaster strikes and enhance their disaster preparedness. This information will allow the Red Cross to better adapt their own programming and communication strategies to enable vulnerable communities to better prepare for and cope with disasters.

Name: People to People Community Reconciliation in Ukraine
Summary__c:
USAID/DCHA/CMM’s Global Reconciliation Fund RFA FY2015 makes available $16M in 11 countries worldwide, including Ukraine, where American Red Cross has a bilateral partnership with Ukrainian Red Cross and has supported current health programming with the national society for six years.   AMEE Region has stated in recent strategy sessions an intention to remain active in Ukraine as a priority country and to explore resilience programming beginning in FY16.  At the moment, in March 2015, American Red Cross is starting up a cash transfer relief operation to assist internally displaced people who have fled eastern Ukraine due to the armed conflict.

Programming funded under this RFA should facilitate peacebuilding and reconciliation and must take a USAID (CMM) developed approach of “People to People” (P2P). Funds are available for programs planned over 1-4 years.  For Ukraine, international organizations are eligible to apply for grants from $1M-1.2M; a lower range of funds is available to purely local organizations.  Among the suggested approaches in the Ukraine country-specific program information is Community Conflict Management, where activities can propose P2P approaches to build better relations and peace between IDPs and host communities, or between returnees and those who remained in zones of conflict – which will constitute two very key and essential aspects of reconciliation in Ukraine, given the current context.

In Ukraine, the current crisis has led to the internal displacement of over a million people from the conflict area in 2 regions in the east of the country.  These internally displaced people (IDPs) have sought shelter in communities that are struggling to accommodate them with over-stretched resources and dwindling budgets. In areas formerly under separatist control, now re-taken by the Government, divisions have emerged between returnees and those who remained during the period of separatist control. As the current conflict winds down, repairing and bridging the social cleavages that have emerged or have been exacerbated by the crisis will be a key element of community resilience.

American Red Cross will submit a proposal on behalf of a consortium consisting of ARC, Ukrainian Red Cross, and Danish Red Cross.  While the detailed needs assessment and program design will begin the week of March 23, preliminary discussions have defined an arrangement where Ukrainian RC serve as the primary implementers of a P2P approach focused on the relations between IDPs and host communities.  Activities are expected to draw on the strong volunteer base of the national society and strong work with youth.  Danish RC is being engaged as a key technical partner, delivering technical assistance related to community-based psychosocial services and youth resilience programming, as well as on approaches to building social cohesion.  American Red Cross is taking the lead role in coordination and management, delivering technical assistance on monitoring and evaluation, project management and compliance, and managing donor reporting for the consortium.

Name: FY15 OD in Honduras for 100 Day Plan
Summary__c:
To provide support to the National Society’s 100 Day Plan which was developed as part of the STAR workshop conducted May 4-6, 2015 in Tegucigalpa, Honduras.
 
The focus of the plan is to design a National Regionalization (Decentralization) Strategy which will allow the Honduras Red Cross to boost the development of its branches. In order to achieve this, structures, functions, roles and responsibilities need to be defined for the regional technical office and board of the four regions of the National Society. This is a process that aims to strengthen and develop local capacities by empowering local branches to achieve self-sustainability, improve positioning and institutional credibility, and adapt NS structure to facilitate better and more immediate response in case of emergencies.
 
To support this process, $10,000 will be granted to the Honduran Red Cross to implement workshops and a consultation process with its regional offices and branches.

Name: Citoyenneté à Martissant (Citizenship in Martissant) through FOKAL (Youth)
External_Title__c: Developing Citizenship in Martissant through FOKAL
Summary__c:
Demographically, Martissant is comprised of a majority of youth under 25. The daily violence in the neighborhood and the weak involvement of the state has important effects on the absence of security and well-being of the community, struck by unemployment, poverty and crime. In this context, the youth is offered little opportunity to engage in public debate and civic integration. Within the framework of this project, FOKAL wants to address the question of civic education, in order to convey a better knowledge and understanding of civic, health and educational issues. FOKAL also wants to give the youth the tools they need to build their own conscious, organic and reflective vision of the obstacles they face. FOKAL’s project is focused on an area of Martissant, where it has led integrated grassroots projects since 2007. The project responds to the first and second objectives of the ARC Youth Engagement Program.
The overall GOAL is to contribute to the emergence of a feeling of civic engagement among the youth of Martissant.

The specific Objectives of the project are:
  • To train young people of Martissant on human rights and civics;
  • To empower young people of Martissant with professional tools,
  • To empower local NGO’s to enhance life skills for better psychological and physical health.

Name: Ecuador Earthquake-2016
Summary__c: On April 16, a powerful 7.8 magnitude earthquake struck the northwest coast of Ecuador at 6:58pm local time. The epicenter was 27 kilometers south-southeast of the small coastal town of Muisne, at a depth of 20 kilometers.  The earthquake resulted in more than 660 deaths and injured more than 4,000 people, leading the Government of Ecuador to declare a state of emergency in 6 provinces: Esmeraldas, Manabí, Santa Elena, Guayas, Santo Domingo and Los Ríos.

Name: Haiti & Dominican Republic Cholera-2014
Summary__c: Since October 2010, when the first cholera cases were reported in Haiti in more than 100 years, the cholera caseload in Haiti and the Dominican Republic has increased dramatically.  Cholera has killed more than 8,500 people in Haiti and 454 people in the Dominican Republic since 2010, and more than 650,000 Haitians and 30,000 Dominicans have contracted the disease during this period. In 2012, the governments of Haiti and the Dominican Republic developed ten-year national action plans outlining investments and interventions necessary to eliminate the transmission of cholera by 2022.  Agencies working in support of the respective national plans, including the Red Cross, formed a coalition to coordinate cholera response efforts.  In recent years, Red Cross efforts have contributed to a reduction in the number of cholera cases in Haiti and the Dominican Republic.  However, eradication of the disease requires further reducing the number of cholera cases, increasing awareness of beneficial hygiene and sanitation practices, increasing national capacity to detect and control cholera outbreaks, reducing the risk of contamination, and supporting treatment of cholera patients.

Name: Restoring Family Links Services through HRC
External_Title__c: Restoring Family Links Services through the Haitian Red Cross
Summary__c: The Haitian Red Cross, in collaboration with the Dominican Red Cross, seeks to re-establish a permanent restoring family links program that will benefit both national societies (through capacity building and closer cooperation), as well as the individuals they endeavor to assist. With the support of the American Red Cross, HRC's Capacity to provide RFL Services will be strengthened at the national level. The project aims to reach a larger number of persons with a special emphasis on reinforcing RFL services at the Haitian / Dominican Republic border points. The priority target group being those families facing problems with their legal immigration status and risk of an expulsion from the Dominican Republic.

Name: FY17 Organizational Development (OD) in Ukraine
External_Title__c: Organizational Development - Ukraine
Summary__c:
To improve financial accounting National Society recognizes the need to improve the existing centralized financial accounting system through additional software changes. To reach this objective it planned to define the system of financial monitoring (financial statements, methods of transmission, accounting documents, their storage and analysis), financial reporting forms will be prepared and deadlines for financial reporting will be defined. Skilled person will:
- adopt 1 C8 program for National Committee and all regional URCS branches;
- prepare and install necessary program software;

Software adaptation will be conducted in order to carry out monitoring according to specifics of URCS financial structure by analyzing the problems in software of accounting and reporting in 1C8, development of terms of references for adapting 1C8 and preparation of new software product. As a result, it planned to get executive summary on financial monitoring of URCS activities.
At the same time, the improvement of knowledge and skills of URCS financial service staff will be carried out.

During the project implementation personnel of URCS NC and regional branches financial departments will be trained to work with adapted program by: creating user guidelines how to work with adapted software and carrying out training for personnel. The result of these efforts will be:
1. Trained personnel (financial staff of URCS NC and regional branches) for work with adopted software
2. Trained personnel for preparation of reports on humanitarian cargos 
3. Trained personnel on making of summarized URCS financial report, on implementation and serving of programs of centralized financial accounting and carrying out of audit in URCS regional branches.

During the project implementation it is planned to purchase technical equipment for software adaptation. It is necessary for smooth functioning of software and work of financial monitoring system. It is planned to select supplier and purchase technical equipment through tender procedures of supplier selection.
This project aims to regulate the work of URCS 26 organizations in the field of accounting and management reporting, to optimize the expenses related with maintenance of software system, to provide a possibility of control and receiving consolidated financial reporting for central office.
Project implementation supposes purchasing of such technical and software components:
1.    Host server – meant to be used for storage of database and serving users who work with database. Currently National Society has entry-level server sufficient for work of 4-6 users 
2.    Operating system  Microsoft Windows Server 2008 R2.
3.    Software complex «1С:Предприятие 8.2» is available.

Name: FY13-15 Resilience in the Americas (IPA/RITA) in Costa Rica
FY16 Public Series - Our IHL Programs
Support to Livelihood Resilience (North and Northeast) through CECI
External_Title__c: Support to Livelihood Resilience through CECI
Summary__c:
Value chain in tubers and ginger represents one of the main economic in the rural areas of Haiti. It represents an integral part of the economic reconstruction and revenue stream of rural households in all of the six communal sections targeted by this program. Despite differences in the agro-ecological characteristics between the North (wet mountain areas) and Northeast (lowland areas), they present relatively similar production potential and constraints. These constraints are characterized by difficulty to access seeds, high cost of agricultural input and labor, inappropriate cultivation practices, and the inherent weakness in packaging, conservation techniques and marketing. In view of the above, the project provide technical assistance, resources, strategy and methodologies to support select farmers in the Northern and Northeastern Departments to enhance their livelihood resilience and improve their opportunities for income-generation in two value chains i.e. ginger and tubers. The project objectives are: 
  • To increase the capacity of Communal Agricultural Office (BAC), Haitian Red Cross (HRC) and Rural Producer Organizations to support extension training of farmers in appropriate value chains in target communal sections
  • Targeted communities have increased their resilience through improved knowledge, practices and assets for disaster resistant agriculture techniques (ginger, root crops). 
  • Targeted communities and households - in particular young women - enhance their incomes through transformation and commercialization of yam, cassava, sweet potato and/or ginger.

Name: FY13-15 Resilience in the Americas (IPA/RITA) in El Salvador
Nepal Earthquake Recovery Program - Utthan
External_Title__c: Utthan – Nepal Earthquake Recovery Program
Summary__c:
Executive Summary

 
On April 25, 2015, a magnitude 7.8 earthquake struck Nepal, affecting an estimated 8 million people (more than a quarter of Nepal’s population) across 31 districts in Nepal’s West and Central Regions. This powerful earthquake was followed by another major earthquake of magnitude 7.3 on May 12 and thousands of aftershocks including more than 380 of magnitude 4.0 or greater. The earthquakes and subsequent aftershocks caused widespread destruction and loss of life. More than 8,800 people died, and another 100,000 were injured. Nearly 600,000 houses were destroyed and 280,000 damaged by the quakes, forcing nearly 3 million people out of their homes and into makeshift shelters. More than 5,000 schools and 1,200 health facilities were heavily damaged or destroyed, hindering provision of education services to more than a million children and primary health care services to whole communities in earthquake-affected areas. The Government of Nepal (GoN) Post Disaster Needs Assessment (PDNA), undertaken in May 2015, estimated that the earthquake caused NPR 706 billion (the equivalent of $7 billion) in damages overall, including homes, government buildings, heritage sites, schools and health posts, rural roads, bridges, water supply systems, agricultural land, trekking routes, and hydropower plants. In the 14 most-affected districts, 46% of water supply systems were damaged and approximately 220,000 toilets partially or totally destroyed. Disruptions to water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) systems create increased risk of communicable diseases such as diarrhoea, respiratory infections, and mosquito-borne illnesses.
 
Nepal Red Cross Society (NRCS), in partnership with American Red Cross (ARC), Spanish Red Cross (SpRC) and Canadian Red Cross (CRC), propose to undertake a three year post-earthquake integrated recovery program in 19 Village Development Committees (VDCs) and one municipality of three of the 14 most affected districts of Nepal: Nuwakot, Rasuwa and Makwanpur. The Utthan program will focus on long-term recovery and community resilience building.
 
The overall goal of the program is to contribute to the sustainable recovery of vulnerable earthquake-affected households and develop safer, more resilient communities. Program objectives are:
 
Objective 1: Vulnerable earthquake-affected households and communities increase the ability to self-organize and take actions to recover quicker and build back safer by adopting improved resilience practices to disasters
 
Objective 2: Vulnerable earthquake-affected households and communities increase access to safe and sustainable infrastructure and basic services to better meet household needs.
 
Objective 3: NRCS increases organizational and technical capacity to manage and implement community-based recovery, resilience and readiness to respond programming.
 
Building on the principles and strategies laid out in the NRCS draft recovery framework, The Utthan program will adopt a community-driven integrated approach to self-recovery and resilience building. An integrated program approach recognizes that single sector interventions cannot be done in isolation from other interventions and that there is a strong need for a holistic approach. Appropriate and sustainable shelter solutions are more than four walls and a roof: it’s about increasing access to water and sanitation, adopting healthy behaviours and improving employment or livelihood opportunities. The Red Cross will focus on an integrated approach which looks at the main services needed for a community to thrive and which involves working side by side with local residents, engaging them as active participants and decision makers in their recovery process. Interventions must not only be comprehensive and managed in a holistic manner; they must be based on the expressed desires, wishes and active participation of the affected population. The Red Cross role will be to facilitate the process whereby implementation is carried out by those affected and not on behalf of those affected. Community members must have the necessary knowledge, skills and motivation to self-organize, identify risk, establish priorities to take individual and collective actions, and advocate for their needs. In addition to capacity building, the program will also provide essential financial or in-kind materials support to vulnerable earthquake-affected households and communities to recover quicker and to better meet immediate household needs. The program will take a holistic comprehensive approach and where appropriate will integrate and mainstream cross-cutting themes, including: gender and diversity, to ensure inclusion of the most vulnerable groups (such as female and child headed households, persons with disabilities, Dalit and other marginalized caste/ethnic groups); environmental sustainability; and disaster risk reduction (DRR).
 
Resources will be allocated to further enhance and build the organizational and technical capacity of the NRCS at both the national headquarters and the district chapter level. NRCS district chapter capacity building will be based on detailed district chapter capacity assessments undertaken at the start of the program. Human resource development will include: ensuring that chapters have sufficient and appropriate trained and skilled staff; targeted trainings for NRCS staff and volunteers to develop essential skills for facilitating community-based recovery, resilience and readiness to respond (such as post-disaster rapid and detailed assessments, participatory planning, community mobilization, Behaviour Change Communication (BCC), technical trainings, first aid, etc.); and recruiting and training volunteer district disaster response teams. Organizational systems strengthening will include contributing to the development/refinement of NRCS MIS systems at both headquarter and district chapter levels; building district operational capacity in areas such as warehouse management and early warning systems. Hardware support will include supporting district chapters to rehabilitate/construct safe, sustainable and appropriate buildings, including warehouses, and provision of other necessary assets, including fleet, IT and communications support. NRCS headquarters capacity building will focus on strengthening the ERO and relevant NRCS technical departments.
 
The recovery program timeline will begin from October 1, 2015 through September 30, 2018. The first 90 days will focus on start-up operations and project inception, including: hiring and training of staff, conducting rapid participatory integrated assessments with the development of community action plans, building community trust and cohesion through social mobilization. Community mobilization and the development of community specific actions plans at the onset will ensure designed interventions are community-driven and provide an integrated package of services that meet the unique needs and cultural aspects in each respective community. Based on the results of the integrated assessments and community action plan the program will develop a detailed implementation plan focused on the sectoral activities and interventions the Red Cross will deliver. While initial project design is an iterative process through the inception phase, initial program plans intend to target 3,000 vulnerable earthquake-affected households with an integrated package of services and support with the Red Cross primarily focused on providing sectoral support in the areas of shelter, WASH and livelihoods and working with a wider set of partners to ensure other prioritized areas and needs a fully met. Additionally, the program will provide support at the wider community level in 19 VDCs providing coverage to an estimated 20,636 households through interventions that include improving community water schemes, providing WASH services in selected schools and health posts in each VDC, community health promotion and selected community-level livelihoods activities. The total proposed program budget is $17.6 million implemented over a three year period.

Name: RFL-Phone Project-San Diego
Summary__c: This project is to support a phone project in the San Diego Region. It will provide phone calls for vulnerable migrants in need of communicating with family and/or loved ones in their country of origin and in the US.

Name: Disaster Project - Paraguay Fire-2004
Summary__c: More than 300 people were killed in a supermarket fire on the outskirts of the Paraguayan capital, Asunción. The supermarket doors were locked, trapping victims inside the building.

Name: FY15 OD in Kenya for M&E Strengthening Project
Summary__c: The Kenya Red Cross Society is requesting $ 10,657 from the American Red Cross to support the Monitoring & Evaluation 2015-2016 unit plan. The partial contribution to the overall budget will enable the unit conduct a Monitoring & Evaluation refresher training for program staff and purchase of a programming software (SPSS/PASW) for data analysis.  This initiative is envisioned to increase our national society’s foundations of sustainability, service delivery effectiveness and ultimately greater success in fulfilling our mandate.

Name: Colombia Population Movement-2015
Summary__c: Colombia refugees in Venezuala are being sent back to Colombia. DREF issued today. Ops meeting to be scheduled.

Name: Thailand Floods-2011
Summary__c: More than 3.4 million people are still affected by Thailand’s worst flooding in more than five decades. Many communities across the country have been isolated for weeks, relying on local authorities and organizations like the Thai Red Cross for basic assistance. Thai authorities are working to channel water from flooded Bangkok into the Gulf of Thailand. But the sheer volume of water and seasonal high tides has resulted in extensive flooding and the forced evacuation of a growing number of districts in the densely populated city of 12 million. Thousands of people have been forced to leave their homes and move into government shelters while one million people have become unemployed as floods engulfed factories and agricultural land.

Name: New Zealand Earthquake-2011
Summary__c:
A 6.3 magnitude earthquake struck near Christchurch, New Zealand on February 22. There was widespread damage, including collapsed buildings in the city center and damage to roads and bridges.  Authorities have reported 172 confirmed deaths, but predict that this figure may rise as remains are recovered from the rubble and identified. They have confirmed the identity of 140 victims so far. More than 100,000 homes were damaged, representing 60% of Christchurch residences.  Approximately 2,000 people were displaced to evacuation centers.  Government authorities have extended the state of national emergency until April 18.  Although outages remain within the Christchurch city center, 99% of households outside of that area have power.  
The New Zealand government estimates that the direct cost of the earthquake to the government is US$4.3 billion and warns that the catastrophe will negatively impact the country's struggling economy.

Name: Central America Tropical Storm Agatha-2010
Summary__c: On May 29, the first Pacific Tropical Storm of 2010, Agatha, quickly devolved into Tropical Depression Agatha in the afternoon of May 29. The weather system brought unusually heavy rainfall to Central America. El Salvador, Guatemala and Honduras have been particularly impacted, with Guatemala experiencing the highest amount of rainfall since 1949, with precipitation ranging from 8 to 14 inches between May 25 and 28. More than 150,000 people have already been evacuated from their homes in the region. The situation is still developing as rain continues to fall, leading to more flooding and landslide risk.

Name: Caribbean Hurricane Tomas-2010
Summary__c: From October 30 to 31, Hurricane Tomas struck the Caribbean Islands of Barbados, Saint Lucia, and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, causing landslides and damage to homes and infrastructure. Now downgraded in scale to a Tropical Storm, it is on course to strike Haiti within the next 48 hours, bringing heavy rains which are expected to severely affect the country.

Name: Bangladesh Floods-2011
Summary__c: Two months of continuous torrential rains coupled with a monsoonal depression in the Bay of Bengal has caused flooding that has affected more than 1.5 million people in 18 districts in Bangladesh.

Name: Disaster Project - Southern Africa Floods - Cyclone Jokwe-2008
Colombia Floods-2011
Summary__c: Colombia has been experiencing a heavier than normal rainy season since September. Many communities are affected and are relying on government authorities and the Colombian Red Cross for basic assistance. The UN reports that 410,000 people are affected across more than 80 percent of the country. More than 100 people have died and 62,300 homes have been damaged. The most critical needs identified by the Red Cross are for food, temporary shelters, tarps, hygiene items as well as water and sanitation services. In the departments of Cesar, Chocó and Córdoba y Norte de Santander, the combination of heavy rain and ongoing armed conflict have created even greater humanitarian needs.

Name: Mexico Floods-2011
Summary__c: Heavy rains associated with various recent tropical depressions and storms have caused flooding in more than 850 communities in the southeast Mexican states of Tabasco and Chiapas.

Name: Vietnam Floods-2011
Summary__c: According to the Vietnam government’s flood control agency, a total of 140,000 households (approximately 590,000 people) have been affected by the floods.  At least 73 people are dead, more than 91,400 houses are damaged and 24,000 acres of rice paddies destroyed. Government authorities have opened shelters and health stations to support those in need, but food supplies are low and people continue to face difficulties in everyday living. Assessments performed by the Vietnam Red Cross and other agencies indicate that the greatest needs are for food, tarps, blankets, mosquito nets, safe water, hygiene and health promotion activities. According to the Mekong River Commission, floodwaters are forecasted to remain high at least until mid-November.

Name: Bangladesh Floods-2012
Summary__c: While still responding to the heavy rains from earlier this year that caused floods and landslides in ten districts, Bangladesh was struck by a fast moving tropical storm that caused damage to over 27,000 homes in three districts on the coast. Due to the quick onset of the storm, as meteorological agencies weren’t able to give much advanced warning, the fishing community was particularly affected by being caught out on the water. Organizations on the ground in Bangladesh are coordinating response activities with the government and through the Humanitarian Coordination Task Team (HCTT).

Name: West & Central Africa Floods-2009
Summary__c: A heavier than normal rainy season in West and Central Africa has caused serious flooding in 16 countries. Beginning in early September the flooding worsened, affecting more than 600,000 people in Benin, Central African Republic, Chad, Cote d'Ivoire, Gambia, Ghana, Guinea, Guinea Bissau, Liberia, Mali, Mauritania, Niger, Nigeria, Senegal, Sierra Leone and Togo. The rains have caused 159 deaths and considerable damage to homes and infrastructure, leaving thousands homeless. The number of people affected is expected to climb as rains continue.

Name: Haiti Floods-2009
Summary__c: On October 20, heavy rains triggered flooding in Haiti’s Carrefour department, located west of the capital of Port-au-Prince. The rains caused both flash flooding as well as left standing water, damaging the homes and belongings of 500 families.

Name: DPR Korea (North Korea) Floods-2011
Summary__c: Floods in the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea (DPRK) caused by months of heavy rainfall and a recent typhoon have destroyed homes, infrastructure and crops, leaving more than 25,000 people homeless.More than 45,000 people are affected in the DPRK. While flood damage is reported throughout the country, south and north Hwanghae provinces have been the worst hit by repeated flooding, leaving an already vulnerable population in a critical condition.

Name: Panama Floods-2012
Summary__c: On Sunday, November 25, 2012 heavy rains over the western part of Panama triggered floods and landslides causing at least five deaths and affecting over 5,000 people. Landslides have also caused a disruption of economic activities and hampered access to some communities. Figures of people who have died and been affected are likely to increase as more isolated communities have not yet been reached. Preliminary reports indicate that over 1,000 houses were damaged. The situation is likely to worsen as overflow of rivers and continued threat of landslides restrict access to flooded communities, particularly in the mountainous areas.

Name: Philippines Typhoon Megi-2010
Summary__c: Typhoon Megi battered the Philippines on October 18, when it made landfall in the north of the country as a Category 5 typhoon with 140 mph winds and heavy rains.  While evacuation efforts saved many lives, the typhoon caused significant damage to homes, livelihoods and infrastructure.

Name: Afghanistan Floods-2012
Summary__c: Melting snow and heavy rain have caused flash floods in the Sar-e-Pol and Jawzjan provinces of Afghanistan, damaging property and livelihoods.  Over five thousand homes have been damaged or destroyed, leaving many families unable to find alternative shelter. Water supply systems are inundated and local markets are difficult to access, making shelter, food, water and healthcare the top priorities for the response efforts.

Name: Namibia Floods-2011
Summary__c: Months of rain have caused large-scale flooding in northern Namibia, displacing thousands of people and destroying homes, crops, roads and other infrastructure. The Namibian government and the Namibia Red Cross Society are responding to the floods. The government has declared a state of national emergency and has reported that more than 228,500 people are affected and 60,000 are displaced, with 65 deaths due to the flooding. The UN reports there are approximately 78 relocation centers housing an estimated 15,000 people in the six affected regions. The Namibia Red Cross Society reports that houses, roads, bridges, businesses, crops and other infrastructure have been destroyed in the affected regions of Caprivi, Ohangwena, Oshana, Oshikoto, Kavango and Omusati. Some communities are inaccessible and cut off from assistance.

Name: Belize Hurricane Richard-2010
Summary__c: On October 24, Hurricane Richard hit Belize with sustained winds of 90 mph, tracking directly across the cities of Belmopan and Belize City. It damaged over 800 homes and was particularly destructive to local agriculture.

Name: Disaster Project - Horn of Africa Food Insecurity Crisis-2008
Disaster Project - El Salvador Hurricane Stan & Volcano Eruption-2005
Disaster Project - Kenya Election Civil Unrest-2008
Palestine Gaza Crisis-2012
Summary__c: Starting on November 14, 2012, eight days of fighting across the border between Israel and Gaza resulted in 160 deaths and nearly 1,400 injuries in Gaza. Initial assessments in Gaza indicated that 137 houses were completely destroyed and 294 had been damaged. Airstrikes destroyed infrastructure and displaced approximately 12,000 people. Initial assessments also indicated an immediate need for relief supplies, medical supplies and ambulances.

Name: Kenya Floods-2013
Summary__c: Seasonal rains starting in March 2013 have caused severe flooding and landslides in Kenya, destroying houses, crops and vital infrastructure, forcing affected populations to leave their homes in search of safer areas. Flooding has displaced 10,000 households, caused 39 deaths and destroyed 640 households completely. Rains are forecasted to continue into the month of June and could worsen flooding and cause further displacement and destruction.  Immediate needs include search and rescue services, safe shelter, access to water and improved sanitation, health and hygiene education, and grants to enable affected populations to purchase the supplies they need in areas where markets are functioning.

Name: Hurricane Sandy-2012
Summary__c: Hurricane Sandy began as a tropical storm in the western Caribbean in October 2012 and intensified into a hurricane before making landfall over south-eastern Jamaica. It then moved over Cuba, affecting Haiti and the Dominican Republic as well, before making landfall in the U.S.

Name: Kenya Drought-2009
Summary__c: In Kenya, the cumulative effects of three consecutive failed rainy seasons and the 2008 post election violence have crippled food production, creating a 40% shortfall in the 2009 national grain harvest.  In northern and eastern Kenya, an estimated 3.8 million pastoralists and marginal farmers require urgent food assistance. Recently, rain has brought some relief to drought-stricken areas but it will be months before the harvest comes.

Name: Mexico Floods-2010
Summary__c: The 2010 hurricane season has significantly impacted Mexico. Record high seasonal rains combined with two major storms in the past month have generated extensive flooding in Mexico’s southern states, affecting an estimated 500,000 people. Hurricane Karl hit on September 17, followed by Tropical Storm Matthew on September 26.

Name: Disaster Project - West Africa Population Movement-2010
Summary__c: Political turmoil following December’s presidential elections in Cote d’Ivoire has caused armed clashes and prompted significant internal and cross border population movements into neighboring countries. Liberia has been particularly impacted with thousands of Ivorians crossing its border, placing burdens on communities. Up to one million people have been internally displaced in Cote d’Ivoire, and more than 100,000 have crossed into Liberia. Many of the displaced are staying with host families.

Name: Disaster Project - Southern Africa Food Security Crisis-2006
Haiti Earthquake-2010
Summary__c: On January 12, a magnitude 7 earthquake struck the Haitian coast 10 miles from the capital of Port-au-Prince, causing massive damage and generating a tsunami alert in Haiti and neighboring countries.

Name: Pakistan Floods-2011
Summary__c: Since the beginning of August, monsoon rains have caused widespread flooding in southern Pakistan and isolated floods and landslides across the north of the country, affecting 5 million people.

Name: Japan Earthquake & Tsunami-2011
Summary__c: On March 11, a record 9.0 magnitude earthquake struck Sendai, Japan, generating a powerful 32-foot tsunami which caused widespread destruction to northern Japanese coastal areas and communities. Damage to a nuclear power plant caused the ongoing threat of radiation exposure.

Name: Horn of Africa Drought-2011
Summary__c: A drought that began in 2009 has resulted in massive crop failure, water scarcity, low food supplies, livestock deaths and the migration of residents from Ethiopia, Kenya, Djibouti, Tanzania and Somalia. A short rainy period at the end of 2011 improved the situation across much of the region, though drought conditions persist in some parts of Ethiopia and Kenya. Red Cross societies are largely ending food distributions and focusing their activities on reducing disaster risk, restoring livelihoods and promoting safe hygiene.

Name: Vietnam Floods-2010
Summary__c: Since October 1, torrential rains have caused rivers and dams to overflow, inundating five provinces in Central Vietnam.  To date, more than 100 people are reported dead and another 660,000 affected in the worst flooding in the country in 20 years.

Name: Argentina Floods-2013
Summary__c: On April 2, 2013 a severe storm caused heavy flooding in La Plata, the capital of Buenos Aires province in Argentina, bringing eleven inches of rain overnight. This was the highest level of rainfall the area experienced in a 24 hour period since 1980. Flood waters rose to over six feet in some areas causing destruction of homes and disruption to power and clean water supply. The floods affected over 350,000 people, caused 52 deaths and resulted in 3,000 people evacuating to shelters.

Name: Disaster Project - Haiti Hurricane Season-2008
Summary__c: Perparations for the 2008 hurrican season in the Caribbean.

Name: Malawi Food Insecurity-2012
Summary__c: As a result of low food production in some districts and an increasing economic crisis, Malawi is facing a critical food shortage, affecting an estimated 1.9 million people. The food shortage is concentrated in central and southern Malawi, affecting approximately 11% of the total population and over 50% of the population in two southern districts, Nsanje and Chikhwawa. Heavy rains and flooding in the spring, followed by prolonged dry spells resulted in poor harvests this fall. The next harvest season is not expected until March 2013.  The current situation is exacerbated by fuel shortages, rising food prices, and rapid inflation which occurred earlier this year.

Name: FY16 Zuia Mafuriko: Dar es Salaam Flooding Mitigation (Prepared)
External_Title__c: Zuia Mafuriko Dar es Salaam Initiative
Sub_Sector__c: (ORGANIZATIONAL DEVELOPMENT);(BENEFICIARY ENGMT & ACCOUNTABILITY);(GIS & INFORMATION MANAGEMENT);(RESEARCH);(RESPONSE READINESS)
Summary__c:
Dar Es Salaam, in eastern Tanzania, is a bustling urban center home to approximately 4.4 million residents, and is the economic center of Tanzania.[1] Dar es Salaam is also a city prone to regular flooding and has experienced four major floods in the past ten years. The main causes of flooding in Dar es Salaam are inadequate and blocked drainage systems. Flood effects are then amplified by unplanned and crowded settlements, weak municipal capacity to issue flood warnings and evacuate communities in high-risk areas, and poor sanitation infrastructure. Most recently, in April 2014 three days of heavy rain led to extensive flooding throughout the city, leaving 19 people dead, and 20,000 people displaced from their homes. Major service delivery systems such as roads, water and sewage systems were also impacted.[2]
 
In protracted debates over the best strategy for government agencies and the Red Cross to intervene based on a forecast, a lack of funding to carry out significant early action measures and a lack of standardized operating procedures, identifying the most appropriate actions to take, are often cited as clear and insurmountable challenges. This contributes to a decreased sense of responsibility and accountability to act. This project aims to contribute to progress toward overcoming these challenges by focusing on the most flood prone areas of Dar es Salaam. A consortium of institutions comprised of the World Bank, Ardhi Univeristy, the Tanzania Red Cross Society, the American Red Cross, the Danish Red Cross and the Red Cross Red Crescent Climate Centre will implement this project in coordination with local authorities.
 
[1] National Bereau of Statistics (2013) Tanzania in Figures 2012 Dar es Salaam, Tanzania
[2] Reliefweb (2014 May 27) Retreived 15 August 2014 from http://reliefweb.int/disaster/fl-2014-000053-tza

Name: Argentina Floods-2015
Summary__c: Flooding in Argentina. Corporation interested in donating to responding ($25k). Only possibility is through grant letter to national society. Stacy and Paul to follow up.

Name: Sierra Leone Cholera Outbreak-2012
Summary__c: Since the first cases were reported in February, the latest cholera outbreak in Sierra Leone has caused an estimated 217 deaths and affected almost 12,000 people. The rate of new cases has accelerated rapidly since the beginning of August and spread to 10 of the country’s 13 districts. Hospitals and health centres in some districts lack clean water and stable power. The actual number of cholera cases may be higher than what has been reported because cases are often unreported or not treated by proper medical personnel.  There are a number of organizations currently responding in Sierra Leone but the majority are concentrated in the capital of Freetown.

Name: Sahel Food Crisis-2012
Summary__c: More than 11 million people in the Sahel region of West Africa, which includes Burkina Faso, Chad, Mali, Mauritania, Niger and some parts of Senegal, face severe food shortages due to crop failure caused by erratic rainfall and drought. This will worsen the chronic risk of food insecurity and malnutrition many families in the region already face. The Sahel region will run out of food stocks earlier than usual and already high food prices are expected to increase, which will limit families’ ability to purchase additional food at markets. Immediate priority needs are for food assistance, nutritional supplements and agriculture support. In several regions in Chad, Mauritania, Niger and Senegal, child malnutrition rates are already above the emergency threshold of 15 percent. Without immediate action, the situation is predicted to worsen. The population’s ability to obtain food has also been impacted by an increase in crime and insecurity due to armed groups in Chad, Mali, Mauritania and Niger.

Name: Disaster Project - Uganda, Rwanda, Burundi Population Movement-2008
Disaster Project - South Africa Civil Disturbance-2008
Disaster Project - Southern Africa Floods - Cyclone Jokwe-2008
Syria Crisis and Population Movement-2012
Summary__c: The conflict in Syria has been ongoing since March 2011; violence began after demonstrations demanding the departure of President Bashar al Assad. Conflict across the country has caused large-scale displacement and disintegration of infrastructure, leaving millions in need of food, health, shelter, and WASH assistance amid a dynamic conflict in which aid provision is highly problematic.

Name: North Africa & Middle East Civil Unrest-2011
Summary__c: A year after violence began between the Syrian government and protestors demanding political reform, the humanitarian situation in Syria has worsened. Thousands of people are trapped in their homes, are caught in open conflict or are fleeing to escape the fighting. Food and water supplies are running low in some areas and medical needs are urgent. The Syrian Arab Red Crescent has been assisting those in need since the violence began. It is the only humanitarian organization on the ground in many parts of the country and is working hard to ensure that its neutrality and impartiality is understood by all sides. The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) has called for a daily two-hour cease-fire so that the Syrian Arab Red Crescent can deliver medical assistance and aid to the worst-affected areas.  The ICRC and Red Crescent have been granted very little access by the Syrian government to enter the severely-hit Baba Amr neighborhood of Homs. The UN reports that more than 9,000 people have been killed during the conflict, including more than 600 children. The UN and other organizations have called for immediate humanitarian action.

Name: Paraguay Drought-2012
Summary__c: A La Niña weather phenomenon has created irregular rain patterns throughout South America, causing a serious drought in Paraguay. The drought has hit southern Paraguay in one of the most important agricultural regions of the country. The government declared a food security emergency in January. It reports that 8 of the country’s 17 departments are under a serious drought, with agriculture production reduced by 30 to 50 percent. Small farmers and food producers are particularly hard hit; more than 263,800 households are experiencing crop loss and are in need of food.  The most immediate needs for the short term are for safe water, food items and seeds for immediate planting. The drought has limited the movement of food and commercial shipping along rivers due to low water levels and led to a lack of safe water for household use.

Name: Nigeria Floods-2012
Summary__c: Between July and October 2012, the worst flooding Nigeria has experienced in 40 years has affected 7 million people, killed 363, and displaced 2.1 million. Flooding has affected 33 of Nigeria’s 36 states, with the greatest impact currently in the southern parts of the country.  Flooding has destroyed crops and damaged roads and bridges making transportation of goods to communities extremely difficult. In some flooded areas, food prices have increased by 30 to 70 percent resulting in food insecurity. Displaced people are living with host families or in camps and schools, many of which do not have adequate sanitation facilities and drinking water. This situation is also preventing schools from functioning normally.

Name: Costa Rica Floods-2010
Summary__c: Since November, torrential rains have hit Costa Rica, triggering landslides, floods and the movement of thousands of people to shelters along the Pacific coast and in the Central Valley. Floods have also destroyed infrastructure including roadways, bridges, water systems and housing.

Name: DR Congo Population Movement-2013
Summary__c: Since December 2012, refugees escaping violence in the Central African Republic (CAR) have been migrating into Equateur, a province in the north of the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC). According to the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs, more than 30,000 refugees from CAR are now residing in DRC. The population remains in flux and the numbers could increase due to the overthrow of the CAR government by rebels in March 2013.  Immediate needs include temporary shelter, food, water and reconnecting separated family members. Assessments have also highlighted health, nutrition and protection for the displaced population as additional needs.

Name: Philippines Typhoons-2011
Summary__c: Two typhoons have hit the Philippines within a five-day span. Typhoon Nesat struck September 27 with strong gusts and heavy rains, triggering floods and widespread damage across the entire island of Luzon. Before the country could recover, another less powerful storm, Typhoon Nalgae, struck on October 1, following the same route, adding to flooding and isolating communities.

Name: Bolivia Floods-2012
Summary__c: A La Niña weather phenomenon has created irregular rain patterns throughout South America, causing serious flooding in Bolivia.  Floods have affected virtually all of the country.  More than 13,000 families (or 65,000 people) are affected. The government declared a state of emergency in February. Rains are predicted to continue into April. Bolivia is also experiencing an outbreak of dengue fever and the Red Cross is working to address water and sanitation issues caused by the floods to curb the spread of the disease. Assessments show that the most immediate needs of affected families are for relief items, rehabilitation of water and sanitation systems to prevent further spread of dengue and support for livelihoods as many crops have been lost.

Name: Mexico Hurricane Jimena-2009
Summary__c: Hurricane Jimena hit Mexico’s Baja California peninsula as a category two hurricane on September 3, affecting the state of Baja California Sur and later the state of Sonora. The hurricane affected 120,000 people, causing damage to homes, businesses, electricity infrastructure, and water and transportation systems.

Name: Philippines Typhoon Washi-2011
Summary__c: Typhoon Washi hit the southern Philippines on December 17, bringing heavy rains and strong winds which resulted in massive flooding and widespread damage in the Northern Mindanao area.  According to government reports, the number of dead and missing is now more than 1,000. More than 10,000 homes were damaged or destroyed, displacing 284,600 people. More than 42,700 people are in 63 evacuation centers and another 241,800 people are staying with relatives or in makeshift structures.

Name: Philippines Typhoon Bopha-2012
Summary__c: Typhoon Bopha made landfall on the eastern coast of Mindanao Island in the Philippines on December 4, 2012.  The storm caused flooding and landslides, destroying homes, agriculture and infrastructure across coastal areas. Typhoon Bopha has affected 6.2 million people, killing 1,043 and leaving 841 missing. The storm damaged or destroyed over 130,000 houses and displaced over 986,000 people.  Destruction of roads and bridges is hindering response efforts to the most affected areas. Flooding and landslides have contaminated water supplies and 67 percent of health facilities in three provinces were damaged by the storm.

Name: Peru Floods-2012
Summary__c: Hydro-meteorological disturbances and La Niña weather phenomenon have worsened Peru’s annual rainy season, causing major flooding across the country. An estimated 650,000 people throughout Peru have been affected by the flooding and roads have sustained heavy damage, making relief distributions challenging. On March 29, the government declared a state of emergency for three-quarters of Peru’s departments. In the most affected department of Loreto, more than 1,800 families have been evacuated to emergency shelters. Initial needs assessments show that the most immediate needs of affected families include relief items, water and sanitation services, disease prevention efforts, and improvements to the conditions of emergency shelters.

Name: Philippines Floods-2012
Summary__c: Following the heaviest rains recorded in three years, the Philippines has experienced severe flooding that has impacted 2 million people.  Floods have damaged more than 14,000 homes and displaced approximately 500,000 people. The southwest monsoon was triggered by two storms, Typhoon Saola and Tropical Storm Haikui. More than 60 cities were immediately submerged in flood water. Continuous rain has affected a large majority of the country and some flood water is not expected to recede until February 2013. Thousands of people have sought refuge in evacuation centers, and are receiving basic provisions from the Philippine Red Cross.

Name: Disaster Project - Panama & Costa Rica Floods-2008
Kyrgyzstan-Uzbekistan Population Movement-2010
Summary__c: Since April 2010, political upheaval has led to ethnic clashes have escalated between Kyrgyz and Uzbeks living in southwest Kyrgyzstan.  An interim government had announced a referendum on a new constitution for the end of June.  Violent clashes, including looting and targeted killings. The violence has led an estimated 375,000 residents to flee their homes, particularly in the cities of Osh and Jalalabad.

Name: Panama Floods-2010
Summary__c: Continuous rains have fallen across Panama since early November, causing two deaths and affecting over 24,000 people in eight provinces. Overflowing rivers have caused severe floods over wide areas, while landslides have affected homes and cut off many communities.

Name: Indonesia Tsunami & Volcanic Eruption-2010
Summary__c: Two disasters struck Indonesia on October 25. Following a 7.7 magnitude earthquake, a 9-foot tsunami hit the Mentawai Islands off the coast of Sumatra, travelling at least a quarter of a mile inland and destroying the coastline in many locations. On the island of Java, the Mount Merapi volcano has been erupting since  October 25, killling 104 people.

Name: Mozambique Floods-2013
Summary__c: Heavy rains in January 2013 have caused flooding in Mozambique, destroying houses, schools, health centers and crops, forcing the affected populations to leave their homes in search of safer areas. These floods have affected more than 230,000 people and displaced more than 180,000 since the beginning of the rainy season in October 2012. The Ministry of Health confirmed a cholera outbreak in early February, with 317 cases and 2 deaths reported. The threat of more rain from an approaching storm could worsen flooding and cause further displacement and destruction.

Name: Central America Floods-2011
Summary__c: Since the beginning of October, heavy rains associated with a tropical depression have caused flooding and landslides throughout Central America—most severely in Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras and Nicaragua—resulting in more than 100 deaths and affecting more than 630,000 people.

Name: Mongolia Severe Winter-2010
Summary__c: More than ninety percent of Mongolia is experiencing severe winter conditions compounded by dzud, a phenomenon resulting from continuous heavy snowfall combined with extreme cold and preceded by dry summers, resulting in the insufficient production of grazing pastures. Herding is the main livelihood for 80 percent of Mongolia’s rural community. The dzud has had a devastating effect on the livelihood of herders by causing a serious loss of livestock, their primary source of income and food.

Name: El Salvador Floods-2009
Summary__c: On November 7 and 8, El Salvador experienced significant floods and mudslides due to the combined effects of Tropical Storm Ida and a low pressure weather system. Overflowing rivers destroyed houses, health centers, crops and infrastructure.

Name: Chile Earthquake-2010
Summary__c: On February 27, 2010, an earthquake of magnitude 8.8 occurred in Bío-Bío region in central Chile, 56 miles northeast of the city of Concepción. An ensuing tsunami affected the island of Juan Fernandez and communities along the coast in Bío-Bío region, inflicting loss of life and major damage to infrastructure.

Name: Paraguay Dengue Epidemic-2011
Summary__c: Paraguay Dengue Epidemic

Name: RFLHotline-pilot
Summary__c: The purpose of this project is to support the Restoring Family Links (RFL) program in serving more clients and providing more consistent and effective services through the establishment of a centralized call center. Existing American Red Cross call center technology will be leveraged to address the need for a sustained investment in technology, management, volunteer engagement and training as well as sustaining elements of the current RFL core functions for Movement coordination and partnerships. It is anticipated that establishment of an RFL call center will further the organization’s goals of  reducing costs, improving quality, and increasing efficiency of RFL services. Call agents from the Red Cross volunteer workforce will be cross-trained and cross-utilized to serve RFL and other clients at the Red Cross. Through this project the American Red Cross will have piloted and tested a call center model and be able to transition from a decentralized to a more central casework system for RFL that will have a lasting impact on improved quality for RFL clients and benefit the organization’s call center infrastructure through training a larger and more diverse pool of volunteers.

Name: Iraq Population Movement-2014
Summary__c: In early June, the security situation in northern regions of Iraq deteriorated as fighting between the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS) and the Iraqi government reached major cities. Mosul, the second largest city in Iraq, fell under the control of ISIS on June 10, followed by most of the surrounding Ninewah province. Security conditions have also worsened in Salah al-Din and Diyala provinces. The recent violence has displaced more than 650,000 people to the Kurdistan Region of Iraq. If the situation continues to deteriorate, humanitarian organizations expect significant additional displacements. This rapid population movement adds to the approximate 550,000 people displaced since January by a surge of violence in central and northern Iraq, and the more than 200,000 refugees from the Syria crisis currently residing in Iraq. Overall, an estimated 1.5 million people, including displaced persons, host communities and communities under siege are in need of humanitarian assistance in Iraq, a 300 percent increase from February. Humanitarian actors are mobilizing all resources available to scale up emergency operations across Iraq. Priority humanitarian needs are food, water and fuel. Protection and the risk of disease outbreak are also concerns, primarily for the hundreds of thousands displaced during the June offensive. Host communities are being increasingly stretched, as the conflict in neighboring Syria has also led to a large influx of refugees, mostly into the Kurdistan region.

Name: FY16 Saving Lives in the Caribbean (SLIC) Program
External_Title__c: Saving Lives in the Caribbean through Preparedness
Summary__c: On December 19th 2014, ARC submitted a cost-modification concept note following a request from OFDA/USAID’s Regional Advisor John Kimbrough. Following review of the cost extension concept note, ARC was asked by OFDA/USAID to submit a full proposal for a twelve-month, $300,000 USD cost extension modification request. The proposed cost extension will build on the success of the current OFDA-funded Saving Lives in the Caribbean through Preparedness (Saving Lives) project. Under this initiative, we will further strengthen the readiness capacity of Antigua & Barbuda, Bahamas, Barbados, Belize, Dominica, Grenada, Guyana, Jamaica, St. Kitts & Nevis, St. Lucia, St. Vincent & Grenadines, and Trinidad & Tobago, all which confront significant disaster risks. The proposed project will include interventions simultaneously at the most local level, through community response trainings, Community Disaster Response Team-led simulations (integrated with community-wide events), and small- scale mitigation projects, and at the Red Cross national society level, building first aid training capacity to promote first aid business and enhancing outreach to deliver life saving information using previously developed apps. We will also focus on integrating branch capacity building through program activities, thus promoting their further integration and development.

Name: Nepal Diarrhea Outbreak-2010
Summary__c: Diarrhea is endemic to Nepal due to unsafe hygiene practices, open defecation and lack of access to safe drinking water.  Additionally, poor health infrastructure, surveillance and laboratory facilities mean that highly transmissible diseases like cholera cannot be detected quickly at the local level, resulting in a delay in diagnosis and management, leading to high mortality and morbidity rates.  Statistics over the past five years indicate a trend of increasing cases, culminating in the 2009 outbreak in western Nepal that claimed an estimated 371 lives and affected approximately 67,000 people.  Given previous trends, an immediate and sustained intervention is required to prevent an outbreak with a number of deaths similar to or higher than those during previous monsoon seasons.

Name: Bolivia Floods-2011
Summary__c: Disruptions in weather patterns due to the La Niña effect have resulted in heavy rains in Bolivia, causing floods and mudslides affecting 88,000 people in 30% of the country’s municipalities. The Bolivian government estimates 7,400 acres of food crops have been lost.  Access to the affected areas is difficult due to damaged roads and bridges. Affected families are sheltering in camps and evacuation centers.  Authorities note the need for longer-term shelter solutions is becoming urgent, particularly in La Paz city, where there are challenges in locating land for transitional housing for families whose homes were destroyed by landslides.

Name: Haiti & Dominican Republic Cholera Outbreak-2010
Summary__c: Since October, a severe cholera outbreak has spread from the Artibonite River to all departments in Haiti. Cholera is a highly contagious illness, especially in situations with poor sanitation, a lack of clean water and crowded living conditions. It causes severe diarrhea and dehydration and can kill within 24 hours if not treated.

Name: Zimbabwe Food Insecurity-2012
Summary__c: The food security crisis in Zimbabwe is affecting 1.6 million people primarily in the southern regions of the country. Below-normal rainfall is forecast for the southern regions of Zimbabwe throughout the coming season which may worsen conditions in the regions already affected by drought. Droughts over the past two years, along with poor agriculture practices and limited access to supplies, have contributed to a smaller harvest this year. Assessments indicate an immediate need for food, agriculture support and clean water.

Name: RFL-Training-San Diego
Summary__c: The San Diego chapter will be hosting a Restoring Family Links Caseworker Course February 26th and Outreach Workshop February 27th.  A RFL Mentor from the Los Angeles Region will be facilitating both trainings.

Name: FY17 IROC Underfunded Disasters with ARCT
Building Sustainable School Red Cross Clubs in the Kavango Regions, Namibia
External_Title__c: Building Sustainable School Red Cross Clubs in the Kavango Regions, Namibia
Summary__c: The purpose of this project is to build youth engagement, youth leadership skills, and a new generation of future Red Cross leaders who understand and put into practice the principles of the Red Cross Red Crescent Movement through their participation in school based Red Cross clubs. The project will establish 6 school based youth clubs in the East and West Kavango regions, targeting Grade 8 through 12 students, paired and supported through a network of local and international volunteer, life skills teachers, and twinned with establish school RedCross clubs in other countries for peer-peer support.

Name: FY16 IFRC Americas Regional Office Pledge: Disaster Risk Reduction
Summary__c: Funds contributed to the IFRC for DRR Workshop in Panama, per Appeal MAA42003 - Americas Region, Project code P42107 - Disaster Risk Redcution. Budget is in USD, AP code 2582.

Name: ARC/StLRC Funding & Collaboration Agreement
Summary__c: The American Red Cross (ARC) received a donation from the Hess Corporation established Hurricane Allen St. Lucia Fund in 2000 to support projects benefiting the poor, distressed, and underprivileged citizens of St. Lucia through the collaborative efforts of ARC and the St. Lucia National Red Cross Society (StLRC). This donation is held in the United States in an ARC interest bearing account.  A Funding Agreement was established  to maximize the cooperation and coordination of the ARC and StLRC to ensure the commitment by the Parties to work effectively and in an efficient manner. ARC and StLRC intend to enter into separate project agreements to implement projects.  The Funding Agreement is effective June 1, 2015 between the ARC and the StLRC. The Agreement supercedes and replaces the “Funding Agreement” effective November 11, 2000 and “Funding Agreement Amendment” effective May 15, 2008.

Name: Costa Rica Population Movement-2015
Summary__c: Beginning in November 2015, increasing number of Cuban migrants are arriving at the Paso Canoas border crossing between Panama and Costa Rica.

Summary__c:
This project represents the 2nd phase of the Zimbabwe Volunteer Management System project, which begain in FY15 funded by the ARCT Capable Partners grant.  https://na14.salesforce.com/a00d000000YsRn7?srPos=2&srKp=a00

Name: Argentina Floods-2016
Summary__c: More than 20,000 people were displaced by the end of December due to floods caused by the rise of the Uruguay, Paraná, and Paraguay rivers, brought on by heavy rainfall in the provinces of Entre Ríos, Corrientes, Formosa, Chaco y Santa Fe. The impact on the agricultural sector is expected to be severe.
