Name: FY13-15 Resilience in the Americas (IPA/RITA) in Belize
Summary__c: Currently, there is a tendency to design community based disaster preparedness (CBDP) programs using a prescriptive, standard package of activities. While the activities have proven effective in some contexts, programming in this way neglects to consider articulated community desires and indigenous coping strategies as the basis for program design. It also limits the scope of disaster risk reduction interventions to a core set of CBDP interventions that may not be the most relevant or effective in all environments or that could be strengthened by integrating additional sectors. The proposed integrated, participatory assessment initiative will result in better understanding of the key needs, vulnerabilities, and hazards of diverse, disaster prone communities as well as existing resources that may be mobilized to make them safer and more able to cope with hazards.   Participatory assessments will take place in eleven countries in the region, including: El Salvador, Costa Rica, Panama, Nicaragua, Colombia, Paraguay, Ecuador, Belize, The Bahamas, Saint Lucia and Guyana. A number of target communities have been pre-selected as a result of current programming.  The remaining communities will be selected based on criteria issued specifically for this initiative. Research around participatory learning demonstrates that people are motivated to solve problems when they themselves participate in a solution.  Therefore, it is assumed that community members who partake in the participatory integrated, assessments will be empowered and directly benefit from involvement in the process. Recruitment for participatory assessments will focus on gender balance and equal representation of all members in the community, regardless of age, gender or ethnicity. An estimated minimum of twenty people per community will be mobilized as assessment participants resulting in at least 2,240 direct beneficiaries. Additional direct beneficiaries will be reached through skills and knowledge building activities such as First Aid training and Community Disaster Response Team (CDRT) trainings. At least ten people per community will participate in each of these activities. Therefore, an approximate total of 5,000 direct beneficiaries will be reached.

Name: RFL-World Refugee Day-Baltimore
Summary__c: Baltimore will use this World Refugee Day Grant to participate in local World Refugee Day celebrations. Through this event, they will build closer relationships with local refugee resettlement agencies as well as refugee communities in the region.

Name: GFDRR Challenge Grant
Summary__c:
This project addresses the challenge of engaging smart phone app users to quickly and accurately crowd source information about hazard impacts in a reliable way. The data collected will inform disaster response planning and decision making.   This project builds additional enhancements to already existing Red Cross multi-hazard apps available in Indonesia, Myanmar and the Philippines that enable users to assess and prepare, mitigate risks and take action while communicating government alerts and key messages from the Red Cross that will better prepare the public for whatever the future may bring. 
 
Emergency resources are often insufficient to fully satisfy the demands for professional help and supplies after a public disaster. Urban populations continue to expand worldwide; natural disasters are precipitating increased challenges to public health, welfare, and safety. Simultaneously, another trend has arisen—the use of social networking and crowdsourcing for disaster management and improving public health. Earthquakes, tsunamis, tornadoes, violent storms, and influenza epidemics have proven difficult to manage despite all of our technological advancements. When a disaster occurs, sometimes the best way to save numerous lives is to generate a timely reaction to its outcomes. That puts extra emphasis on the importance of high-quality information management for emergency communications.
 
Crowdsourcing has proven to be an informal process for obtaining information about desired services, ideas, or content. The Global Disaster Preparedness Center (GDPC), a resource center of the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent societies hosted by the American Red Cross, proposes adding an enhancement to its existing multi-hazard apps to capture public reporting of disaster impacts in a way that quickly validates the extent of the disaster impact by querying other nearby app users. This chained effect can quickly map pockets or widespread hazard impacts, damages or other inconveniences such as power outage or disruption in other services. For example, if someone reports their home is flooded, nearby app users will receive a notification asking whether they too have flooding. The users will have an opportunity to quickly respond. If anyone answers in the affirmative, the notifications will continue. This result is a spontaneous ability to rapidly map communities or neighborhoods.  This potentially powerful tool is designed to provide real-time data enabling quick responses during earthquakes, hurricanes, flooding, or other natural disasters.  It also allows the alerting of people in affected areas and notifies them with key messages about how to stay safe or ‘what to do’ now information.  In contrast with established emergency management methods, crowdsourcing can provide faster localized information for situational awareness and assistance in disaster situations. 
 
This project seeks to capture the good will and self-motivation of app users, who during a disaster, frequently look to their smart devices for information and guidance. By asking users to report their current status or observation, Red Cross and emergency managers could radically reduce the time, effort and cost of doing preliminary disaster assessments in the moments following a disaster impact. Making crowd sourced information reliable and trustworthy is challenging especially as it is self-reported.  The GDPC approach will hopefully validate the self-reported through methods of triangulation and expanded mapping of responses.  By utilizing the multi-hazard app as the crowdsourcing platform, the public will have the added benefit of rich risk reduction content and access to warning messages.

Name: FY17 OFDA Honduras
External_Title__c: Disaster and Climate Resilient Honduran Communities
Summary__c: Honduras is a country highly vulnerable to many natural hazards including tropical storms, hurricanes, landslides, droughts, and earthquakes. Since 2015, Honduras has also been hit hard by the effects of the El Niño phenomenon which has caused a severe and prolonged drought in the country. The current drought, the ongoing vulnerabilities to disasters and the lack of appropriate response mechanisms at the local levels have affected many Honduran communities. Building off the experience of the American Red Cross in the region and the work of the Honduran Red Cross at the community level, the project seeks to build capacity at individual, community and institutional level to promote resilience to disasters and climate related phenomena as well as raise awareness and train communities and local authorities on good practices related to water, hygiene and sanitation. The project will work in the area of risk management, including activities such as vulnerability and capacity assessments, creation and training of community committees, the development of emergency and contingency plans, as well as the area of water and sanitation with activities such as PHAST trainings, water management training and micro-projects.

Name: FY17 OFDA Costa Rica
External_Title__c: Actions to reduce the effects of El Niño and climate change in the North Pacific
Summary__c:
This project focuses on promoting education, organization and community strengthening in the area of environmental management, in order to implement actions to mitigate the impact of climate change in populations of the Canton of Carrillo in Guanacaste that have been severely affected by El Niño. This will be done through close coordination with local governments and the Ministry of Environment and Energy, the Institute of Aqueducts and Sewers and the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock.

Project activities will be carried out with community members from the northern Pacific zone of the country, as well as organizations and community leaders who engage in actions to reduce the effects of drought on their economic activities and livelihood. Likewise, paid and volunteer staff of the Costa Rican Red Cross will be involved in training and implementation of activities in areas related to the project, in order to strengthen institutional capacity in the field.

Overall the project seeks to: strengthen community organization in the area of environmental management; increase coordination mechanisms (public and private sector) to reduce the effects of climate change; have trained and aware communities especially in as it relates to environmental management issues; have communities prepared to respond to periods of drought; strength and capacity of the Costa Rican Red Cross to address these issues in other communities.

Name: Flash Flood Crisis Communications Campaign in Iraq with OFDA
Summary__c:
Dollar Amount Requested from USAID/OFDA: $333,640 (AP 0651)
Dollar Amount from Other Sources: $51,173 (cost share AP 0751)
Total Dollar Amount of Program: $384,813

This project,  a Flash Flood Crisis Communications Campaign, will employ a comprehensive community mobilization strategy to enhance public awareness of preparedness information and support local resilience in anticipation of flash flooding caused by a compromise of the Iraqi Mosul Dam.  The campaign reflects the mutual goal of USAID/OFDA and the Red Cross to save lives by strengthening early warning and early action, utilizing the Red Cross’s network of partners and well-established guidance and outreach tools with disaster preparedness and response information. 

The project involves a two-pronged strategy grounded in dissemination of Red Cross/Red Crescent (RC/RC) flood-related public awareness and public educational (PAPE) guidance: first through communication methods rooted in traditional media, and secondly through the GDPC-supported Universal App Program for increased access and reach. The first prong involves local-capacity building and mobilization through working with local partners to disseminate preparedness messaging and actionable information via channels such as radio programming, community forums, and trainings.  The second prong leverages mobile applications for rapid information communication, through the First Aid App already developed by the Iraqi Red Crescent Society (IRCS) and through development of a Multi-Hazard app to contextually fit the region and specific hazards.  Through this dual outreach strategy of complementary traditional public education campaigns as well as use of new technologies, the proposed intervention will provide and amplify localized early warning alerts and preparedness information to hard-to-access governorates at risk of flash flooding. Enhancing communication networks through the proposed project will provide a significant opportunity for OFDA to support the linking of pre-disaster preparedness activities with the creation of post-disaster response capacity.

The Global Disaster Preparedness Center (GDPC), along with the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC) and the American Red Cross, is strongly positioned to lead this type of crisis communications intervention with the IRCS’s access, as well as the support and experience of the global RC/RC network.  The IRCS is an auxiliary to Government of Iraq disaster management plans, and an inherent part of the Government of Iraq contingency planning process.  With some 2,000 paid staff and 4,000 volunteers already working to reach vulnerable populations in Iraq, the IRCS will play an integral role in mobilizing communities exposed to the Mosul Dam hazard.  The IRCS is also already actively engaged in responding to the concurrent complex humanitarian emergency and associated displacement in Iraq, and as such has strong working relationships with other key humanitarian partners on the ground in Iraq, such as UNDP.  These preexisting relationships will facilitate coordination and cooperation between this project and other response activities being implemented.  The RC/RC network has solid experience utilizing PAPE messages in early warning campaigns and leveraging the First Aid and Multi-Hazard apps for early warning dissemination.  With the GDPC support and the RC/RC network’s knowledge and experience, the IRCS will enhance public access to preparedness information and guide individual and community decision-making to respond to this urgent threat.

Name: RFL-Outreach-Baltimore
Summary__c: This outreach grant will increase the Greater Chesapeake Region to increase their outreach capabilities and efforts to populations in need of the reconnecting families services of the American Red Cross.

Name: RFL-Outreach-Minnesota
Summary__c: This Outreach Grant will help increase capacity in the Minnesota Region by providing funds for an RFL Caseworker Training. The training will help ensure that chapters throughout the entire region will be ready and capable of providing RFL services. The training coincides with a conference that will also allow RFL caseworkers to build relationships with partner organizations to better reach potential clients.

Name: Climate Services for Resilient Development Partnership
Summary__c:
To increase resilience to climate change impacts in developing countries by establishing a new partnership to harness, create, and provide timely, useful climate data, information, tools, and services while also reducing greenhouse gas emissions when possible. This partnership will draw on the strengths and resources of the public, private, non-governmental organizations, and academic communities. The partnership will seek to advance a global community of practice, address coverage gaps, develop actionable tools and services, build capacity in developing countries by leveraging existing expertise and efforts in-country and across the region, and apply the knowledge and capabilities of partner organizations to the challenges.

This partnership has identified three countries and associated sub-regions to begin these efforts. These are: Bangladesh and the South Asian Region; Ethiopia and the East Africa Region; and Colombia and the Andean Region. It is recognized that the specific actions under this partnership need to be driven by the needs of stakeholders in these respective countries, as such the partnership has formed country level working groups tasked with defining priority actions.
 
External Partners Include:
White House Office of Science and Technology (OSTP), National Security Council, and U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID), Asian Development Bank, DFID ESRI, Google, Inter-American Development Bank, Skoll Global Threats Foundation and the UK Met Office
 
Internal RC/RC Partners Include:
 
RC/RC Climate Centre
Ethiopian Red Cross
Colombia Red Cross
Bangladesh Red Crescent

Name: Fire Sensors for Safer Urban Communities, Bridge Funding
External_Title__c: Fire Sensors for Safer Urban Communities, Bridge/Gap Funding
Sub_Sector__c: Community-Based Disaster Preparedness;Early Warning Early Action;Urban
Summary__c:
The Fire Sensors for Safer Urban Communities project was a six-month rapid deployment of smart home sensors in 1,000 households in Mukuru, Kenya.  During these six months a variety of activities were carried out which included engaging the community members in a human centered co-design process, extensively mapping the community, fire response refresher training for approximately 300 community members and an innovation challenge held in Nairobi. A variety of partners were also engaged in this project including UNICEF, Map Kibera, Spatial Collective, the University of Nairobi, iHub, Ushahidi, frog and Halo Smart Labs.
 
The funding for the initial phase of this project ended in January 2016. This gap funding is intended to maintain the partnerships and momentum of the first phase of funding, while improving the overall system, until further larger scale funding can be sourced.

Name: Camp Autonomization through FRC
External_Title__c: Camp Autonomization through French Red Cross
Summary__c: In order to reduce camp residents' dependency on humanitarian assistance and decrease displaced households' density in long term camps, this project seeks to improve resilience of the population in several camps by increasing self-management and access to services as well as livelihood opportunities for IDPs and their surrounding neighborhoods.

Name: FY17 Resilience in Myanmar with ARCT (Asia)
Summary__c:
Project Goal: Targeted communities and MRCS branches have better disaster preparedness and strong capacity to undertake humanitarian assistance in time of disaster and emergency.

Project Objectives:
  • Five communities are supported with preparation of community action plans conducting of disaster drills.
  • Five schools are supported with preparation of school disaster management plans and conducting of two awareness sessions.
  • Four MRCS branches are supported with preparation of branch development plan in order to deliver better humanitarian services.
Project Locations: Dedaye township of Ayeyarwaddy region; Three townships of Kayah State; Myanmar

Project Sectors: Disaster Risk Reduction, Organizational Development, Resource Mobilization

Budget: $95,894
Duration: July 1, 2016 - June 30, 2017

Name: HRC Response to Zika (QAF)
External_Title__c: Haitian Red Cross Response to Zika
Summary__c:
The Zika Virus is an emerging mosquito-born virus first identified in Uganda in 1947. Prior to 2015, Zika outbreaks ocurred mostly in Africa,South East Asia and the Pacific Islands. In May 2015 the Pan American Health Organization (PAHO) issued an alert confirming the first Zika virus infections in Brazil. Currently outbreaks are ocurring in many countries in the region and in January 2016, the Haitian Ministry of Public Health and Population (MSPP) confirmed the presence of Zika in Haiti. As of March 18th, 2016 1,777 cases of Zika virus infection have been reported in Haiti.

The Haitian Red Cross proposes to address the risk of a Zika virus epedemic in Haiti through community mobilization and vector control. Two of the six strategic approaches set out by MSPP to fight the epedemic.

The project will target the areas of the West Department (Carrefour-Feuilles and Canaan), the North Department (Cap-Haitian, LaVictoire, Borgne, Ranquite, and Bahon), and the Northeast Department ( Ouanaminth, Haut Maribahoux and Bah Maribahoux).

Name: Directly Implemented Gran No Pi Djanm (GNPD)
Summary__c:
The key deliverables of the project are broken down by pillar:

  • Pillar 1 - Capacity Building: Haitian Red Cross and local line ministries have improved organizational and technical capacity sufficient to support program implementation and to work towards achieving their strategic objectives.
  • Pillar 2 - Community mobilization, training and behavior change: Effective community mobilization and behavior change strategies build more resilient communities and households. 
  • Pillar 3 - Development of community assets and physical environment: Targeted communities benefit from locally appropriate small- to medium-scale projects such as improved road access, health center refurbishment, and water and sanitation facilities.

Name: Direct Implementation of Enhanced Health Service Delivery
Cholera Response Supply Shipment through PiH
External_Title__c: Cholera Response Supply Shipment through Partners in Health
Summary__c: Due to the outbreak of cholera and the urgency of hospitals and medical facilities to respond to the situation, Partners in Health has obtained ringers lactate and other medical supplies to donate for the cholera response. This grant letter will allow the reimbursement of expenses in the amount of $136,400 that PIH paid for the shipping of the goods on two flights as well as the purchase of megaphones.

Name: HHAP Project Agreement with HRC for PrevSIDA
Sub_Sector__c: HIV/AIDS General;HIV Prevention;HIV Care and Support
Summary__c: In a continuation of the HIV prevention work we have been doing in Haiti since 2004, the American Red Cross, in partnership with the Haitian Red Cross and Population Services International, has joined a consortium of NGO’s funded by USAID working to prevent the sexual transmission of HIV in Haiti. The project will work to identify populations and settings with high-risk behavior and then to improve HIV/AIDS- related knowledge, attitudes, skills and behaviors of the most at-risk populations through individual outreach and community-wide events. The project will also work to strategically link communication and education interventions for sexual prevention of HIV with other health related services and commodities, including targeted condom promotion and availability, as well as livelihoods initiatives for most-at-risk populations and those in settings characterized by high risk behaviors. The project seeks to reach 1,062,680 individuals from high risk youth and adult populations over the course of four and a half years.

Name: Shelter Retrofit for Rental through CARE
External_Title__c: From Camps to Secure Housing in Haiti through CARE
Summary__c: CARE's "Kay Solid Nan Plas Kan Yo (From Camps to Secure Houses)" project aims to close camps by providing camp residents opportunities for safe housing, access to improved sanitation facilities and livelihoods, and security to people currently living in damaged structures.

Name: Participatory Urban Development and Livelihoods through USAID (CUCD)
Burundi Complex Emergency-2015
Summary__c: The current rainy season has been causing severe damages to housing due the El Niño climate event since November 2015, and is expected to continue until May 2016. Until mid-January 2016, heavy rains and floods resulted in the damage and/or the destruction of 5,068 houses in Burundi, affecting 30,408 persons who are in need of assistance in shelter/NFI, based on assessments conducted by the authorities with support from the Burundian Red Cross.

Name: FY17 OFDA Panama
External_Title__c: Mitigation Actions against the effects of climate change in Los Santos
Summary__c: This project aims to build the capacity of communities and schools to mitigate, prepare for and respond efficiently to disasters in the province of Los Santos, Panama. Los Santos is located south of the Azuero Peninsula and is made up the following districts: Los Santos, Guararé, Las Tablas, Macaracas, Pedasí, Pocrí and Tonosí. Currently, an extended period of drought has resulted in devastating social and economic consequences for the population of Los Santos, namely a significant water shortage for human consumption and agricultural use. As the communities of Los Santos do not have the capacity to prepare for or respond to such risks and disasters, the effects of this drought have only been compounded – demonstrating the necessity of new strategies and interventions to build the communities’ coping capacity. Considering its substantial history working in coordination with both governmental and nongovernmental institutions, the Panamanian Red Cross is uniquely well-positioned to implement community capacity building activities. Through the Panamanian Red Cross, the proposed intervention aims to work with communities, schools and Civil Protection organizations to strengthen capacity to be better prepared for and respond to future disasters at all levels by creating effective and sustainable practices for risk reduction, healthy hygiene habits, safe water management, and promoting behavioral and attitudinal change toward the care and maintenance of ecosystems. In order to achieve these goals, it is important to strengthen the level of social organization of these communities, providing knowledge, tools and opportunities for improvement to connect initiatives at the community with provincial and regional level actors.

Name: RFL-Phone Project-Arizona New Mexico El Paso
Summary__c:
**Pilot project began in FY14 and continues through FY16*
The project continues the partnership with Catholic Charities and No More Death, for the purpose of providing international/national calls to migrants traveling through the south of AZ.  Service provision is implemented through the partnership.  This effectively means that the organization continues providing a space, while the American Red Cross will provide material resources in the form of phones (including 1 satellite phone), phone signal boosters and informational materials resources. American Red Cross (ARC) will provide regular training to the organizations volunteers to follow ARC call guidelines. In addition volunteers will also provide a monthly log of the calls.  Each call is a reconnection to a family member and can potentially provide important contact and knowledge of the migrant’s well-being.   
 
In addition to providing international/national calls, the ARC seeks to supplement this partnership with additional material resources, which are needed by the beneficiaries.  Specifically, the partner has asked the American Red Cross to contribute co Comfort kits, which would be used by migrants coming to the shelters.  These comfort kits provide basic hygiene needs which are desperately needed by migrants who have had limited access to water, and have traveled the rough terrain with limited access to water and basic hygiene.

Name: FY16 Nyaruguru Resilience Project in Rwanda -Duhuzeimbaraga, twiyubaka (Africa)
External_Title__c: Building Community Resilience in Rwanda
Summary__c: The project seeks to reduce the number of deaths, injuries and socio economic impacts caused by disasters through strengthening Rwandan Red Cross Society and building safer and more resilient communities in twelve villages in Nyaruguru district.

Name: Construction of Septic Tanks in Support of 16/6 Program through UNOPS
Summary__c:
In  Haiti,  UNOPS  is  one  of  the  4  UN  partners  of  the  Governments  16/6  program  and  is  responsible  for  the  design  and  implementation  of  the  Housing and  Community Infrastructure  aspect of  the  project.  The first phase funded by the Haitian Reconstruction Fund  (HRF),  is  located  in  the  6 neighborhoods  of  Pétion‐Ville and Turgeau.  The  second  phase,  located  in  Fort  National,  funded  by  the  Department of Foreign  Affairs,  Trade,  Development  Canada  (DFATD,  formerly  CIDA).  These  two programs  are  scheduled  over  a  24‐month  period.
The  main  objective  of  UNOPS  and  the  16/6  program  is  to  provide  the  Government  of Haiti  with  different  housing  models  and  community  infrastructure  solutions,  which  are sustainable  and  replicable.  To  be  able  to  achieve  these  goals,  a  holistic  approach  was used  to  tackle  the  main  difficulties  blocking  both  the  housing  sector,  including  the complexity  of  the  land  tenure  situation,  the  lack  of housing  credit,  weaknesses  in  the construction  industry  and  local  authorities,  high  density  settlements,  no  urban  planning, limited  historical  government  interventions,  and  very  difficult  terrain  prone  to  landslides and  other  natural  risks. UNOPS  engaged  in  three  different  housing  solutions  in  order  to  address  the  issue  of  lack of  housing  in  informal  urban  settlements: Repair  and  reinforcements,  Single  core expandable  houses  and  collective  site.
 
The  main  objective  of  this  request  is  to  seek funding  for  the sanitation  component attached  to  the  housing  program.  In  light  of  the  request  of  the Direction  Nationale  de l'Eau  Potable  et  de  l'Assainissement (DINEPA),  the  National  Water  and  Sanitation Agency,  of  having  a  toilet  for  each  new  house  constructed,  the  project  is  in  need  of  350 sanitation  packages  that  include  the  septic  tank  and  related  plumbing  to  finish  the program.  This  would  cater  to  350  families  who  are  in  need  of  housing  in  the  neighborhoods  of  Pétionville  and  Turgeau. Since  this  falls  inside  of  the ongoing  16/6  project,  the  requested  funds  are  only  for  labor and  material,  as  all  UNOPS  personnel  are  covered.

Name: TTL - Yolanda Recovery Program in Leyte Province, Philippines 2014 - 2017
External_Title__c: TTL - Yolanda Recovery Program in Leyte Province, Philippines 2014 - 2017
Sub_Sector__c: Sanitation Facilities;Cash-for-work;Cash Grants;(DISASTER RISK REDUCTION);Water Infrastructure;(BENEFICIARY ENGMT & ACCOUNTABILITY);Community Mobilization;Education and Awareness;Urban;(GIS & INFORMATION MANAGEMENT);Psychosocial Support;Chapter Support and Public Outreach;(KNOWLEDGE MANAGEMENT);Infrastructure Construction-S&S;Integrated Neighborhood Renewal;Land Stabilization;Permanent Housing;Progressive / Core Shelter;Public Building Construction;Shelter Technical Assistance
Summary__c:
The Philippines Red Cross (PRC) in partnership with the American Red Cross (ARC) is seeking USD 20 million to support a three year program beginning
July 2014 and ending by June 2017. Program implementation is the bulk of the budget with more than 75% allocated to the implementation of the core
sectors, Shelter & Settlements, Livelihoods and Sanitation. The budget includes a mandatory 6% overhead charge from PRC amounting to USD 1.2
million over the three years. This money is to support PRC operational needs not directly associated with implementation of the Leyte program,
including staffing at HQ (e.g. Recovery Task Force) among other costs. All PRC staff directly associated with implementation have been included in the
program budget while no ARC delegate or management costs are included in the program budget.
 
The PRC/ARC partnership (herein referred to as the Partnership) will implement an integrated program in accordance with the PRC Recovery Strategy
in the hardest hit province of Leyte targeting four municipalities (Tacloban City, Alangalang, Mayorga and MacArthur) and providing support in up to 25
Barangays.
 
The program uses the overall PRC Recovery Strategy goal: To contribute to building safe and resilient communities by identifying and addressing various factors
that will help people sustainably rebuild their lives, livelihoods and assets while ensuring that future climate, environmental and disaster related risks are addressed
and/or minimized.

Name: Emergency Assistance to Refugees in Tanzania - PRM12
External_Title__c: Emergency Assistance to Refugees in Tanzania
Summary__c:
Objective 1: Provide high quality healthcare services for at least 90% of refugees in Nyarugusu camp and 20% of Tanzanians living within the vicinity of the camp.
Objective 2: Provide quality basic health services for at least 90% of Burundian refugees in Nyarugusu II camp by providing curative, preventative, and rehabilitative healthcare and community outreach/health & hygiene promotion.

Name: 2016 Namibia Social Mobilization Campaign
Summary__c:
With support in the amount of $175,865 USD from the American Red Cross, the Namibian Red Cross Society will train and mobilize volunteers in 9 out of the 13 regions of the country to conduct social mobilization activities to coincide with the national measles vaccination campaign.  The social mobilization campaign will focus on volunteers conducting house to house visits within targeted communities to provide information and education on the importance of vaccinations and encourage caregivers to bring their children to vaccination posts.  

Activties:
•    Training 1243 volunteers on social mobilization techniques
•    House to house visits by the volunteers in targeted areas before and during the campaign
•    Dissemination of immunisation message through the radio
•    Distribution of IEC materials before and during the campaign
•    Monitoring and supervision of volunteers by NRCS staff
•    Participation in ICC meetings by the NS 
•    The NS will participate in planning/coordination meetings at the Ministry of Health at all levels

Expected Outputs:
•    Increased community awareness on the importance of immunisation
•    Communities in remote  areas are reached with immunisation messages 
•    National Society increasingly participating in the ICC
•    Increased visibility of the NS

Name: FY17 OFDA El Salvador-Phase III
External_Title__c: Building Resilience in Chaparrastique Volcano Affected Communities phase III
Summary__c: In December 2013, El Salvador’s third highest volcano, Chaparrastique, erupted causing thousands to flee their homes. The Salvadoran Red Cross responded immediately providing assistance to the communities and coordinating with local authorities. Despite these efforts, this event demonstrated that communities were neither well prepared nor organized to respond to the event. With the volcano remaining active and the compounded threat of climate related event such as the current El Niño, advance preparation and mitigation is essential. This project build off the current and previous phases of the Building resilience in Chaparrastique Volcano Affect Communities project to ensure that a wider reach of communities and schools within the direct vicinity of the volcano are better prepared for and able to respond to future disasters. The project targets 7 communities and includes activities such as first aid training, creation of community disaster plans, installation of early warning systems, livelihoods training, land use and conservation training and simulation exercises which will increase community knowledge and preparedness to address future disaster hazards and risk. In order to increase knowledge and preparedness in the school systems, trainings in First Aid and evacuation and school protection plans developed, as well as workshops on climate change will also be implemented. Lastly, communities will also receive training in water and sanitation and receive water storage containers that will allow them to have access to safe water.

Name: Rubble Removal and Demolition through JPHRO
External_Title__c: Rubble Removal and Demolition through J/P Haitian Relief Organization
Summary__c: One of the most immediate and pressing needs after the earthquake has been the clearance of millions of cubic meters of rubble and debris from streets, home sites and community buildings. J/P HRO has developed a rubble removal model that is innovative, reproducible and sustainable and which the International Organization of Migration (IOM) has identified as a hallmark of excellence in this field. While developing this expertise, J/P HRO has witnessed first-hand how rubble removal leads to the reinvigoration of local communities through improved safety and rebirth of businesses, schools, health centers and commerce. Furthermore, on-site construction training of local Haitians translates into future work in the construction trade, providing long-term employment in the communities, over the years of rebuilding to come.

Name: Uganda Population Movement-2013
Summary__c: The escalating violence in the Republic of South Sudan has provoked a mass population displacement within South Sudan and into neighboring countries. Uganda has taken the bulk of refugees who have continued to cross the borders since the beginning of the conflict in mid-December 2013. More than 60,000 South Sudanese refugees have crossed into Uganda, and these numbers are expected to increase as the conflict continues between the Government of South Sudan and the opposition, despite the Peace Agreement signed by both parties in January 2014. The increasing number of refugees means that tens of thousands of people in Uganda are in dire need of emergency medical care, shelter, food, water, and adequate sanitation facilities.

Name: India Typhoon Phailin-2013
Summary__c: Cyclone Phailin made landfall along India’s eastern coast on October 12, 2013. Over 1.1 million residents in the region were evacuated before the storm hit. Some 60,000 people were left homeless after the storm hit 14,000 villages mainly in coastal districts. An estimated 13.23 million people were affected; 47 people were found dead. As emergency teams began assessing damage from the country’s biggest cyclone in 14 years, a massive relief effort went into full swing to distribute food to an estimated one million evacuees, clear roads and help the injured. More than 950,000 houses were damaged, including 540,000 in the cyclone and 407,000 in the subsequent floods.

Name: Enhanced Health Service Delivery Program
External_Title__c: Enhanced Health Service Delivery with the Haitian Red Cross
Summary__c:
As Haiti strives to extend health services delivery and improve health outcomes by providing the population with equitable access to primary health services, the MSPP has launched an initiative that revolves around community-based interventions.  One key element of the MSPP’s strategy is to increase the availability of professional health resources by training and deploying 10,000 “Agents de Santé Communautaires Polyvalents”[1] or ASCPs.  The Haitian Red Cross as a long term partner to MSPP seeks to improve the effectiveness and efficiency of the services expected from the ASCP initiative and to build health resilience capacity at the community levels by leveraging its country-wide network of volunteers
 
The goal of the project is to contribute to building resilience in targeted communities in Haiti through improved access to primary health services and availability of trained personnel.
 
The project is divided into two pillars responsive to each objective. 
  • Pillar 1 will contribute to improving access to primary health services in Haiti by training and mobilizing HRC Health Volunteers to conduct health education and promotion in the community; and training “Agent de Santé Communautaires Polyvalents” and supporting MSPP in their deployment to serve as resources for primary health care at the community level. Under this pilar, 40 ASCPs will be trained, deployed and supported by 320 ASCPs at an average ratio of 1:8 of ASCP to HRCV-H.
  • Pillar 2 will support HRC to strengthen the training service capacity by improving their training infrastructure and obtaining national recognition as a training provider, which will result in a source of revenue for HRC.

Name: Indonesia Air Pollution Haze Crisis Response - USAID
Summary__c:
1. Justification/Problem Statement
 
The haze crisis, as well as climate change issues more broadly, was on the agenda on Monday when Indonesian President Joko Widodo made his first state visit to the US – a visit he shortened in order to return home to deal with the fires. Widodo's administration has deployed thousands of military personnel to fight the fires, including in an attempt to get water into peatlands, which ignite extremely easily when dried out. During a recent discussion with  Pak Jusuf Kalla, and other Board Members of PMI,   there were a number of  significant gaps  mentioned that still require support,  most especially supporting PMI to more proactively assist the Ministry of Health (MOH) in providing safe air spaces to those most negatively impacted was high on this  priorities. The Indonesian military also has positioned ships off the coasts of hard-hit areas to facilitate evacuations of children and other vulnerable people should that become necessary.
 
The Government of Indonesia’s (GOI) Ministry of Health will continue to focus its response on providing more public clean air spaces, particularly where vulnerable people are being evacuated. The government has identified local public buildings (health posts, community halls, PMI health centers and blood banks, etc.) in affected areas and provided required assistance to persons suffering from acute respiratory infections, with equipment, such as air purifiers, air conditioning, beds, oxygen, etc. The Ministry’s efforts also include providing in-patient and out-patient health care and treatment at health facilities.
 
Last week, USAID granted $150,000 to support Palang Merah Indonesia (PMI) through the American Red Cross as part of its response to haze-affected people in Riau, South Sumatra, and Central Kalimantan. This first phase intervention was initiated on Oct 29th by PMI Chairman and RI Vice President Jusuf Kalla and focuses on distributing masks (around 170,000 N95), health messaging, and supporting local health facilities and clean air buildings. With these activities beginning, PMI seeks to carry out a more effective intervention and more significantly support the GOI, which requires additional resources, particularly at the community level. Therefore, this proposal note requests consideration for awarding an additional $350,000 to intensify and broaden the level of support to smoke-haze affected  populations and enable PMI to more proactively support the GOI MOH response to this crisis.    
 
2) Needs summary and intervention measures
 
PMI requires resource to support and augment GOI operations, particularly government health facilities (Puskesmas-Public Health Centers, Hospitals) and other recognized local facilities. PMI also seeks resources to support interventions in in areas where it has existing health facilities, such as clinics/hospitals/mosques/blood banks, where safe clean air spaces can be made established and available or improving access to people requiring support and assistance with respiratory problems.
 
As most households do not have facilities that can ensure clean filtered air  and current MOH  facilities have been inadequate to meet  demand, especially from those who are most vulnerable, including  children, elderly and those with astmatic problems, this project  will  support existing public community facilities to augment exiting MOH facilities and provide  additional support to those most adversely  affected.  In some of places, “Clean air space/building” called “Rumah Singgah Asap” in Bahasa  Indonesia has proven to be an  effective temporary shelter to those most  affected by the smoke haze crisis, including those most vulnerable , such as children, pregnant women, and elderly. Local government officials, along with PMI, have identified and set up such facilities  within    community health posts (Puskesmas) mosques (haj dormitory), community halls (Balai) local government buildings etc. (see phots below), as Rumah singgah asap by providing air purifiers and or air conditioner, masks, beds, oxygen, ambulance, health personnel (doctor and or nurse), public kitchen and event space for playing for children. The facilities and services provided are varied depending on the local capacity and provided free to all people in need.
 
In these public clean air spaces, health personnel check on affected person’s health status, provide health promotion, and psychosocial support, especially for children. The  majority of those using these facilities are outpatients, while there are also some people, who require more intensive attention and spend  a few days at these facilities, in order to recover from the acute respiratory infection.  Ideally, there should be at least one Rumah Singgah Asap in each affected sub-district to ensure easy access and or sufficient coverage. These Rumah Singgah Asap are being promoted to communities, so they are aware of them and utilize these facilities when needed. PMI with its significant volunteers and staff (including doctors and nurses) can be fully mobilized to support this services. In addition, when needed, PMI with clinics and or blood transfusion units could use their building facilities to provide similar services.
 
At the district level, PMI is a respected as disaster lead response organization, with its unique strength: its volunteers. PMI have been consistently participated in coordinating with local government and communities they come from for this haze response – assisting to distribute masks, health messages, etc., in close collaboration with Public Health centers and District health offices. Therefore PMI support will continue to add and increase its value to local government as well as to affected communities with the proposed response actions below.
 
3) Proposed Response Action
 
The following measures are proposed for this second phase of appeal:
 
  1. Supporting forty five (45) the “safe and clean air spaces and shelters.”   It is proposed to have 15 shelters per province targeting 3 to 4 of these for each of the worst affected districts.  Each of these facilities will, on average, be able to handle 9 in-patients and 20-30 out-patients per day. The support required for these shelters, will include procurement of small equipment for clean air provision (A/Cs and/or air purifiers), and other associated operational costs of these emergency respiratory health related activities. All these facilities will operate in close coordination with Ministry of Health (MOH)   standards and coordinate with them and in some cases be staffed by them.
  2. Supporting the cost of local health personnel mobilization (such as per-diem and transportation), either from government or PMI volunteers (nurse, doctors) within two months.
  3. Provision of oxygen and simple plastic tents to support the treatment of those with acute respiratory problems at the existing health facilities. Due to the   intermittent nature of the electrical supply, operational costs for existing small gensets have also been budgeted at 30 percent of their time (this has been include in the shelter operational cost).
  4. Supporting PMI ambulance services to help bring people, with limited ability to access health facilities or safe building or shelters. Ensuring that ambulances will have  oxygen for patients  showing signs of difficulty in breathing.   Red Cross ambulances will be used, and only operational costs related to the significant increase in costs, of what PMI would normally cover, due to the increase in patients with acute respiratory  infections, requiring transportation,  have been  allocated to this project.
  5. Continue and increase provision and distribution of 60,000 pieces high quality masks (type N95 or similar mask that meets MOH standards), as well dissemination of health messaging.  An additional 225,000 Masks (Evo Type – certified by MOH for smoke) will be procured .
4) Beneficiary Numbers
 
In addition to the 4,791,959 people that will be reached by the current intervention, this second phase will cover an additional 10% of the population of Riau, South Sumatra, and Central Kalimantan, which includes approximately an additional 1.5 million people.

Temporary Shelter Support for EQ and Windstorm Affected Families in  Rasuwa

In 23 March, a strong wind hit the most of the VDCs of Rasuwa including the district headquarters Dhunche. Hundreds of temporary shelters of earthquake survivors were blown away when a strong storm entered through the settlement. Based on the preliminary report received from Nepal Red Cross Society (NRCS) Rasuwa District Chapter more than 750 households were affected. Also it has seen wider physical damages in public buildings, security posts, schools buildings, health facilities and power lines across the district. The northern VDCs in the district were hit the most by the strong wind.
After coordination with local Nepal Government authorities, the NRCS Rasuwa decided to request Galvanized Iron Sheets (CGI) with NRCS Headquarters as an immediate relief to provide to the storm affected families. These wind storm affected families were affected by earthquake and living in temporary shelter. 
NRCS DC immediately alerted its Sub-chapter to collect the data of damages consulting with local security forces. As of 28 March, NRCS shared the assessment report which shows the numbers of affected household at VDC level as shown in table to right. Similarly, NRCS DC has been regularly coordinating with District Disaster Relief Committee (DDRC) to collect beneficiaries list  to be supported and initiating the required resource to respond storm affected population to NRCS Headquarters. The DDRC have identified CGI along with necessary fixings is a prime need at the field as tarpaulin roofs are unable to bear the pressure of strong winds in affected areas.
Coordination and Response
The DDRC organized a meeting at district headquarters and decided to carry out rapid assessment mobilizing the network of security forces and Red Cross. Meeting also made decisions to request CGI sheet to National Earthquake Authority (NRA) and humanitarian agencies and all relief efforts will be handled through one door system getting the approval from DDRC.
NRCS DC participated in DDRC meeting held on 24 March and continuously sharing the information to NRCS HQs. At the same time, NRCS DC mobilized its volunteers to carry out rapid assessment in the affected areas. NRCS DC distributed 150 tarpaulins at Shyphru VDC so far. Following the decision of DDRC, NRCS Rasuwa requested to provide 700 bundles of CGI sheet to NRCS HQs.
NRCS DM Department already asked to District Chapter Rasuwa to share assessment report and deliver immediate relief in the affected VDCs. Based on the presence of Partner for earthquake recovery at field, NRCS have approached to American Red Cross for supporting emergency relief especially CGI to the storm affected families. After getting approval for assistance to respond from American Red Cross, NRCS HQs have proceeded the tendering process of 700 bundles of CGI sheet and fixings.
Further Needs and plan
Shelter NFIs such as tarpaulin, blankets, sleeping mat and CGI are reported as an urgent need in the affected areas. The roof of the most of houses are blown up by storm. As the affected areas are far from the district headquarters, the assessment is still ongoing and detail needs will be identified within next few days.
The NRCS HQs has asked the beneficiaries list with Rasuwa DC. Similarly, a detailed plan of CGI distribution at the storm hit areas have been preparing from the district chapter. The NRCS have prepared a budget sheet of expected expenditures for storm response and submitted to American Red Cross for consent. The details timeline of purposed response activities are shown in table below.
SnActivitiesMarchAprilMay
  4th week1st week2nd week3rd week4th week1st week2nd week3rd week
1Rapid assessment and sharing situation        
2Immediate relief-Tarpaulin, Blankets etc        
3Procurement of CGI         
4Delivery of CGI         
5Beneficiary selection and verification        
6Distribution of CGI sheet and fixings        
7Monitoring and supervision        
8Final reporting        
 

Budget
Based on the need from the field and discussions made with American Red Cross a total of NPR 7,823,340.00 was prepared and forwarded to American Red Cross for approval. The budget includes the procurement of CGI, mat, fixing kits and its transportation and distribution cost as well as associated administrative expenditures from HQs to district level.

Name: Gavi Country Assistance for Accelerated Implementation of Gavi Strategy 2016-20
External_Title__c: Gavi Country Assistance for Accelerated Implementation of Gavi Strategy 2016-20
Summary__c:
The Measles & Rubella Intiative team is submitting an application to be added to the Gavi Country Assistance for Accelerated Implementation of Gavi Strategy 2016-20 program.  If accepted we will be included on Gavi's list of pre-approved technical consultants for Gavi elegible countries and will be elegible to receive funding through Gavi to partner with countries on programs designed to increase demand of vaccination services.  

The M&RI team will use existing resources and staff as well support from staff within the three program regions to conduct projects.  Gavi has identfied 20 tier 1 and tier 2 priority countries where programming will be likely conducted, however all Gavi eligible countries would have potential access to engaging a partner on the technical consultants list.  The currently identified priority countries are below.

Tier 1 Priority Countries    
–    Kenya      –    India  
–    Nigeria     –   Uganda
–    Ethiopia   –   Congo, Dem. Rep.
–    Indonesia –   Afghanistan
–    Pakistan  –   Chad

Tier 2 Priority Countries    
–    Madagascar    –    Niger    
–    Somalia          –    Central African Rep.
–    Myanmar        –    Papua New Guinea
–    South Sudan   –    Haiti
–    Mozambique   –    Yemen

Acceptance onto the Gavi list does not gurantee future programming in any of the listed countries, nor is the American Red Cross obligated to partner with any country that approaches us through the list.

Please note that as no specific programs are identified there is no budget currently associated with this application.

Name: Rwanda Population Movement-2015
Summary__c: Since early April 2015, over 70,000 Burundi nationals have sought refuge in Rwanda due to pre-election tension and violence. Bujumbura currently remains particularly unstable, and refugees are crossing into Rwanda through 25 border entry points across 10 districts along the Burundi-Rwanda border, in the south east of the country.

Name: Pakistan Monsoon Floods-2010
Summary__c: In July 2010, heavy monsoon rains swept through large areas of Pakistan, affecting 18 million people and causing unprecedented floods that submerged homes, roads, bridges and cropland in more than 70% of the country.  The flooding led to widespread displacement of people, destruction of communities and damage to infrastructure.

Name: FY15 IROC Underfunded Disasters with ARCT
External_Title__c: Underfunded Disasters Grant
Summary__c:
International disaster response is at the core of the American Red Cross mission to prevent and alleviate human suffering in the face of emergencies by mobilizing the power of volunteers and the generosity of donors. It is also at the heart of the International Services strategic priority to assist vulnerable people and communities around the world to prepare for, respond to and recover from natural disasters, humanitarian crises and health emergencies, through mobilizing the power of the global Red Cross and Red Crescent network.
 
The American Red Cross, as part of the global Red Cross and Red Crescent network, ensures rapid and appropriate disaster response as part of a holistic approach to disaster management, which spans the disaster management cycle of preparedness, response and recovery. The purpose of this grant is to make additional resources available for the American Red Cross to respond to underfunded disasters globally in a timely manner in order to reduce the number of deaths, injuries and socio-economic impact caused by disasters.

The Underfunded Disasters Grant will support the American Red Cross priority of disaster response and align with International Services’ strategy to enhance the global Red Cross Global network’s resilience to respond to vulnerabilities. The proposed outcomes of the Underfunded Disasters grant are as follows:
 
Outcome 1: The Red Cross global network's capacity and readiness to coordinate, advocate for and deliver response activities for underfunded disasters is enhanced by support from the American Red Cross.
 
Outcome 2: More underfunded international disasters and humanitarian crises are supported by the American Red Cross and global partners have funds to implement disaster response and humanitarian assistance activities in a timely manner.

Name: Operational Leadership Support to IFRC
Summary__c: Financial support to the IFRC's operational leadership profile, consisting of $50,000 to the Head of Emergency Operations program and $10,000 to the Emergency Team Leader Training.

Name: Canada Wildfires-2016
Summary__c: The 2016 Fort McMurray wildfire began on May 1, 2016, southwest of the urban service area of Fort McMurray in the Regional Municipality of Wood Buffalo, Alberta. It has since spread through the town, forcing the largest evacuation of residents in Alberta's history and the destruction of thousands of homes. An unusually warm May temperature of 32 °C (90 °F), and low humidity at 15%, have contributed to the fire's growth. It has been reported that 88,000 people were successfully evacuated, with no reported fatalities or injuries.

Name: CTP Pilot for Clean Water Access in Indonesia with IROC (FY16)
External_Title__c: Supporting Household Access to Clean Water Using Mobile Wallet Cash Transfers
Summary__c: The American Red Cross will support the Indonesian Red Cross Society (Palang Merah Indonesia, or PMI) as it increases its cash transfer programming capacity. The project will provide support specifically in identifying operational tools and building human resource capacity. This corresponds directly with activities in PMI’s “Cash Preparedness of PMI- Logframe” dated August 18, 2015. PMI’s Disaster Management Department and the American Red Cross Indonesia delegation outlined the activities to be achieved in the three-month implementation period. Further steps and activities to support PMI in their CTP readiness will be planned for the year July 2016-June 2017, pending availability of funding.

Name: CRS Anibong Shelter & Settlements
External_Title__c: CRS Anibong Shelter & Settlements
Sub_Sector__c: Sanitation Facilities;Hygiene Promotion;Urban;Permanent Housing;Progressive / Core Shelter;Safe Construction Training;Safe Shelter Awareness;Secure Land Tenure Support;Shelter Technical Assistance
Summary__c:
The Anibong Shelter and Settlement Project in Tacloban, Leyte, forms the core of American Red Cross’ partnership with Catholic Relief Services (CRS) in the Philippines. The overall budget for the project is USD$12.1 million, with the American Red Cross providing up to USD$4 million.  CRS has confirmed the balance of the required budget through its private resources raised for Typhoon Haiyan.

As a result of American Red Cross support to this project, up to 1,200 families will relocate and build safe, sustainable, resident-governed communities outside of Tacloban City’s No-Build Zones.  CRS’s own resources will enable land purchase, site development, and support to livelihoods and community infrastructure, while ARC support will focus on primarily on the construction of houses and latrines as well as capacity-building in construction, WASH and risk reduction.   CRS will ensure their own resources are also used to support the land ownership process, capacity-building in DRR and other areas related to the operation and maintenance of the new infrastructure. The CRS approach will, in time, result in land-tenure for these households.

Key interventions include: 
  • Capacity-building of home-owners, family members, skilled and unskilled laborers in safe shelter techniques and latrine construction
  • Capacity-building of home-owners and family members in the operation and maintenance of their home and latrine
  • Construction of homes for up to 1,200 families
  • Construction of latrines for up to 1,200 families

Name: FY16 Public Series - Working Under Fire: Providing Health Care During Conflict
Kenya Cholera Outbreak-2015
Summary__c:
Initial signs of a cholera outbreak were found in a surveillance system in Nairobi. Since December 2014, 21 counties have reported cases, with a total of 5,564 cases and 113 deaths. Ministry of Health has a lead management role in outbreak control (management of cases and prevention of new infections), but with challenges in control efforts, the Ministry of Health has formally requested by KRCS's support in scaling up these efforts by increasing trained personnel dedicated to epidemic control in 10 counties. 

Emergency appeal was launched on 9/2.

Name: Mexico Hurricane Patricia-2015
Summary__c:
A potentially catastrophic landfall is expected Friday evening as a very powerful and dangerous Hurricane Patricia moves towards Mexico's Pacific coast. Hurricane Patricia became the most powerful tropical cyclone ever measured in the Western Hemisphere on Friday morning as its maximum sustained winds reached an unprecedented 200 mph (320 kph).

The hurricane is forecast to make landfall in the Mexican state of Jalisco Friday evening as a catastrophic Category 5 hurricane capable of causing widespread destruction. Residents and authorities in Mexico are rushing to prepare for what will likely be the strongest hurricane to ever make landfall on that country's Pacific coastline.

Name: Philippines Typhoon Koppu-2015
Summary__c:
Typhoon Koppu (locally known as Lando) made landfall over the town of Casiguran, Aurora province (around to 350 km northeast of Manila), on Sunday 18 October 2015 as an equivalent of a category 3 cyclone, packing maximum sustained winds of 185 km/h near the centre and gusts of up to 220 km/h. After landfall, the typhoon skirted the northern part of Luzon Island, moving at a slow speed of 5 kph and bringing heavy rains within its 600-kilometre diameter.

Situation Update
  • According to the latest update released by National Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Council (NDRRMC), Koppu left 47 people dead, 83 injured and four missing.
  • In all, a total of 2,733,294 people (630,602 families) were affected across seven regions.
  • Some 89,900 people remain in 311 evacuation centres.
  • Koppu has been described as the most destructive storm to hit Philippines in 2015, with the cost of damage wrought on agriculture and infrastructure estimated at PHP 9.8 billion (CHF 206 million); a total of 103,447 houses were damaged; 15,289 totally and 88,158 partially with 803 schools damaged – 249 totally and 554 partially.

Action by PRC:
  • PRC is in full response mode, and its chapters continue to deliver assistance to affected people. Initial assistance was on saving lives, and in that regard the National Society rescued 728 people who had been trapped by floodwater.
  • As of Sunday 25 October 2015 evening, PRC had provided:
    • Psychosocial support to 10,075 people
    • 10,793 people with hot, ready-to-eat, meals
    • 5,514 families with food packs comprising of rice, noodles and canned items
    • 2,755 families with sleeping items (sleeping mats and blankets)
    • 959 families with mosquito nets
    • 634 families with jerry cans
    • 436 families with tarpaulins
  • Distributions continue, with a substantial part of them covered by the DREF allocation approved on 20 October.
 
IFRC support:
  • IFRC continues to work with PRC on the response at the National Society’s headquarters level, including in moving forward the DREF-supported action; however, the three IFRC delegates who had been deployed to support the National Society in the immediate response, communications and rapid assessments have returned to their respective duty stations as the response is considered within the capacity of PRC chapters to handle.
  • The IFRC Country Delegation is representing the IFRC system (Secretariat and National Societies) in NDRRMC and HCT meetings, together with relevant PRC staff.
 
Looking ahead:
  • Following an analysis of funding scenarios, an international appeal will not be launched for this response. Instead, IFRC will support in promoting PRC’s domestic appeal for partners to support directly to the National Society.

Name: FY16 Public Series - Dismantling Roadblocks to Response for Syria
FY16 Public Series - Out of Focus: Journalism & Modern Warfare
Villa Clinic Support through St. Boniface Foundation (CIF)
External_Title__c: Villa Clinic Support through St. Boniface Foundation
Summary__c:
The 2010 earthquake devastated much of Haiti and damaged the Centre de Santé Communautaire (center) beyond repair. This event forced our staff to move into tents as the communities served by the center needed health services more than ever. Once the Spanish Red Cross discovered this situation, they committed funding to rebuild the center and will break ground in the next few weeks. However, due to budget constraints, the Spanish Red Cross is unable to fund medical equipment. This creates a gap in the St. Boniface Haiti Foundation’s ability to provide the best possible care. Prior to the earthquake, the center had a limited but sufficient supply of equipment. Much of this equipment had been donated by our main hospital or other organizations working Haiti. However, Haiti’s climate and the current working conditions have left much of the equipment inoperable. This proposal will fill the gap required to truly increase the health and well-being of Villa and its surrounding communities, with skilled attendants delivering babies and performing routine and case-specific testing for malaria, HIV and syphilis.  In immediate areas surrounding the center there are 15,000 residents who can directly benefit from its services. Based off previous years of data, the hospital averages 9,000 patient visits, 1,000 of which are patients under 14 years of age. 

SBHF has seen three decades of working in Haiti. We have grown a one-room clinic into a 60- bed facility treating a variety of complex diseases.  SBHF has partnered with various INGOs such as CRS, CMMB and Food For The Poor in addition to multilateral and bilateral organizations such as UNICEF, CDC and USAID. Through these partnerships, SBHF has and is currently implementing large-scale initiatives in infant and maternal health, HIV treatment and prevention and spinal cord rehabilitation. 

The project will run for six months, starting August 1, 2013 and ending January 31, 2014. The target area for this project is Villa and its surrounding communities. Villa is located in the mountain of the Haiti’s southeast department. 

The overall goal of the project is to improve the health and well-being of rural communities in and around the health center. This will be achieved by specific but interconnected objectives:

  1. Increased access to and usage of quality primary health care services
  2. Improved maternal and neonatal birth outcomes
  3. Curb the spread of infectious diseases. 

Principle activities revolve around the purchase, training and maintaining of medical equipment. The amount requested from the American Red Cross for this project is $100,000USD.

Name: FY16 Universal App Program Research with 2583
Summary__c:
Through the Universal App Program, the Global Disaster Preparedness Center (GDPC) and the Global First Aid Reference Center have created a platform to facilitate the adaption and localization of mobile applications (apps) with first aid and hazard information for use in countries across the globe, putting preparedness information directly into people’s hands. As part of the program, the GDPC closely works with Red Cross/Red Crescent (RC/RC) national societies to facilitate the adaptation and localization of app content. The First Aid app is live in 56 countries worldwide with over 40 national societies in the process of development in addition to the Hazard app being live in 15 countries. As of February 2015, the First Aid app has over one million downloads and counting.  The program is well on its way towards its target of releasing the First Aid app in 100 countries by 2016. 
 
The performance of all live apps and related user engagement is tracked using APIs from Google Analytics and App Figures. These sources provide national societies with the ability to monitor numerous data points including: number of downloads, number of new and/or active users, location of users, screen views, average session duration, and mobile device and operating system. To leverage the growing institutional experience and further support the implementation and roll out of First Aid apps there is need for an in-depth study on the success factors of the program.
 
The diversity of countries participating in the program brings with it interest to gain a better understanding of how the apps are being used in the context of national society programming and for the benefit of the end users. In order to assess relative impacts of and experiences with the use of the First Aid app in different countries, it is first relevant to establish what constitutes ‘success’ in the context of the Universal App Program. With a growing number of countries involved in the Universal App program, a comprehensive comparative review of the program elements has to consider different regions, cultural, demographic or socioeconomic aspects as well as determinants of First Aid app use and knowledge transfer of the app content. This research will increase understanding of how apps can support national society service delivery for First Aid and enhance overall preparedness levels of the population. Research findings will contribute to future program developments and support potential app enhancements.

Name: FY16 Resilience in the Americas (IPA/RITA) in Suriname (OD)

The proposed activities build on the success of the Suriname Red Cross’ first aid business and ongoing relationship with the tourism industry.

Name: FY17 Building Community Resilience in Tanzania (Africa)
Sub_Sector__c: First Aid;Health Promotion;Community-Based Disaster Preparedness;Contingency Planning;Micro-mitigation Projects;Savings and Loans
Summary__c:
The goal of this project is to facilitate well-organized, safer and healthier communities with capacities to manage disasters and health risks in the Geita Region in Tanzania, with specific objectives as follows:
 
Objective 1: Capacity of TRCS built to deliver community resilience and disaster management programming
Objective 2: Communities are better organized, prepared and have the capacity to respond effectively to disasters through identifying risks, resources, and integrated responses
Objective 3: Communities are knowledgeable and healthy and have the ability to understand, assess, manage and monitor their resources, risks and behavior

In FY17, the project will maintain the 15 project sites identified as communities established in previous project years. The geographical spread of these communities is as follows; Bukombe District hosts two wards (Igulwa and Uyovu) with nine communities collectively while Mbogwe District hosts one ward (Lulembela) with six communities.  In the 15 communities, the project is expected to directly reach about 23,169 beneficiaries.

FY17 is the end year of this project phase and the project will continue to build communities skills, capacities and facilitate organization for enhanced disaster management, preparedness and response, as well as livelihoods activities addressing natural hazards that affect the Geita region, such as drought. Additional activities will address community-based health and first aid as well as promote proper health, hygiene and sanitation. Building on FY16 efforts, the community disaster contingency funds associations will be rolled out in additional villages. To ensure the sustainability the project work will continue to be delivered through the different existing community forums and structures in collaboration with the government and key influential traditional community leaders. Further, project efforts will also include building capacity of Tanzania Red Cross to deliver community resilience and disaster management programming. Other results expected as a result of FY17 activities include better organized communities with the capacity to act effectively to identify problems, resources, and integrate responses; and communities which are knowledgeable, healthy and have the ability to understand, assess, manage and monitor their resources, risks and behavior. In FY17, the project will conduct a comprehensive external evaluation exercise to evaluate effectiveness.

Name: Europe Population Movement-2015
Summary__c: Greece has experienced a dramatic increase in migrant arrivals at sea in 2015, with numbers of arrivals surpassing those of Italy in recent weeks. The main groups of migrants are arriving via Greece's sea borders with Turkey, with six islands most seriously impacted by this increase - Chios, Crete, Kos, Lesbos, Rhodes, and Samos. Authorities have reported a three-fold increase of arrivals for the same period in 2014, and the numbers in the past weeks continue to increase dramatically. According to available data, more than 90% are coming from countries experiencing war and conflict, principally Syria, Afghanistan, Iraq and Somalia.

Name: RFL-Outreach 2-Colorado Wyoming
Summary__c: The Colorado and Wyoming Region has requested $2,000.00 for outreach to their local refugee and migrant communities. Specifically through this program, they will partner with Red Cross Disaster Cycle Services to ensure that their local community has access to all the services of the Red Cross they may need. In doing so, this project also strengthens ties between lines of service. The chapter requested and is receiving $2,000.00 for this project.

Name: USAID Funded ARC/HRC Project Agreement for PrevSIDA
Sub_Sector__c: HIV/AIDS General;HIV Prevention;HIV Care and Support
Summary__c: In a continuation of the HIV prevention work we have been doing in Haiti since 2004, the American Red Cross, in partnership with the Haitian Red Cross and Population Services International, has joined a consortium of NGO’s funded by USAID working to prevent the sexual transmission of HIV in Haiti. The project will work to identify populations and settings with high-risk behavior and then to improve HIV/AIDS- related knowledge, attitudes, skills and behaviors of the most at-risk populations through individual outreach and community-wide events. The project will also work to strategically link communication and education interventions for sexual prevention of HIV with other health related services and commodities, including targeted condom promotion and availability, as well as livelihoods initiatives for most-at-risk populations and those in settings characterized by high risk behaviors. The project seeks to reach 1,062,680 individuals from high risk youth and adult populations over the course of four and a half years.

Name: Nepal Social Mobilization Measles Campaign 2015/16 - Phase 2, 3, 4
Summary__c:
Social Mobilization for Measles Rubella Campaign 2015/2016
 
Type of CampaignTarget Group Campaign DateTime Frame Anticipated Budget

Overall Context
In its policy document, the comprehensive Multi-Year Plan of Immunization (cMYP) 2011-2016, Nepal has shown its commitment to initiate measles elimination efforts. In 2004/2005 children from 9 months to 15 years were given the measles vaccine through a campaign, Catch up program and in 2008 follow up campaign was conducted where children from 9 months to 5 years were provided with measles vaccine. Similarly, in 2012 a mix dose of measles and rubella was given to children from 9 months to 15 years through a Measles- Rubella Campaign. According to WHO, the number of measles and rubella cases decreased after these campaigns. Therefore, the Government of Nepal (GoN) plans for campaign every 3-4 years. As a result this National Measles- Rubella Campaign, 2015/2016 has been planned. The 1st phase of the campaign in 14 most earthquake affected districts has already been completed and the campaign activities for the remaining 61 districts has been planned.
Ministry of Health and their partners, including Nepal Red Cross Society, are working towards achievements of the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) through improvements in maternal and child health. Nepal Red Cross Society, through participation in social mobilisation activities during mass vaccination campaigns, can assist their governments with achieving the MDG of reducing child mortality.
 
Background
Measles is a highly infectious disease which can cause serious illness, lifelong complications and even death. But it can be easily prevented through vaccination. Clinically, almost similar to measles, rubella infection causes milder disease than measles. In pregnant women, the virus infects the placenta and developing fetus, rubella causes variety if physical defects, collectively known as Congenital Rubella Syndrome (CRS).
Coordinated efforts under National Health Policy contribute towards improving health status and achieving the MDGs. Increase in availability of health facilities and mobilization of health volunteers at grass root levels and promotion of public, private partnerships often contribute to addressing health issues at community level. Alongside this, humanitarian and development partners are also often pivotal in playing a key role in augmenting the Government of Nepal capacity to reduce the burden of measles and rubella.
Such efforts will be invaluable in contributing towards preventable diseases but also in working towards achievements of the millennium development goals (MDGs) through improvements in maternal and child health.
 
Phases of the Measles Rubella Campaign
To ensure adequate supervision from regional and central staff and adequate logistical support for the measles rubella campaign, the campaign will be conducted in different phases
