Proposed activities for NRCS Campaign Coverage
NRCS has been involved in previous immunization campaigns in three key areas, which have included firstly, NRCS local chapters mobilizing its volunteers at vaccination booths, secondly NRCS have carried out social mobilization activities in focused geographical areas and thirdly NRCS have integrated immunization dissemination and motivation messages for routine vaccination in relevant health projects. This year NRCS will be supporting with the printing of IEC materials which will be complimented by social mobilization activities.
 
Overall Campaign Goal
To reduce the morbidity and mortality rate of the target population (children of 6 months to 5 years) by Measles Rubella vaccination
 
Overall Campaign Objectives
  • To immunize all children between 6 months to 5 years of 61 districts of Nepal
  • Increase awareness among people about the immunization campaign to ensure their participation
 
Nepal Red Cross Society Goal: To contribute to the Ministry of Health and Population Measles and Rubella campaign in 61 districts of Nepal through key social mobilization activities
 
Outcome
  • Reached target population with messages through mobilization of volunteers and school students
  • Increased coordination among stakeholders at central and district level
 
Activity Details
Outcome 1: Reach target population with messages through mobilization of volunteers and school students
  1. Printing of IEC materials ( booth banners, street banners)
  2. Organization of rallies in coordination with schools and Junior Red Cross Circles to raise awareness regarding the importance of immunization
  3. Mobilization of Red Cross volunteers for pre campaign activities
Means of verification
  • IEC materials printed and ready for distribution
  • NRCS progress and monitoring reports
  • Observation
Outcome 2: Increase coordination among stakeholders at central and district level
2.1 Identification of program officer at HQ level
2.2 Identification of focal points in each district
2.3 Regular participation at central and district level meetings

Name: FY16 OD Rwanda Red Cross Society Youth Leadership & Governance Project
External_Title__c: Rwanda Red Cross Society Youth Leadership & Governance Project
Summary__c:
The Rwanda Red Cross Society (RRCS) is requesting $ 20,014 from the American Red Cross for the Youth leadership Project, which will contribute to increased national society’s foundations of sustainability, service delivery effectiveness and ultimately lead to greater success in fulfilling RRCS’s mandate.
 
RRCS is committed to building an institution that has a strong youth governance structure for effective and efficient delivery of services to the most vulnerable.  As part of RRCS’s youth and volunteer management services, youth branch committees are set up as key actors for coordination and implementation of RRCS activities.  This project proposal seeks support from the American Red Cross towards building leadership capacity of the national society’s youth governance structure.  In the recent past, the American Red Cross supported Rwanda RC in a nation-wide youth membership mobilization, recruitment and elections of youth leaders in district committees to constitute a national youth governance board.  During the same period, the newly elected youth members were trained in diverse areas related to RRCS youth pillars, RC movement fundamental principles, leadership and management skills. This is to enable them carry out their roles and responsibilities efficiently and effectively and to participate in the affairs of the national society.

Name: 2016 Kenya Social Mobilization Campaign
External_Title__c: Social mobilization for National Measles Campaign 2016
Summary__c:
With financial support from the American Red Cross in the amount of $249,093.00 (USD), the Kenya Red Cross Society (KRCS) will conduct a social mobilization campaign in support of the Feb-March 2016 national measles and rubella vaccination campaign.  The social mobilization campaign will be conducted prior to, during, and after the national camapign which is scheduled for February 29 - March 8, 2016.  Total number of beneficiaries is 1,884,879 children 9 months to 14 years of age.

1,310 volunteers will be recruited and trained in social mobilization techniques.  Volunteers will then be mobilized in three counties Nairobi, Bungoma, and Tharaka Nithi to conduct house to house visits.  They will provide information to caregivers on the importance of vaccinations and will encourage them to bring their children to fixed site health posts to receive them during the national campaign.

Objectives:
•    To support the Ministry of Health at the National and County level carrying out a measles and rubella campaign to vaccinate 95% of 1,984,083 (=1,884,879) children 9 months to 14 years in Red Cross operational areas.

Expected Results:
•    Reducing incidence of measles to <2 cases per 100,000.
•    Increasing SIA coverage of measles to above 95% in targeted districts.

Expected Outputs 
•    Enhanced capacity of Community Health Volunteers and Red Cross volunteers in ACSM (Advocacy Communication and Social Mobilisation) activities.
•    Increased access to the correct information regarding the integrated measles/rubella campaign to all targeted households and parents/caretakers.
•    Visited parents/caretakers take eligible children to receive measles/rubella vaccination and other integrated measles/rubella services.
•    Enhanced coordination and oversight in the campaign implementation.

Name: Haitian Red Cross Post Construction with USAID (CUCD)

Name: Myanmar SLNSP in Tanintharyi with LIFT
Summary__c:
The American Red Cross (ARC) in partnership with Myanmar Red Cross Society (MRCS) and Australian Red Cross proposes a multi-sector project, which will contribute to sustainably improving the inc1/omes, nutrition and resilience of displaced persons, including internal displaced persons (IDP) and returning refugees, and host communities, while enabling an environment of trust building, inclusion and empowerment of vulnerable groups.

The project will cover two townships in Tanintharyi region targeting 50 villages. The project will apply a do-no-harm approach advocating for and supporting the fulfilment of health, economic and social protection needs and rights of these populations. It will build on Red Cross’ experience of implementing similar projects in the region, and will address components 4 (off-farm employment), component 5 (nutrition) and 6 (social protection) of the LIFT Uplands Programme Framework.

Name: Livelihood Opportunities for Youth through IDEJEN (YOUTH)
External_Title__c: Livelihood Opportunities for Youth through IDEJEN
Summary__c: This project is designed to improve the economic status and resilience of 240 young people and their families living in deprived areas of Cité Soleil and Martissant. Thanks to ARC’s contribution, the project will provide educational and employment opportunities to 240 vulnerable out of school in Cité Soleil and Martissant to ensure their socio–economic reintegration.  The objectives of the project will be : a) Provide non formal basic education, life skills education and technical skills to a group of 240 marginalized out-of-school youth in two (2) Port-au-Prince slums areas during a six month period; b) Reinforce the capacity of 4 Community based organizations located in two slum areas to address programming needs of out-of-school youth in vulnerable situations; c) Provide accompaniment support to 240 out of school youth during a period of six (6) months after the training period in other to find economic opportunities; d) Advocate and develop partnership with the public and private sector to provide economic opportunities to the graduated youth and also to set a task force which could address vulnerable and impoverished youth situation in the rebuilding process of Haiti.

Name: FY13-15 Resilience in the Americas (IPA/RITA) Program
Summary__c: Every year in the Americas more and more people are living in conditions of vulnerability to natural hazards and climate change. To help reduce disaster risk and enhance community resilience in the region, the American Red Cross is working with Red Cross partners in the Bahamas, Belize, Colombia, Costa Rica, Ecuador, El Salvador, Guyana, Nicaragua, Panama and Peru to address local hazards and vulnerabilities in over100 disaster-prone communities. This initiative began with a Red Cross-led mapping and assessment process where communities themselves identified the most significant risks they face and the actions they can take to mitigate them. Some examples of community interventions include strengthening water and sanitation systems, delivering key messages about health promotion and disease prevention, and training and equipping community members with first aid skills and supplies. In addition to addressing specific hazards, another key program component is working with communities so they are able to self-organize and self-manage advocacy or education efforts that will help them be better prepared for future disasters.  The American Red Cross is also helping strengthen the capacity of Red Cross partners in the region to deliver services to communities. This program is being implemented in Bahamas, Belize, Colombia, Costa Rica, Ecuador, El Salvador, Guyana, Nicaragua, Panama and Peru, targeting more than 100 communities.

Name: Saving Lives in the Caribbean (SLIC) Program (FY12-FY15)
Summary__c: The ARC has been active in the Caribbean Region for a number of years working alongside Red Cross partners to implement resilience, health, and preparedness programs; risk reduction initiatives; and disaster response and recovery efforts. This project is a new initiative under way to introduce new technologies for communicating with the public about disaster risk in the Caribbean for preparedness, early warning, and response.  It aims to save lives and protect livelihoods and assets, increasing the impact of humanitarian efforts through low-cost means of reaching scale, and informing and empowering community decision-making on disaster management.  This 12-month regional initiative is funded by the United States Agency for International Development's Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance (OFDA).

Name: FY13-15 Resilience in the Americas (IPA/RITA) in Bahamas
FY13-15 Resilience in the Americas (IPA/RITA) in Ecuador
Summary__c:
The present extensión of RITA Project for the fiscal year 2015 seeks to continue contributing to improve people’s life quality standards in five urban communities in Huaquillas Canton. Communities are located near the International Channel and at the south limits with the City Aguas Verdes in Peru. The communities to be attended are Choferes Sportman, 8 de Setiembre, Los Ceibos, Los Vergeles and Brisas del Sur.  
Families are prone to be affected during the Winter time by overflows of the International Channel. Furthermore, there are other type of risks associated with fuel handling and other risks to health, such as contagion of diseases caused by presence of stagnant water, garbage, poorly maintained water channels, limited sewage system and drinking water supply, and also health problems as consequence of the vulnerabilities mentioned before as Dengue, Malaria, Acute Diarrheal Diseases, which present more in children under 5 years old. To this situation is added delinquency problems, lack of security and community organization, and increase of the number of pregnancy in adolescents.     

It must be said that all communities in Huaquillas possess a governmental structure supported by the Autonomous Descentralized Government of Huaquillas Canton and a significant organization level capable to create high-impact changes. The Canton authorities have declared their intention to contribute to actions allowing for an improvement of the population health.  
For this reason, through the RITA Project, we want to contribute to creating resilience of communities by strengthening their organization, training, improvements in the physical environment and advocacy with the stakeholders of the Canton (local government and other instances are included). For the above mentioned reason, it has been deemed very important to consolidate the organization of communities through risk management teams and health committees, trained in risk prevention, preparation of community plans, healthy habits, basic first aid, drinking water management, environmental sanitation, sexual and reproductive rights, pacific coexistence.

Name: BRACES Concept Note for USAID/OFDA
External_Title__c: Building Resilient African Communities
Summary__c:
Every year, communities across southern Africa experience disasters intensified by climate change. The changing climate has resulted in unpredictable weather patterns, including increased intensity of rainstorms, prolonged dry spells and warmer temperatures. These changes increase the risk of flooding, crop failure, shelter damage, livestock death, soil erosion and increased prevalence of vector-borne disease. Combined with existing health, social and economic conditions, communities have a weakened capacity to respond to the shocks of climate change.

With support from USAID/OFDA, the American Red Cross (ARC) has gained extensive experience in community based disaster risk reduction programming across the globe. That experience has helped inform our Building Resilient African Communities (BRACES) program, which since 2011 has used proven resilience programming techniques and lessons learned adapted to the southern African context. BRACES is a multi-year program designed to increase the resilience of communities in southern Africa. The approach integrates key interventions in other sectors – including shelter and water, sanitation and health – to provide a more holistic approach to disaster risk management that is more responsive to community-level risks.

Name: FY17 Organizational Development (OD) in Kazakhstan
External_Title__c: Fundraising Capacity Building in Kazakh Red Crescent Society
Summary__c:
The Kazakh Red Crescent Society (KRCS) requests $ 45,000 for capacity building of resource mobilization and implementation of fundraising tools in practice in order to achieve the objectives of the resource mobilization strategy in the domestic market and increase the Society's capacity in resource mobilization.
 
During the period of 2015-2016, the Resource Mobilization Department of Kazakh Red Crescent Society was established. The director of the department and 4 fundraising specialists were hired:
  1. Corporate Fundraising Specialist;
  2. Governmental Fundraising Specialist;
  3. Community Fundraising Specialist;
  4. Community Fundraising Specialist’s Assistant, who is responsible for the accounting of the KRC’s members and volunteers based on the data distribution and administration of the website.
 
Over the past year, the team has done a big preparation work: updated the resource mobilization strategy for the 2016-2018 years, developed internal regulations on donation boxes, membership cards and society’s coupons. Developed and tested a new membership system, the main feature of which is - transparency, feedback and larger coverage of attraction to potential members. The new membership system will also allow the Society to attract more funds into the organization's gross revenue from membership fees.
 
The new website was developed, along with the development of KRC’s members, volunteers and partners accounting system. Functionality of the new site is also aimed at raising funds for the Society; the focus of it is to collect online donations and attract new members and volunteers. The team has started cooperation with the corporate sector, signed partnership agreements with several companies. Society has become a full member of the American Chamber of Commerce. A number of presentations for the corporate sector, the public sector and the general population were developed. First community fundraising campaigns were held.
 
Thus, new basic fundraising tools were developed, which are needed to be inserted in practice. The society needs funds in order to implement the tools in practice properly.
 
Team has decided, that one of the most potentially viable sector is fundraising among the community. Research has showed that people are more willing to donate during emergencies, and are more willing to donate for the charity campaigns.  Therefore, it is essential that as many people as possible will learn about our new membership program and the opportunity to donate to the Red Crescent, both in time of peace, by supporting various charitable campaigns, and in the case of emergencies. Red Crescent plans to increase donations from the population by attracting new members to the society, as well as involving an increased number of people in charitable activities, creating different motivational tools and increasing their presence on the streets and in the online space.
 
In addition, the Society needs the internal regulations’ analysis and bring them in line with new fundraising procedures and programs, in order to ensure that the resource mobilization activities comply with the laws of the Republic of Kazakhstan and provide financial transparency for donors and partners. This procedure by itself will require the assistance of professional lawyers. 

The Director of the Resource Mobilization Department will coordinate all resource mobilization activities.

Name: Salary Support Grant Letter for HRC

Summary__c:
In 2013 and 2014 the Haitian Red Cross (HRC) will undergo financial audits for 2011 and  prepare for the 2012 and 2013 audits, as well as undertake a major institutional assessment. Based on HRC’s formal request to ARC to provide interim financial support to ensure business continuity of the HRC’s Finance, Human Resources and Internal Audit Departments in preparation of these major processes, ARC has agreed to pay for the salaries and associated benefits of key Finance, Human Resources and Internal Audit staff.  

This proposal is part of the overarching OD efforts being supported by ARC under AP 2630.

Name: Carrefour Sustainable Income Project through Grace Intl (CIF)
External_Title__c: Haiti Empowerment Program – Carrefour Sustainable Income Project
Summary__c: This program seeks to increase the income of growing small business (GSBs) for residents of Carrefour through the holistic approach of education, training, guidance, and support.  A criteria of the 120 program participants in Carrefour is to achieve economic independence through sustainable income through the growth and formalization of mostly small growing production-based enterprises with a consistent annual income of 50,000HTG to 80,000HTG per program participant.  This one-year program will emphasize business fundamentals and personal finance, setting expectations for income sustainability and income creation while providing a “global village” support system for their financial counselor/manager and training courses.  A structure of business development courses, soft skills and customer service courses, business/financial counseling, management, financing, and advising empowers the program participants to achieve economic independence.  Women entrepreneurs will also be advised by women entrepreneurs weekly within a group as an extra layer of support to discuss and be trained on issues specifically for women entrepreneurs such as managing family and work.

Name: FY16 Restoring Family Links Core Program
Summary__c: American Red Cross caseworkers at local chapters around the U.S. help families locate missing relatives by working with our partners— the International Committee of the Red Cross and Red Crescent organiza­tions in nearly every country around the world. Once a family member is found, the Red Cross helps them reconnect. Messages or phone calls can be very brief, but the three short words “I am alive” may be all that is needed to ease the minds of distraught relatives half a world away. Red Cross messages or phone calls can also be exchanged between families and their loved ones in refugee camps and detention centers to allow them to keep in contact and share family news. This past year, the American Red Cross helped reconnect thousands of families—bridging years of separation to reconnect people in the U.S. and their families around the world.

Name: FY16 Restoring Family Links ARCT Outreach & Training (RFL)
External_Title__c: Restoring Family Links
Summary__c:
The purpose of this grant is to support the Restoring Family Links (RFL) program in serving more clients through increasing awareness of Red Cross services to reconnect families separated internationally, especially in immigrant and refugee communities; enhancing client access to Restoring Family Links services, and improving service quality through training of caseworkers in the highest demand areas. In FY15-17, the Restoring Family Links program aims to serve more families that are separated from loved ones, provide quality casework services and eliminate barriers to accessing services.
 In FY14, the Anne Ray Charitable Trust supported Restoring Family Links outreach and training efforts. The grant supported three staff positions, training of additional casework instructors and provision of outreach grants to local regions to raise community awareness. This support enhanced training capacity so that courses were regularly available in the top 20 American Red Cross regions and led to higher awareness and demand for services. 
 To ensure that high quality service is provided to families, instructor trainings will continue to ensure that guidance, tools and courses are available to caseworkers in the 20 regions with the highest Restoring Family Links case volume. Many refugee and immigrant families, as well as agencies and community groups that serve them, are unaware of Red Cross Restoring Family Links services. Direct outreach to communities, agencies, and organizations will focus on areas with large refugee and immigrant populations so that potential beneficiaries know about these services. Outreach mini-grants will be provided to regions to support local community engagement. In FY15, the Red Cross will also pilot a web form to make it easier for clients to learn about and utilize the program so that more families can be served.
The training and outreach initiatives for this three year proposal have low risk. The American Red Cross employs many training programs for its mainly volunteer workforce and the training modalities utilized by the RFL program are based on best practices from other Red Cross programs. The main challenges for training are maintaining and instructor pool in the top 20 highest demand regions which can change based on program demands as well as staff and volunteer turn-over. To address this challenge new instructor trainings and refresher trainings will be offered. For RFL caseworkers who do not have an instructor-led course readily available to them, on-demand online training modules are available and will be updated to meet caseworker needs.  For the outreach initiatives, the chapter grant program is now well-established, lessons learned have been collected and chapters are utilizing the grants in productive and creative ways. The pilot projects have inherent risk because they involve new activities. The structure and review of the pilot projects mitigates any high risk and the projects are flexible so that lessons can be applied quickly to adjust the programs to meet community needs. The pilot phone call projects are based on a similar program by the Mexican Red Cross where phone calls are offered to migrants at Red Cross health clinics. Employing best practices from the Mexican Red Cross program also helps to mitigate risk.  A new activity in this proposal is initiation of a web inquiry system so that potential RFL clients can have easier access to program information. It is designed as a pilot in the first year so that information on demand can be collected and case processes can be developed based on client needs. A moderate risk for the RFL program in general is the low capacity of the chapter network to provide RFL services and conduct outreach. This three-year grant proposal to ARCT requesting support for caseworker training and outreach initiatives directly addresses this ongoing challenge of the organization.

Name: FY15 OD in Ecuador for Strategic Plan Support

The Ecuadorian Red Cross (ERC) is seeking support for the development of their 2015 - 2019 National Society Strategic Plan:

  2. Preparation & Conceptualization (November  2014) - 
  3. Production / Formulation of New Strategic Plan (December - January 2014)

Bangladesh Cyclone Komen-2015
Summary__c: The monsoon depression over the northeast Bay of Bengal and the Bangladesh coast intensified into Cyclone Komen on Wednesday, 29 July 2015, causing further downpours in regions already affected by recent storms, flash floods and landslides which had started at the end of June 2015. Since mid-July, IFRC has been monitoring the situation and working closely with BDRCS in responding to the immediate needs of the affected communities. Cyclone Komen made landfall along the coast of south-eastern Bangladesh between the Hatiya and Sandwip islands on 30 July, weakening as it moved slightly towards the northeast. Cox’s Bazar, Chittagong, Bandarban, Noakhali, Feni and Bhola1 districts were significantly affected. At least 7 people (2 of them children) were reported dead, 38 missing, and a number injured due to the cyclone. Thousands of houses were flattened and trees uprooted. Many houses went under water, power supplies were disrupted, and communication systems ceased to operate in some places. Crops were damaged and shrimp projects flooded.

Name: HRC Response to Migrant Deportation – Phase I (QAF)
External_Title__c: Response to Dominican Republic Deportation of Haitians through Haitian Red Cross
Summary__c:
In 2015, Haiti continued to experience a huge increase of migrant arrivals in its territory on its border with Dominican Republic. Authorities are reporting at least 3,000 persons per week increase in arrivals in Haiti this month compared to the same period in 2014.
 
The situation of irregular migration from Haiti is particularly problematic in the Caribbean region. According to the International Organization for Migration (IOM), the three main Caribbean countries attracting the most Haitian migrants are Turkey and Caicos Islands, the Bahamas and the Dominican Republic. The Turkish and Caicos Islands and the Bahamas represent both final destinations, as well as transit country for migrants seeking to enter the US territory. The main reason of destination to these countries is mainly due to the limited nature of border controls, the high demand for unskilled labour, particularly in the fields of construction and tourism, or access to medical care (Dominican law provides free health care).
The majority of these migratory movements are illegal, often through networks of traffickers, and migrants are particularly at risk when crossing borders through dealers or during travel by sea. According to the Coast Guard, 3,000 people were intercepted at sea and returned each month in Haiti. For example, April 9, 2015, in the town of Borgne northwestern department, boat heading towards the coast, resulting in the death of 17 people and the disappearance of 19, including 7 children, 12 people have been rescued.
 
In 2013, the Constitutional Court of the Dominican Republic issued the Judgment "TC 168/13" resulting in withdrawal of nationality from a population estimated at 400,000 people, including 300,000 of Haitian origin. On 22 May 2014 the Dominican Congress passed legislation establishing a registration procedure and regularization of persons of foreign origin born in the Dominican Republic between 1929 and 2007 or "Ley de Régimen Especial y Naturalización 169-14." This law established two distinct groups:
 
- Group A: consisting of 24,000 heads of families with members of their families (a total estimated 100,000 people) were born in the Dominican Republic and registered at the civil registry office;
 
- Group B: 55,000 heads of families with members of their families (200,000 people) were born in the Dominican Republic and have not been registered at the civil registry office.
 
During his speech on the State of the Nation on 27 February, President Medina of the Dominican Republic said that the registration phase ended on 1 February 2015 and allowed the recording of 8755 persons belonging to Group B This includes 40% of the files that were deemed admissible for regularization and 60% rejected because of deficiencies in the submitted files (no information was provided about the Group A).
 
The deadline for the regularization process was established at 17 June 2015 and that there would be no extension of the process and that all persons who have not been regularized to June 17 would be considered illegal migrants and exposed to deportation proceedings.
 
In parallel with the above two groups, a third category is made up of an estimated population of more than 300,000 undocumented Haitian migrants, 250,000 of them would not have civil documentation.

Name: Economic Strengthening and Livelihoods Improvement in NW Haiti through PADF
External_Title__c: Economic Strengthening though the Pan American Development Foundation
Summary__c:
The project’s goals are to (1) enhance food security and (2) contribute to more sustainable and resilient livelihoods for rural women and men in the Northwest Department. This goal will be achieved through the following objectives:
  • Increase food availability for sale and for consumption by sustainably improving water access, offering, newer horticultural varietals, introducing new technologies and approaches to increase yields, as well as disaster‐resilient crop protection measures;
  • Diversify men’s and women’s on‐ and off‐farm income generation activities through providing small-scale productive infrastructure and equipment thereby creating opportunities to add value to current production as well as creating ancillary activities to generate revenue; and
  • Increase knowledge of good nutrition, particularly for women and small children, by integrating nutrition education into training for production and processing activities, and via specific interventions.

FY17 Tanzania Integrated HIV and AIDS (Health)
External_Title__c: Tanzania Integrated HIV and AIDS Project
Summary__c: The American Red Cross and the Tanzania Red Cross launched the Tanzania Integrated HIV & AIDS Project in May 2009. In FY17 project will target districts – Bukombe and Mbogwe – in Geita Region, Tanzania. It aims to reduce HIV associated morbidity and mortality, and improve the quality of life of the chronically ill, including people living with HIV and vulnerable children. The project addresses the effects of HIV in a comprehensive, holistic manner while working to strengthen the ability of the Tanzania Red Cross Society to implement and sustain HIV programming. The Tanzanian National AIDS Control Program recognizes Geita region as a priority site for HIV interventions. The project’s goal is achieved through the following objectives: to improve the quality of life of the chronically ill, including PLHIV, through provision of home-based care and support; to improve the quality of life of OVCs by increasing capacity of communities, families and OVCs; to promote HIV prevention by improving related knowledge, attitudes, skills and behaviors of youth in the community, and to strengthen capacity of TRCS, Ministry of Health, Community Development, Gender, Seniors and Children and Tanzanian communities to implement HIV/AIDS programming.

Name: IFRC Europe Zone Eurasia NS Resource Mobilization Capacity Building Initiative
Summary__c:
Fundraising needs good investment to build a sound and committed donor base domestically.  National Societies in Eastern Europe, Central Asia and South Caucasus (Eurasia subregion) for years had a reliable funding source, first from the Soviet government, and then from the International RC/RC Movement.  Government funding for these NS is by and large unknown and untapped, and the International Movement’s funding is on a steady decline. Many National Societies find themselves struggling to ensure they have enough resources to fulfil their missions. 

Philanthropic giving is a comparatively new and poorly understood concept in the region, but it is slowly developing. The level of competition is relatively low, with very few organisations approaching the public to give. The market in the region, coupled with existing rich expertise and experience in the Movement as far as fundraising is concerned, have many ingredients for the RC/RC Societies to very quickly become market leaders in their countries if they are prepared to invest the time and resources in developing their fundraising outreach and get support and encouragement, along with exposure to skills and information, from their partners.

To address this situation, the IFRC Europe Zone's Organisational Development unit has embarked on a Capacity Building in Resource Mobilisation project, which aims to contribute to the increased capacity of National Societies in the region to maximise domestic funding opportunities and growth. This will be achieved through provision of targeted, comprehensive and longer-term technical and financial support to five National Societies per annum that will express strong willingness and commitment to significantly grow their income.  It is expected that as a result of this support they will use evidence-based decision making in resource mobilization (RM), and will reach established RM performance targets. In addition to the targeted support, the project will ensure that all National Societies in the region receive and share resource mobilisation expertise, knowledge and innovations on a regular basis, including through the fundraisers’ networks that will be established in 2015. 

As an element of this project, with support from PNS including Swiss, British Red Cross, ICRC, and the American Red Cross, an initial meeting of National Society staff engaged in fundraising will be held in Budapest from 25 to 27 November 2014 at a total cost of CHF 40,000.  In alignment with current ARC plans to streamline engagement with National Societies in Eurasia subregion, ARC staff have determined that support for Resource Mobilization efforts and capacity building in this area will constitute a key element of the more limited future support that can be provided to operating National Societies in the region, while also capitalizing on successful efforts of the IFRC Europe Zone and working to build sustainability for the NS with which ARC has engaged over a number of years.  In particular for Kazakhstan Red Crescent and Kyrgyzstan Red Crescent, which have received project-based Organizational Development support from ARC, and Turkmenistan Red Crescent, which has also received ARC support for Disaster Preparedness and shorter-term OD initiatives, the successful organization and completion of the Fundraisers' Meeting in Budapest, and follow-on activities, will be an important step in achieving lasting and sustainable improvements.

Name: FY16 IFRC Reg Office Europe Resource Mobilization Capacity Building Initiative
Summary__c:
The first fundraising meeting in Russian language was held in Budapest in November 2014 and was attended by 28 participants from 15 National Societies. The second fundraising meeting was held in Almaty, Kazakhstan, in June 2015 and saw participation of 42 people, including from 16 National Societies of Eastern and Southern Europe, Central Asia and South Caucasus.
The cross cutting theme of the second Fundraising Meeting focused on building longer-term and trusting relations with donors, in particular with individual donors. Sessions and discussions during all three days of the meeting were delving into the importance of developing and establishing a proper fundraising system that will aim to bring in regular un-earmarked income on a monthly basis, year on year.
One of the important highlights of both, the first and the second fundraising meetings, was participation of Senior Management of many National Societies. To ensure longer-term commitment of donors and their readiness to make larger contributions a few fundamentals need to be in place, and it is for the leaders of National Societies to prioritise and develop these: 
  • The first is a sound fundraising strategy for a few years ahead highlighting priority income streams, approaches, activities and resources needed to develop these income streams, how the income pattern will look like year on year from different income streams and how our costs will be covered.
  • The second, and often neglected area – is a need to have a dedicated, motivated and professional team. Fundraising will never become a system that brings good and regular income every month if no investments into having a strong fundraising team are made.
  • The third is the need for infrastructure, for example a sound data base, a good web-site, varied payment mechanisms appropriate for different donors etc.
All participants requested that such event becomes a regular occasion.
The evaluation of the meeting showed a continued need to strengthen membership schemes and to upgrade members to donors, to harness the power of corporate sector for fundraising, for resources and expertise and for contacts and networks, and to strengthen relations with Grant Making organisations and foundations.
Practical information                                                       
The third combined fundraising and communication meeting will take place from 22nd to 24th of June 2016 in Budapest. The participants will arrive one day before and will depart one day after the event.
All fifteen National Societies from former Soviet Union will be invited to attend the event. The available funding will cover two participants from each National Society: a fundraiser and a communications professional or people who are expected to do fundraising in their National Society.
The meeting will also bring external speakers and trainers both within and outside the Movement.
Professional simultaneous translation will be ensured during the meeting.

Name: FY16 Global Disaster Preparedness Center (GDPC) Program with ARCT
External_Title__c: Global Disaster Preparedness Center

Name: Mobile Communication for Preparedness in Southeast Asia with OFDA
External_Title__c: Technology for Preparedness in Southeast Asia
Summary__c: The Global Disaster Preparedness Center (GDPC) and American Red Cross are partnering with Red Cross national societies in Southeast Asia to pilot using mobile technologies, including interactive applications (apps) and SMS messaging, to enhance disaster preparedness in the region. By introducing interactive hazard preparedness apps in the region, the GDPC and American Red Cross will help partners increase public access to preparedness information and improve decision-making towards safety and resilience. The GDPC will provide Red Cross partners access to a web-based platform where they can adapt and contextualize the American Red Cross hurricane/flood app for release in their own country. The GDPC will also offer technical guidance throughout the app development process, sharing resources for translation and marketing for the apps, among others. This 18-month project is funded by the United States Agency for International Development’s Office of U.S. Foreign Disaster Assistance (OFDA).

Name: FY17 Global Disaster Preparedness Center (GDPC) Program with ARCT
Women Integration and Training Program
Summary__c:
A $114,000 USD Grant Letter to German Red Cross (GRC) because it was negotiated that they would receive 6% of the funds raised by the World of Warcraft (WoW) fundraising initiative.  WoW raised $1.9 million USD, 6% of that is $114,000 USD.  

GRC will use these funds to support its WIN (Women Integration and Training) project which supports disadvantaged women in West Point, Monrovia Liberia that have been highly affected by the Ebola Virus Disease.  The project key components include:
1) Pyschosocial Support
2) Adult Literacy
3) Skills Training
4) Community Sensitization/Awareness
5) Business Management
6) Maternal Child Care
7) School Awareness 

Direct Beneficiaries include 200 women and girls aged15-45 years. Indirect Beneficiaries include 25,000 people, such as spouses, children of direct beneficiaries.

Name: LAMIKA Program
External_Title__c: Integrated Neighborhood Reconstruction and Recovery Program
Sub_Sector__c: Health Promotion;Medical Care;Sanitation Facilities;Vocational Training;First Responder Training;Savings and Loans;Business Training;Early Warning Early Action;Community Mobilization;Complaints and Feedback Mechanisms;Education and Awareness;Community Mapping;Sexual and Reproductive Health;Microfinance;Repair / Retrofitting;Rubble / Debris Removal
Summary__c: Following the January 2010 earthquake, Haiti has experienced tremendous challenges in its recovery, especially in hilly and densely populated urban neighborhoods. In order to allow those affected by the earthquake to return to more secure homes, it is necessary to address their diverse needs more effectively and efficiently, through an integrated approach that encompasses land and housing, water and sanitation, health, disaster risk reduction and livelihoods interventions. Phase I of LAMIKA has focused on conducting participatory assessment and design activities in the target area of Campeche, a neighborhood in Carrefour Feuilles, Port au Prince. Over the next three years, the American Red Cross will implement LAMIKA with the goal of enhancing community and household resiliency while providing safer, healthier and more secure living conditions.  LAMIKA will contribute to a more hazard resistant Port au Prince and a better future for Haiti. LAMIKA will conduct activities in social empowerment, economic strengthening and physical renewal to address needs across sectors.  Likewise, activities will be designed to respond to needs at various scales, from the individual household to the municipal and national level.  The overall implementation strategy will be driven by a community-based, participatory approach. This project expects to reach an estimated 45,000 people with a range of services. The American Red Cross is coordinating with a number of government and humanitarian partners to achieve and expand this vision.

Name: RFL-Outreach-Central and South IL
Summary__c: This Restoring Family Links mini-grant will increase the outreach capacity for the Central and Southern Illinois Region, enhancing their ability to provide reconnecting families services to refugee and migrant communities in their area.

Name: Micronesia Cyclone Maysak-2015
Summary__c: Typhoon Maysak moved through the Federated States of Micronesia beginning on the 29 of March as a super typhoon, bringing damaging winds and torrential rainfall to the archipelago that has caused widespread damage to houses, infrastructure, crops and water sources. In Chuuk state, five deaths have been confirmed more than 6,000 people were displaced in shelters or living with relatives. In Yap state, where the storm made landfall, the majority of homes were destroyed and there is widespread damage to crops and infrastructure as well as possible contamination of food and water sources.  Assessments are ongoing, but priority needs include food and essential household items, safe water, emergency shelter, health and hygiene.

Name: RCRC Research and Evidence Based Workshop
Summary__c:
Throughout the Red Cross Red Crescent (RCRC) network and the wider humanitarian community there is an increasing recognition of the need and value of collecting and producing evidence to support and enhance humanitarian work across all sectors. Conducting research is an important part of building an evidence base and can make a number of valuable contributions to humanitarian work, including more reliable knowledge about what works and what doesn’t work and why. This can lead to more efficient aid, an increase in impact, heightened credibility of humanitarian work, more accountability and an understanding of future trends.

In 2012 the IFRC commissioned a study to compile and assess the existing experiences with research and the need to build capacities within the RCRC network. More recently, this has been complemented by an analysis of research needs and capacities in the IFRC and National Societies. These assessments highlight a great diversity of engagement in research activities across the IFRC and National Societies; however, there is a lack of collaboration and information exchange on research activities. Key findings of the assessments include the need to build a common vision for and understanding of research and evidence across the network and a demand for enhanced knowledge and information sharing to learn from otherwise dispersed research activities.

There are growing institutional experiences with research within the RCRC network but much remains to be done to build on collaboration and information exchange between different actors. As a resource to the RCRC network the Global Disaster Preparedness Center (GDPC) is supporting research activities and collaboration efforts to support RCRC’s work. Jointly with IFRC’s Learning and Research Department, and together with a diverse group of National Society, IFRC secretariat and Zone representatives, the Center seeks to initiate a workshop to focus and synthesize the discussion on research understanding and collaboration within the RCRC network. The RCRC workshop on research and evidence based work is planned to take place in Geneva, Switzerland, May 19 - 20, 2015.

Name: International Seminar on Urban DRR and Management
Summary__c:
Program/Project Specifics:
To contribute to global efforts in reducing risk and negative consequences of disasters in cities, the IFRC and the Iranian Red Crescent are organizing: “International Seminar on Urban Disaster Risk Reduction and Management” from 4-7 May 2015 in Tehran, Iran.

GDPC intends to support the participation of 4 National Societies in this seminar, pending OFAC approval. 

  1. Bangladesh Red Crescent Society
  2. Haiti Red Cross
  3. Mexico Red Cross
  4. Myanmar Red Cross Society


Background:
The International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement, through its National Societies, has always been present in urban areas. However, their capacity and action were relatively more effective in rural areas and not in complex urban contexts. As a response to the growing need in the area of urban disaster risk reduction and management, the IFRC and the Iranian Red Crescent Society agreed to cooperate on a Partnership for Urban Disaster Risk Reduction and Management to support Red Cross and Red Crescent programmes and activities in this area. This programme will be implemented in the timeframe May 2013 to April 2015.

A number of other initiatives which were carried out by the Federation and National Societies confirmed the gaps in our understanding of urban risk context and endorsed the need for a Federation global position and strategy on urban disaster risk reduction as well as the necessity for developing specific capacity of National Societies for effective engagement in urban risk reduction and management. At regional level and with the support of a number of PNSs, practical steps toward addressing urban disaster risk reduction and management were taken.

Name: FY15 OD in South Africa for Leadership Support
Summary__c: Support to the SARCS for leadership and financial management strengthening.

Name: FY15 OD Africa Executive Humanitarian Leadership Program Support
Summary__c: With focus on effective leadership in Africa, delivering quality outputs on time, putting the right systems and practices in place and achieving targets are all crucial skills required of those leading responses to complex emergencies and disaster management programmes such as with Red Crescent and Red Crescent movement. If anyone has ever wondered about what kind of staffing structure to use on a new project, how to motivate their staff/teams, or how to navigate issues and mediate difficult situations, there has been no adequate interventions implemented focusing on Africa Red Cross and Red Crescent national societies to strengthen the leadership in respective countries. In light of this, there is a need to strengthen learning about leadership in a humanitarian context and create opportunities to discover what suits each national society on their style and their own organisations. It is therefore imperative to continually carry out organizational environment scanning to identify leadership practices, capacities that exist and crucial developmental needs. It is also envisaged that by developing a systematic evaluation framework of EHLP, this will provide an opportunity to gauge the significant impact both at individual and organizational levels. Gaps identified and recommendations made coupled by the findings of planned assessment will be useful to inform the future design, delivery and content of the training programme.

Name: Nepal Earthquake Emergency Response Program with OFDA
Summary__c:
On April 25th, a 7.8 magnitude earthquake struck 48 miles northwest of Kathmandu, Nepal, affecting an estimated 8 million people across 41 districts in Nepal’s West and Central Regions.  Of these 41 districts, 14 have been identified as highly affected.  Preliminary assessments found the districts of Nuwakot and Rasuwa—in the Central Region—to be among the most severely impacted, with an estimated 80–90 percent of houses damaged or destroyed.  Many areas of Nuwakot and Rasuwa are only accessible on foot and have thus received limited assistance to date, compounding the urgency to respond
 
After the earthquake struck, the Nepal Red Cross—which has branches in all 75 districts of Nepal—immediately deployed its national- and district-level disaster response teams to the most-affected districts, including Nuwakot and Rasuwa.  In addition, the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC), the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) and over 30 national Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies have mobilized for the response.  Nepal Red Cross teams are conducting assessments in all affected areas, as well as conducting distributions to provide shelter, drinking water and food to earthquake-affected populations. Rapid assessments have found that shelter materials, particularly tarps and plastic sheeting, are priority needs.   There is a limited stock of water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) kits and shelter materials in country; however it is insufficient to meet the needs of those displaced by the earthquake. 
 
In response, the American Red Cross, in collaboration with its local partner the Nepal Red Cross Society (NRCS), proposes to save lives and alleviate the suffering of earthquake-affected populations in 17 Village Development Committees (VDCs) of Rasuwa and Nuwakot districts by providing emergency shelter materials, safe drinking water and improved sanitation options.  The American Red Cross and the NRCS request $534,920 for emergency shelter, non-food items (NFI) and WASH activities for a three-month period, as well as plastic sheeting from USAID stocks for distribution in remote VDCs of Rasuwa and Nuwakot districts.

Name: Investing in Human Capital in Martissant and Cité Soleil through HELP (Youth)
External_Title__c: Investing in Human Capital in Martissant and Cité Soleil through HELP
Summary__c:
The Haitian Education & Leadership Program (HELP) is a comprehensive university scholarship program operating in Haiti for 18 years. HELP has 167 students enrolled across five universities in Port-au-Prince. As part of their scholarship, HELP students receive a package of services and support which includes a mandatory four-year Citizenship & Leadership (C&L) curriculum focused on the qualities of an effective leader, how to capitalize on a community’s resources, and how to bring about positive change. A key component of HELP’s C&L program is service projects. Introduced in 2011, HELP students now participate in one of seven service projects ranging from waste management and neighborhood clean-up, to literacy and tutoring programs.

The overall purpose of this project is to invest in the human capital that already exists in the youth of Cité Soleil and Martissant. Through the four activities proposed, HELP will contribute to both of ARC’s Youth Program Objectives. Academic excellence and engagement is encouraged on multiple levels and operates in a symbiotic relationship of beneficiaries who contribute to the output. Through scholarships, youth from the target areas of Martissant and Cité Soleil will not only benefit from services that encourage them and help them attain educational improvement, but will also be the medium through which other youth in the target areas will be inspired and seek access to educational attainment. Through motivational speaking (during outreach & recruitment) and through mentorship and academic support (via the service projects), HELP students will not only benefit from the enhanced services the project offers but will also contribute to vastly enhancing the services offered to high school students.

Name: Haiti Cholera Prevention and Response Program
External_Title__c: Haiti Cholera Prevention and Response Program
Summary__c:
Since the beginning of the devastating cholera outbreak in October 2010, American Red Cross (ARC) work in Haiti has included activities in emergency response, referral, prevention and treatment. Despite the support provided by the Red Cross movement including other humanitarian organizations in the aftermath of the 2010 cholera outbreak, the need to eliminate cholera in Haiti remains. Cholera prevention and response was identified as one of the key priority areas that require continuous attention by the Red Cross partners during the humanitarian needs analysis carried out after the 3rd anniversary of the 2010 earthquake by HRC and IFRC in consultation with Haitian Government Authorities.  Following that assessment, ARC initiated a high level consultation in August, 2013 with a number of key cholera partners to understand the needs at the local and departmental level and how the Red Cross partners could use their strategic advantage to address these needs. Following the consultations it became apparent to ARC that the priority geographic areas that required support from ARC are the North, Northeast, Artibornite and the West departments. It was also evident from the assessment that the continued persistence of cholera in these departments is primarily due to lack of funding to support prevention and response programs.
 
Due to the ongoing needs in cholera prevention and response to eliminate cholera in Haiti, an additional $2,8 million was allocated to five organizations in support of the UNICEF short-term objective to reduce the annual incidence rate of cholera from 3% to less than 0.5% during the period 2013-2015. By focusing on the UNICEF strategy, ARC’s cholera prevention and response is in line with the Government of Haiti’s plan for the elimination of cholera in Haiti. These five organizations are the HRC, Swiss RC, Norwegian RC, FRC and Oxfam.

Name: RFL-Outreach-Puerto Rico
Summary__c: This project will provide the Puerto Rico chapter in the San Juan Region with funds to increase their capacity for outreach. Puerto Rico has a large, undocumented Dominican population. This project will target them with information regarding the reconnecting families work of the Red Cross, as well as, disaster preparedness.

Name: FY16 IFRC Cash in Emergencies Cash Pledge
Security Grant to MAEC (CIF)
External_Title__c: Security Wall Construction for MAEC (CIF)
Summary__c:
In 2005, La Maison l’Arc-en-Ciel purchased a property of 3,55 Ha with a view to implementing its in-house program,  establishing a foster home center to accommodate abandoned, HIV/AIDS infected/affected children.  In 2007, the construction work of the residential unit was undertaken, and in September 2010, both the children and staff were able to move and settle in this new place.
 
The property’s particular location in an agricultural area situated in Thomassin 32, facilitate the implementation of various farming activity programs (including chicken farming and animal husbandry) aimed at training children too old to be enrolled in regular schooling programs, while also helping their integration into the labor market at the end of the training process.  Whereas these farming programs result in the development of income generating activities, they also reduce our dependency on externally procured food items, as various food crops are grown on the property.
 
From June through November of this year, our institution received death threats and experienced violent aggressions from a gang known for being a criminal organization specialized in lands/property usurpation, misappropriation and encroachment in the Thomassin area.  Using violence and brutal force, this gang attempted an unlawful entry of the property through illegal rock mining activities, digging the ground with the view of building a foundation and dividing up the land to attract potential buyers.
 
Numerous measures were undertaken to notify the relevant state authorities, our partners, the embassies, requesting the assistance needed to protect the traumatized children.
 
The project submitted to the American Red Cross is a request for a financial assistance to be used for the building of a stone enclosure wall aimed at permanently ensuring the security of the most vulnerable 778 meters over the total perimeter of 933 meters).

Name: IFRC Haiyan Recovery - Babatngon
External_Title__c: IFRC Haiyan Recovery - Babatngon
Summary__c:
This project is the result of a negotiation between American RC and IFRC around funding transferred to IFRC during the relief phase after Typhoon Haiyan that ended up going unused as of the end of relief activities.  American RC authorized the redirection of just over $1.3 million of the unspent funds to this recovery initiative in Babatngon municipality.  The goal for this project is the provision of recovery assistance to an approximately of 850 households (4,250 beneficiaries) from five (5) coastal barangays in terms of shelter, livelihood, and capacity building through implementation of disaster risk reduction activities in communities and schools for a period of twelve months.

Specific objectives include: 
  • 200 households receive construction assistance for core shelter – Type A design;
  • 300 households received shelter repair assistance;
  • 600 households receive livelihood assistance through conditional cash grants to kick start livelihood
  • 100 individuals receive livelihood assistance through skills training programmes
  • Five barangays receive livelihood assistance through support for community-based livelihood projects.
  • Five barangays receive water and sanitation assistance through support for community-based projects.
  • Capacity building in disaster risk reduction for communities and schools.
Note that, due to the negotiated nature of this project, there is no separate charter (since the funds were transferred via emergency phase cash pledges).

Name: Indonesia Disaster Management & Logistics Readiness with OFDA
Summary__c:
Indonesian Disaster Management and Logistics Readiness - Emergency Water Supply and Strengthening Regional Logistics Capacity

Start Date: April 15, 2016
End Date: October 14, 2018 (30 months)
Budget Ceiling: $2,400,000  (Initial Obligated Amount: $900,000)
OFDA Sectors: WASH; Risk Management Policy and Practice

Program Goal: Assistance to drought affected populations and improved PMI disaster response capacity and improved coordination among key stakeholders during short-term El Niño-related drought, related and longer term disaster management situations.

Project Geographic Areas: 
WASH: East Java, Central Java, West Java, East Nusa Tenggara and West Nusa Tenggara
Risk Managemnt Policy and Practice: Sumatra Region (Padang and Aceh), Kalimantan region (South Kalimantan), West Java, Central Java, East Java-Bali-NTT-NTB region (East Java and Bali), and Sulawesi-Maluku-Papua region (South Sulawesi, North Sulawesi and Papua)

Executive Summary:
The ongoing El Niño-exacerbated drought has created significant water supply issues, and there remains a lack of understanding as to what the total water supply and demand by communities and service providers looks like. 

The American Red Cross (ARC) will work with the Indonesia Red Cross (Palang Merah Indonesia or PMI) to carry out:
a) comprehensive water supply assessment;
b) provide temporary water supply to communities adversely affected by severe drought conditions; and
c) strengthen existing PMI regional disaster response management by improving disaster management policies, standard operational procedures and coordination mechanisms related to water supply and  non-food-item (NFI) logistics with  government (i.e. BNPB, PDAM, PEMDA), international  organizations (e.g. UNICEF, WFP) and private sector (e.g., KADIN members). 

Project implementation will span 30 months. Although the assessment will examine all drought-affected (14) provinces to determine water service availability and to  confirm which are the worst affected districts, information from the Indonesian Meteorological, Climatology and Geophysics Department (BMKG) 14 drought-affected provinces that will require temporary water supply assistance have been tentatively identified as: East Nusa Tenggara, West Nusa Tenggara, East Java, Central Java, Jogjakarta, West Java, South Sulawesi, North Sulawesi, South Sumatra, Lampung, Banten, West Papua, Southeast Sulawesi, and Central Kalimantan. Based on BMKG’s current situation analysis and projections, WFP assessments, and ARC’s electronic survey related to drought conditions, the program will focus on the following 5 provinces: East Java, Central Java, West Java, East Nusa Tenggara, and West Nusa Tenggara. The exact number of beneficiaries will be determined through the base-line assessment and verification of the existing situation.  Strengthening PMI regional disaster management readiness and response capacity will ensure that it dovetails well with other disaster response efforts by the government and private sector. This project will improve emergency supply coordination by working first with other stakeholders to better understand and address the immediate drought-related water supply problem.  Subsequently the project will build institutional capacity through improved management and coordination of other stakeholders’ efforts with PMI’s regional warehouse infrastructure hubs.

Name: HRC West Branch Development (LAMIKA Transition Project - Pillar 1)
External_Title__c: Haitian Red Cross West Branch Development
Summary__c: Via this project, LAMIKA/ARC will provide the Haitian Red Cross with $43,300 over the period of March 1, 2016 to December 31, 2016 to aid HRC's West Regional Committee (CROM) to take over LAMIKA’s Pillar I activities. HRC's West Branch management capacities will be reinforced through learning by doing process for delivering services related to health and DRR to the communities of Carrefour Feuilles. The population served will n from the eight communities of LAMIKA intervention area, 52,999 persons. Other collaborators will include the Civil Protection Direction (DPC), Ministry of Health (MSPP).

Name: Building Capacity of Haitian Red Cross Youth Department
External_Title__c: Kore Kwa Wouj Jenes
Summary__c:
The aim of this project is to support the strengthening of the Haitian Red Cross Youth to enhance the sustainability of the Haitian Red Cross. The project will target 11,000 young people between 15 and 25 years of age in the 14 regional branches of the National Society.

The project aims to achieve the following specific objectives:
  •  Promote the representation and participation of young people in HRC’s governance structures through leadership training. 
  • Strengthen strategic alliances with other youth organizations such as the Scouts of Haiti, Kiro, Young Adventists (YA), Volunteer for Haiti Development (VHD), Junior International Youth Chamber (IYC), HELP, FOKAL the Dominican Red Cross Youth and other organizations in the Caribbean.
  • Strengthen the Haitian Red Cross Youth capacity to become social and economic development agents in their community. 
  • Revitalize the Haitian Red Cross Youth volunteer network through awareness campaigns, recruitment campaigns, training and retention activities.
  • Support the strengthening of the administration of the Haitian Red Cross Youth Coordination Unit.

Name: FY16 Building Resilient African Communities (BRACES) in Zambia (Africa)
Sub_Sector__c: Community-Based Disaster Preparedness;Micro-mitigation Projects;Education and Awareness;Branch Development
Summary__c:
Building Resilient African Communities (BRACES) is a multi-year program designed to increase the resilience of communities to withstand the shocks and stresses of annual floods in the Zambezi River basin. This project complements and supports the  Zambezi River Basin Initiative activities implemented by Zambia Red Cross Society with support from IFRC, set to close in August 2015.  
 
Working closely with the Zambia Red Cross Society, the primary objective of this project is to reduce the number of deaths, injuries and socioeconomic impacts caused by disasters through strengthening the Zambia Red Cross Society (ZRCS) and building safer and more resilient communities in the Sesheke, Kazungula and Mwandi districts. 

In FY16 key activities include: 
- Environmental management & natural resource protection training for ZRCS staff, BEC and other stakeholders
- Emergency needs assessment training for the SDMCs
- BOCA
- Environmental awareness campaign and tree planting
- District stakeholder engagement
- Cookstove construction
- Micro-mitigation projects such as road clearing and well rehabilitation
- Farmer training and agricultural inputs
- Small livestock promotion

Name: FY16 Zimbabwe Urban Disaster Risk Reduction (UDRR) (Africa)
External_Title__c: Zimbabwe Urban Disaster Risk Reduction
Sub_Sector__c: First Aid;Hygiene Promotion;Water Infrastructure;Education and Awareness;Urban;Solid Waste / Trash Collection
Summary__c: To be input.

Name: FY16 Building Resilient African Communities (BRACES) in Zimbabwe (Africa)
Sub_Sector__c: First Aid;Health Promotion;Sanitation Facilities;Hygiene Promotion;Community-Based Disaster Preparedness;Micro-mitigation Projects;Water Infrastructure;Water Supply;Education and Awareness;Branch Development;Resource Mobilization
Summary__c:
Building Resilient African Communities (BRACES) is a multi-year program – currently in Phase IV in Zimbabwe - designed to increase the resilience of communities to withstand the shocks and stresses of annual floods and droughts in the Zambezi River basin. This project complements and supports the Zambezi River Basin Initiative activities implemented by Zimbabwe Red Cross Society and the IFRC, that is currently set to close down in August 2015.
 
Working closely with the Zimbabwe Red Cross Society, the primary objective of this project is to reduce the number of deaths, injuries and socioeconomic impacts caused by disasters through strengthening the Zimbabwe Red Cross Society (ZRCS) and building safer and more resilient communities in four Administrative Wards: Siachilaba, Simatelele, Manjolo and Saba in Binga District, Zimbabwe. 
 
FY16 project activities include the following:
-Stakeholder engagement
-Estbalishment of Ward Civil Protection Unit
-Construction of 105 latrines
-Branch office construction and supporting resource mob activities
-First Aid & DRR training
-Health & hygiene promotion
-BOCA
-Estblishment of water supply
-Red Cross Youth Clubs

Name: Building Resilience in Chaparrastique Volcano Affected Communities (Phase 2)
External_Title__c: Building Resilience in Chaparrastique Volcano Affected Communities
Summary__c: In December 2013, El Salvador’s third highest volcano, Chaparrastique, erupted causing thousands to flee their homes. The Salvadoran Red Cross responded immediately providing assistance to the communities and coordinating with local authorities. Despite these efforts, this event demonstrated that communities were neither well prepared nor organized to respond to the event. With the volcano remaining active, with small explosions being reported as recently as January 2015, and subsequent eruption or other natural disasters inevitable, proper preparation and planning is critical. This project build off the current phase of the Building resilience in Chaparrastique Volcano Affect Communities project to ensure that a wider reach of communities, schools and local agencies within the direct vicinity of the volcano are better prepared for and able to respond to future disasters. The project targets 11 communities which have been selected based on their vulnerability and exposure to the volcano, leaving them at greatest risk to subsequent volcanic eruptions and landslides. The project will include activities such as first aid training, creation and training of community committees, creation of community disaster plans, installation of early warning systems, and simulation exercises which will increase community knowledge and preparedness to address future disaster hazards and risk. In order to increase knowledge and preparedness in the school systems, trainings in First Aid and psychosocial support will be conducted, evacuation and school protection plans developed, and school simulations carried out. Lastly, training in Damage Assessments (EDAN) and Management of Emergency Operations Centers (MACOE), Shelter management and School Safety (SSC) will be provided to local authorities to strengthen their ability to carry out rapid damage and needs assessments and enhance their administrative capacity.
